PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Public Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Federal Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients, and call upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron (from 20 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from 15 citizens) and Mr Shipton (from 116 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Public Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned electors of the Division of Corangamite, respectively showeth:

That we are gravely concerned about the public release of confidential medical information, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients, and call upon the House to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
Your petitioners, therefore, pray that the House ensures that there will be no further public release of such private confidential medical information.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectively showeth:
That there is a general dissatisfaction in the community at the levels of road funding made available by the Federal Government.
While noting the commitment of the Government to maintain a high standard of roads in Australia, we are specifically concerned at the real cutbacks for road fund- ing in the Local Government area.
We especially note that roadworks are a labour intensive industry and cutbacks will create unemployment and hardship in rural areas.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, give due consideration to increasing the amount of funds available to Local Government authorities for roadworks.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby (from 77 citizens) and Mr Mildren (from 519 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Murray respectfully showeth that:
Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will

Refer the above mentioned Bill to an appropriate Parliamentary committee and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards (from 11 citizens) and Mr Johns (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the urgent need, in this Bicentennial year, to acknowledge that Australia was occupied by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders for thousands of years before British Settlement in 1788, and to acknowledge the importance of their culture and heritage.
Your petitioners therefore request that our federal parliamentarians pass unanimously a resolution in the presence of the Queen on May 9, at the opening of the new Parliament House stating:
The Queen, and the Senate and the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia acknowledge that:
Australia was occupied by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who had settled for thousands of years before British settlement at Sydney Cove on January 26, 1788.
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were denied legal recognition of their land rights upon acquisition of their traditional lands by the British Crown.
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were denied full citizenship rights of the Commonwealth of Australia prior to May 27, 1967.
And affirm:
The importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage.
The entitlement of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia.

And consider it desirable that the Commonwealth negotiate the terms of a compact with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hand (from seven citizens) and Mr Katter (from 154 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament.

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Kennedy draws to the attention of the House the urgent need, in this Bicentennial year, to acknowledge that Australia was occupied by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders for thousands of years before British Settlement in 1788, and to acknowledge the importance of their culture and heritage.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House pass unanimously a resolution in the presence of the Queen on May 9, at the opening of the new Parliament House stating:
The Queen, and the Senate and the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia acknowledge that:
Australia was occupied by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who had settled for thousands of years before British settlement at Sydney Cove on January 26, 1788.
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were denied legal recognition of their land rights upon acquisition of their traditional lands by the British Crown.
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were denied full citizenship rights of the Commonwealth of Australia prior to May 27, 1967.
And affirm:
The importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage.
The entitlement of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia.

And consider it desirable that the Commonwealth negotiate the terms of a compact with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker (from 238 citizens) and Mr Shipton (from 249 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Government. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the House to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Milton (from 100 citizens) and Mr Scott (from 30 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern about the proposal to Irradiate Food in Australia.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should:
Block the introduction of Food Irradiation into Australia
Bans the import of Cobalt-60 and Cesium-137 and Cesium-134 to be used to Irradiate Food products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned residents of South Australia are concerned that patient care for nursing home residents will be adversely affected when staffing hours are reduced as from 1st July 1988.
We humbly pray that the decision be urgently reconsidered and withdrawn so that our senior citizens can have adequate care and observation on their failing years.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned Electors showeth:

That any proposed redistribution of funds for Nursing and Personal Care staff costs in Nursing Homes will detrimentally affect the quality of care given in Nursing Homes in South Australia and the quality of life of the residents in those Nursing Homes, so recently established, will not be achieved and elderly people will not receive the standard of care or quality of life that they need.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will raise the funding level for Nursing and Personal Care staff hours for all States to enable at least the number of hours of care for Nursing Home residents in South Australia. To be achieved by all States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker of the House of Representatives and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Australian families are highly dependent upon telephone communications.
2. The Australian community needs an extensive and reasonably priced telephone system.
3. For many Australians, especially the aged and infirm, the telephone provides a ready means of communication especially at times of illness.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House of Representatives will take measures to ensure that the aged, infirm, and other fixed-income groups that are dependent on telephone communication are in no way disadvantaged by any changes to the system of charging for local telephone calls.

PETITION.TITLE: Gymea Bay Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office at Gymea Bay be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, or even to collect registered letters and parcels, cash Pension cheques and transact banking. Many of us are Pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Office is 2.3 kms away with no convenient transport.

We maintain that the purpose of the Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Gymea Bay Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will revoke the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983, will also revoke the new section 4a of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, and bring back the former section 4a which banned the importation of blasphemous, indecent, or obscene matter or goods into Australia, because sex shops are being set up in every suburb and town and we are powerless while obscene books are legally available;
because there is a flood of obscene publications into the country
because such publications depict the abnormal as normal
because such publications degrade men and women
because such publications create new, offensive demands on women, with which they do not willingly comply (Eysenck and Nias)
because this causes marriage breakdown
because children easily obtain such publications
because children copy what they see

because the child found in possession of such publications is at risk, facing rejection, and carrying the burden of having altered the relationships in his home for the worse, between parents, and between parent and child
because such a child faces, alone, the loss of trust
because I am a reasonable adult person and I am offended by the obscene books which you have legislated into this community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will follow the example of our Western Australian Government and legislate to make the possession of child pornography a criminal offence, with strong deterrent penalties, likewise the sale and hire of such obscene publication or video, or other goods; also that the Customs barriers be closed to pornography, and all such crime stimuli, because there are escalating crime statistics, and innocent victims, and the community is outraged by them. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, shall ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence: Television and Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Wannon electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is too much crime and violence on TV and depicted in videos and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. Urge TV stations to reduce the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
2. Introduce tighter controls on the sale and classification of videos so as to limit the access of children to inappropriate material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Jervis Bay National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia who are concerned residents, visitors and holiday-makers, draws to the attention of the House the importance of preserving the natural beauty and environment of Jervis Bay and their support for the proposal of the National Trust of Australia for the permanent protection of natural areas in the vicinity of that bay as the minimum NSW land needed for Jervis Bay National Park.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to preserve an important part of our national heritage by:
(1) Taking all steps necessary towards the formation of a Jervis Bay National Park that would include:

all Commonwealth controlled land on Bherwerre Peninsula, Beecroft Peninsula and Bowen Island, in combination with suitable land around the perimeter of the Bay, thus forming a continuous National Park completely ringing Jervis Bay;
all Jervis Bay waters, plus waters surrounding Bhewerre and Beecroft Peninsulas.
(2) Establishing a Park management system based on the Uluru Model and by establishing a complementary regional management plan for the Jervis Bay region.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker the Honourable Joan Child and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia, in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens in the State of Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Government initiated that the 3 per cent Productivity payment be paid into Superannuation Schemes as basis for each worker ultimately providing their own Retirement benefits and that this system was to be adopted by all workers in Australia and thus reduce the drain on Social Service payments.

The Australian Government has now indicated it's intention to tax the profits of Superannuation Schemes which quite clearly will defeat the original purpose of Superannuation payments to all workers, by the erosion of final benefits able to be paid and thus reduce the standard of living of Superannuants.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
1. Desist from it's intention to further tax Superannuation Funds.
2. Encourage all workers to provide for their retirement years by contributing to Superannuation Schemes.
3. Maintain unaltered it's initial Superannuation Planning and Support for the benefit of all Australian workers.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Personnel Injured in Peacetime
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are totally opposed to the callous treatment of the survivors, widows and next of kin of HMAS Voyager and all other service personnel injured in peacetime.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take action to rectify the matter.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation

The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We are opposed to the proposed restructuring of the A.B.C. We believe that the A.B.C. is one of the most important public services in Australia and a mainstay of democracy.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House of Representatives will take measures to ensure that the A.B.C. is permitted to continue to offer `comprehensive' broadcasting services under its present charter.

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Fairlight Post Office agency is to be closed.

It serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels, and would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that The House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of this post office agency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Day of Prayer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker of the House of Representatives, and Parliament assembled.
`Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a disgrace to any people.' Proverbs 14:34
Considering:
1. the loss of hope among the youth of the nation.
2. the breakdown of the family unit.
3. the increase of corruption in our society.
4. the increasing weight of our national debt.
5. the emerging divisions in our community.
We petition you to:
1. encourage every Australia to see his/her responsibility to live uprightly before God and others;
2. encourage commitment in marriage and encourage fathers and mothers to love and cherish their children;
3. encourage the Members of Parliament to live and legislate according to Biblical principles;
4. encourage business in Australia to pursue their transactions in generosity-without greed;
5. support the Christian Church in expressing the friendship of God, and in carrying out its practical responsibilities to the poor, needy and dispossessed.
by calling a National Day of Prayer for Australia, to seek God's help to heal our land.
We as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mordechai Vanunu
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
Our deepest concern at the plight of Mordechai Vanunu, who revealed details of the nuclear weapons arsenal of Israel;
Our belief that Vanunu's actions were a service to humanity-including to the people of Israel-and were in fulfilment of his duty under international law;

Our belief that the unlawful abduction of Vanunu from Rome, his imprisonment since then, his prison conditions, and his conviction on charges of espionage and treason are denials of his fundamental human rights.
Your petitioners ask that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled should:
Resolve to ask the Australian Government to appeal to the Government of Israel to release Mordechai Vanunu immediately and without conditions.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned by the threat to social morality and the welfare of children, posed by the unrestricted importation, distribution and sale of X-rated pornographic video material in and from the Australian Capital Territory

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and reverse its amendments to ACT legislation and Customs regulations which have resulted in Australia wide distribution of material restricted under State censorship laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens in Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutrional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your petitioners therefore request that your honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
(1) That we oppose timed local calls by Telecom
(2) Timed calls should not be introduced in the absence of widespread community support

(3) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject plans by Telecom to time charge local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material I present the report of the Committee, incorporating a number of dissenting reports, together with the transcript of evidence. The report consists of two volumes, volume 1 being the report proper and volume 2 being dissents, comment, dissenting reports and appendices.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material is the product of a Committee which was set up in mid-1985 to inquire into the operation of current legislation for the control of video material. The Committee's terms of reference focused on the adequacy and effectiveness of current Commonwealth law in the face of a rapidly developing market for video material and an industry that has grown to cater for it. The terms of reference were identical to those of the Senate select committee which was set up in October 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: The report covers a large amount of ground and may be difficult for honourable members to follow without some explanation as to its nature. It consists of 829 pages of text in two volumes and I am given only 15 minutes to present it. The first volume contains what was finally adopted as the `majority' report, together with conclusions and recommendations. The second contains four dissents from sections of the majority report, a qualifying comment on the majority report, a complete dissenting minority report, with recommendations, signed by five people, including myself-the Committee consisted of 11 people, by the way-and 12 appendices. The report has ended up in this unwieldy form because of basic philosophical disagreements among Committee members which in the end proved irreconcilable. The disagreements were not on political party lines, as the House will find as the debate progresses. The majority report in the first volume is the result of close voting on most chapters, with the composition of the majority often varying.

The meanings given by the Committee to the words `violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene' used in the terms of reference was one of the issues of contention within the Committee, and this is reflected in the substantial difference between chapter 3 of the original Chairman's draft-now the minority report in volume 2-and that adopted by the majority in volume 1. Chapter 3 of the majority report defines `pornography' as material which is predominantly sexually explicit in theme and intended primarily for the purpose of sexual arousal. The definition adopted makes no distinction between `hard core' and `soft core' pornography, the majority of the Committee considering that it is `the theme, the message, the intent' that is crucial. The minority, on the other hand-of which I am a member-did not find it possible to propose a definition of `pornography' which would receive general acceptance. In the course of receiving submissions and taking evidence, it became clear to us that the term `pornography' meant different things to different people; that what is pornographic to one person may be merely erotic, humorous or boring to others. As an aside, I state that I found all the X-rated videos terribly corny and boring. We-that is, the minority group-felt, however, that the use of the label `pornography' implied merely that the material in question was to be condemned, and referred to the subjective reactions of individuals to particular representations of sex. The Committee was in more agreement in its understanding of violence, believing that the term is not subject to widespread differences of meaning.

Section II outlines the current law and the administrative arrangements associated with it. This discussion goes into considerable detail and is longer than is the case regarding most committee reports. It is a reflection of the Committee's experience that a widespread misunderstanding or ignorance of what is contained in the laws which govern the control of video material exists in the Australian community, and even amongst parliamentarians, at the present time.

For instance, many of the submissions the Committee received referred to child pornography, snuff movies and beastiality as examples of the kind of material that needed to be banned in Australia. However, these have been and are currently banned for import and distribution. Moreover, changes in both the legislation and the administrative guidelines in the course of 1984 under the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, tightened the prohibitions on violence of any kind to include `detailed and gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty'.

The majority report takes the view that almost all sexually explicit video material is pornography-and I emphasise `almost'-that pornography is harmful and that sexually explicit videos should therefore be banned. The minority report takes the view that democratic government should intervene in the private behaviour of citizens only when there is clear evidence of harm resulting from their behaviour. The minority saw no evidence of a causal connection between viewing of sexually explicit videos of a non-violent kind and harm or harmful behaviour resulting from such viewing. On the basis of the research studies by social and behavioural scientists available to us, we found that these studies do not support the proposition that they cause harm. There are great problems with the methodology of most of the experimental studies and the results of every study seem to be disputed by other workers in the field.

Both reports indicate a fair degree of satisfaction with the present legislation dealing with video materials. Both, however, see a need to afford greater protection to those likely to be affronted by certain kinds of material. Both also suggest that further offences be created by legislation, to deal with the viewing of video by minors whilst outside the direct control of parents or guardians. We recommend that there should be a new category NVE, non-violent erotica, and that the new NVE category contain that material defined in the current classification of X, that is, material `which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but does not include any depictions suggesting coercion, or non-consent of any kind'. Viewing of videos rated NVE should be restricted to adults. Major recommendations in relation to minors are as follows and I believe that the recommendations are contained in both the minority and the majority reports:
That it be an offence to show a minor an R-rated or NVE-rated film without the consent of a parent or guardian of the minor.
That all R-rated material along with NVE-rated material be displayed in a restricted room or if not displayed in such a way be made available to those over 18 by catalogue at the counter.
That all promotional material related to R-and NVE-rated videos or films, for that matter, be similarly restricted.
Other recommendations refer to labelling for improved consumer information and to the structure and function of the Film Censorship Board. The Committee recommends that:

The specific reasons, that is, whether due to language, violence, or sexual or other content and its frequency, intensity or purpose for classifying a Film non-G be displayed on the front cover of video slicks.
It seems quite ridiculous to me that there is a classification PG, that is parental guidance. How can the parent guide when he does not know the content of the video film?

The Committee sees the advantages of a single central classification system; however, it respects the rights of the States to review the classification in the light of their own view of their community standards. It strongly recommends that a widespread education campaign with input from the Film Censorship Board, relevant Federal and State authorities and the film and video marketing and distribution industry be mounted to combat a lack of community awareness about the meaning of classification categories and their contents.

My last act as Chairman must be to thank the large number of people-individual citizens, representatives of organisations, academics and social scientists-who contributed to the inquiry by written submissions, personal appearance or the provision of documentary material. I must say, however, that, while they were helpful in crystallising our view, I would be surprised if any member of the Committee could honestly say that his or her views on the major issues were significantly changed by any of the submissions or evidence. The report, lengthy and somewhat confused though it may seem, clearly reflects the plurality of views that exist in the wide community on this issue.

I wish to acknowledge the very valuable assistance the Committee has received from the Secretary, Jane Vincent; the research officer, Rosemary Brissenden; Sarah Drysdale, the steno-secretary; and her predecessor, Janice Paull.

In regard to acknowledgments on page xvii, the work of the Committee staff was made much more difficult by changes in the Committee membership following the Federal election in 1987. This resulted in the Chairman's draft becoming a minority report. The majority of the Committee asked me to change those two sentences and the Committee agreed to this change: `The work of the Committee staff, especially the Secretary, was made much more difficult by the Chairman's draft becoming a minority report.'The reference to the 1987 election is ignored. This entailed a great amount of extra work in helping prepare a new majority report. I would also like to thank the other officers of the Senate Committee Office who assisted the Committee during the period of its inquiry: Mr Ron Wiber, who was Secretary of the Senate Select Committee and then at the beginning of our Committee, for providing continuity at the beginning of this Committee's inquiry; Mr Terry Brooks, Director, Censorship Section, Attorney-General's Department; the Film Censorship Board for its ready assistance at the various stages of inquiry; and finally the Parliamentary Reporting Staff for providing transcripts of evidence.

As I have only a few minutes left, I want to give some of my own views. However, I hope that this report will help in the discussion of this important issue, which should not be dealt with simplistically. People who know me know my favourite quotation from H. L. Mencken:
To every complex problem there is a simple solution and it is always wrong.

I believe that this is a very complex problem. In this case the simple solution would be to ban things: if we do not like them, ban them. My own view on what is happening with videos is that to a large extent people are scared of new technology. If we look at history, from the arrival of black and white films, through the silent movies era, sound movies, technicolour movies, black and white and then colour television, and finally videos-and I am sure it will go further than that-we can see that people are always scared that somehow these innovations will change society. This tendency goes back much further, to the time when printing became relatively popular and cheap. People are always scared that such innovations will destroy society and its values. They do not seem to have any great confidence that society can continue to exist without the benefits of censorship.

I wish to put to the House the propositions I put to the Joint Select Committee on Video Material on 22 October 1987-a long time ago now. Obviously the report was not completely drafted then, but I believed in these propositions then and I still believe in them. I think governments should agree with them. They are as follows:

We believe that censorship for adults in a democratic society can only be justified if physical or at least significant psychological `harm' is caused to a significant proportion of the population; that the material is likely to cause serious anti-social behaviour in a reasonable adult person. We cannot adopt general standards which are based on the reaction of children or adults with strong psychotic tendencies.

The so-called scientific evidence from the social scientists as to the harmful effects, if any, of various types of films (and videos) was not convincing. We conclude that the available research is of very limited use. The Committee is not prepared to state solely on the basis of the evidence and research it has seen that exposure to a variety of films and videos currently classifiable in Australia cause significant harm.

We believe that harm sufficient to justify censorship must be of an identifiable kind. Films which may lead to a change of community standards do not constitute the type of harm necessary to justify censorship. The defence of so-called `community standards' is a matter for rational debate and education and not for protection by censorship.
The current X classification, although some minor alterations might be warranted, does not cause the type of harm necessary to justify censorship.

We feel that the main aim of the classification system should be consumer guidance. There should be sufficient information to identify potentially offensive material, and this requirement can probably be met by the Film Censorship Board's explanatory key to reasons for classification-`sex', `violence', `language', and `other' on the scale of frequency, explicitness/intensity and purpose-being available to the consumer at the point of sale/hire.

Whilst the Committee members share an abhorrence of violence, we feel that the difficulties in identifying suitable guideline terminology to delete excessively violent films may in fact result in the unintended deletion of films of merit. The current guideline terminology used by the FCB to determine the definition of different degrees of violence-gratuitous, discreet and exploitative-is not without interpretative difficulty, but any recommendation to alter the terminology may prove not to be more effective in practice. But we do support a stricter interpretation of the current guidelines.

The use of such terms as `violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material' even in our Terms of Reference make it difficult to reply intelligently as the meaning is not clearly definable. Other terms such as `blasphemous' and `dehumanising' are also extremely difficult to define. The Committee found from the evidence and submissions that such terms mean different things to different people.

I conclude by drawing the attention of the House to the response to term of reference (1), because I think it is extremely relevant. I would like to thank members of the Committee. We had lots of brawls. I enjoyed them. I see that Senator Walters is in the gallery. She may not have enjoyed them, but she certainly participated. Again, I thank members of the Committee for their contributions and participation during the long existence of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It can be seen from the voluminous nature of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material and the long list of witnesses and hearings that the Committee faced an enormous task. My dissent to major recommendations has been recorded and I propose to comment on some of the submissions to the Committee opposite to both that dissent and other findings of the Committee. I am far from happy with the implication that there was no hard evidence that pornographic videos cause harm. The report tends to suggest that on some occasions submissions indicating such harm comprised opinion but not hard evidence. I entirely disagree with that view. I listened very carefully to social workers, priests-a young priest in Melbourne in particular-and concerned people. To disregard their documented evidence is to turn a blind eye.

SPEECH.PARA: We were confronted with suggestions of prostitution, exploitation and degradation of boys and girls. We were told the manipulators-the exploiters-made use of pornographic films, videos and publications in coaxing young people into this life. Not infrequently, associated with this, drugs and pornography were interlinked. The assertions that criminal elements were actively associated with the production of pornographic videos and material could not be lightly dismissed. Whether this is evidence of the type weighed by a court of law is, to me, splitting hairs. It was the sober, serious observation of those who knew best-those who work among the broken, exploited people and try to salvage them from the degradation into which they have been plunged. I pronounce, without any reservation, that pornographic videos are a major and guilty factor.

I believe that all present X-rated and R-rated video material should be refused classification. Of course, purveyors of this material will protest. It is a highly lucrative business. There is evidence everywhere of the harm it produces. There is not one shred of evidence anywhere of any virtue. It is not produced to bring any benefit to the community; it is produced to make money. It is produced without any consideration of lives that might be destroyed and the harvest it might produce.

This material is available to minors in the Australian Capital Territory. We had hard evidence of that. The explanation that it is difficult for video proprietors to know how old a person is will not suffice. Indeed, we were given evidence that a child of 12 or 13, very obviously well below the age of 18, had no difficulty in hiring X-rated and R-rated videos in Canberra. I believe that there are plenty of proofs of age which could have been required, and I do not believe that there has been a real endeavour in many cases to inquire adequately into or enforce the requirement that such material should not be hired to minors.

The Committee did not agree with my endeavour to control another stream of this pernicious material. I believe that it should be made an offence to send this material through the mail or by other means. It is a farce when States legislate against such material, when distributors in Canberra can and do legally through the mail send to those States catalogues and videos refused classification in those States. Canberra is the pornography capital and efforts in the States to control such video material are completely nullified by the flood of mail orders out of Canberra. I repeat that it should be made an offence to use the mail for such a purpose.

Because I believe that such material should be refused classification, I also naturally dissented from the recommendation that registered hard top cinemas be allowed to screen such films. That would provide a bonanza for the raincoat brigade, a possible source of perversion, a possible place of conscription of young people into vice and prostitution. Again, if not legally provable, there is plenty of circumstantial evidence associating the appetite for pornography with crimes of rape, molestation and worse. We have heard pronouncements of judges on that matter.

Its very purpose is to excite and arouse and without a doubt that can be a powerful catalyst to unstable and perverted people with criminal tendencies. It would harm not a single person if this material was taken away, but it would remove much of the crime, misery and human degradation which every one of us deplores. Who could reasonably complain when the purpose of its production is to make profits by exciting and arousing? The only reason to view it is to be aroused because there is no story, no beauty and no other attraction in any of it. To claim that we care for society and for our young people and to allow this trade to flourish I believe is arrant hypocrisy.

I have absolutely no sympathy for the proposition that if we ban it we merely send it underground. That point of view is unsustainable. If that were credible we would not act against drugs or any other crime. We have no compunction about legislating against cigarette smoking in public transport and other places, yet we allow video pornography to flourish on the pretext that we do not want to drive it underground. If we are serious about it, if we police it and if penalties are severe enough, we certainly can effectively take action against it. We should be serious about it because the sufferers are the innocent, the impressionable and the young. Surely it is our responsibility to afford them some protection.

The least impressive witnesses in my view were those from the video promotion industry. I was aghast at the amount of money turned over by this industry. To hear the witnesses maintaining that they are providing a service to society and have them attempt to suggest that it is a commendable and desirable service was the most tongue in cheek submission that I have ever heard. I cannot accept their protestations that they are concerned about our minors, our boys and girls, and that they would not want to see any harm visited on them. Their total aim, of course, is profit. To make another category-non-violent erotica-and to place information about the video on the cassette and container would achieve nothing; it would merely reinforce and condone what I believe is a trade as pernicious in many ways as the drug trade. It perpetuates and promotes the degrading and dehumanising of mankind and, in particular, women, and it should be given no reinforcement or mark of approval.

As a member of the Committee I received hundreds of letters from all over Australia. I received many phone calls and many people came to my office. I do not recall any of those submissions, save one from the adult video industry, which did not express concern about video pornography and seek positive action against it. It is quite clear what the vast majority of Australians feel about these videos. They were so concerned that I was besieged by protests and I sent many of them on to the Chairman of the Committee. I believe that people will be disappointed and somewhat disenchanted with this report and that they will expect this Parliament to act more positively in the matter. It is all very well to say that adults should be allowed to see and view whatever takes their fancy. In other matters where it is evident that harm and suffering are caused to other people, we are prepared to act. In this instance to do otherwise is a weak unacceptable alibi.

To those who say that it is the responsibility of parents I reply that they are not living in the real world. While there is a place where children-perhaps children visiting mates-can see the material and while there is a profit to be made by peddling the material to young people, and no matter what parents do to ensure that their children are not exposed to it in their own home, children will see it. This industry, because of its pervasiveness, will do as much to undermine parental guidance, control and training as any industry I know. The evidence of teachers who tell of the effect, the impact and often the trauma they see in children who have been exposed to X- and R-rated videos was quite unequivocal and virtually unanimously condemnatory. The evidence of psychiatrists, police, and students of criminology to a greater or lesser degree, was a saga of concern if not, in some cases, outright condemnation. The evidence of Mafia involvement in the United States of America in the video pornography industry was conclusive. If it was not proven in the Australian scene it was very much indicated or suggested. To refuse to face up to the serious reality and to cavalierly pontificate that it is a parental responsibility is reprehensible.

Certainly the Government must face up to the fact that Canberra and the Northern Territory, areas under its jurisdiction, are the distribution centres. It must acknowledge that States which legislate against its distribution are powerless because it is distributed from our Commonwealth Territories. Thus the responsibility rests with this Parliament. I speak not to impose my view of morality on others; I speak because I am concerned about the evidence of harm reaching out to our community and especially to our young people. For that reason I believe that X-rated and R-rated videos should be refused classification. I wish the report had more positively recommended that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to comment on the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material which has just been tabled by the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman). The report addresses many complex issues and questions. They are issues on which honourable members of this House and members of the general community hold strong and often divergent views. To gain a true appreciation of this report honourable members must go beyond the summary and the recommendations. Chapters dealing with terminology, values and perspectives, the likely effects of video material and the issue of access of minors, are essential reading for those interested in this important subject.

SPEECH.PARA: Along with the majority of the Committee I support the arguments in these chapters, and throughout the report, as contained in volume 1. However, I have dissented from recommendations 1 and 2. Recommendations 1 and 2 propose a new category of video material referred as non-violent erotica (NVE), or to describe it more accurately, hard core pornography. This proposal obtained majority support only through a strange convergence of diverse views. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) voted with the proponents of such a category. However, he holds a uniquely narrow view about what should be included in this proposed classification and thus has joined other members of the committee, me included, in forming a majority dissent to the content provisions set out in recommendation 2. I dissented from the recommendations supporting the introduction of this new category as it would entrench pornographic video material in the community under the misleading title of NVE. The proposal runs counter to the evidence submitted to the Committee concerning the harmful effects of this material and is inconsistent with the findings of the Committee. A keystone of the Committee's findings is expressed in the summary of chapter 13 which states:

Theories of behavioural science, laboratory experiments and anecdotal evidence point strongly to the fact that the effects of pornography are not aberrations. Responses to pornographic stimuli fall within the range of human behaviour. It cannot logically be argued that the effects of pornography can safely be ignored because, supposedly, only deviants would respond to pornographic influences. While behavioural science studies in this area do not provide certainty they do establish theories which make reliable predictions about human behaviour. It would therefore be unenlightened for Parliament to ignore them.

We have therefore recommended that the Commonwealth Government introduce substantive legislation to ensure that this material is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws. I refer honourable members to the majority response to recommendation 2 which is placed at the end of chapter 17, `Conclusions and Recommendations' in volume 1. A great deal of the Committee's work and of the report of the Committee is devoted to the question of the potential harm to children and adults caused by explicit violent and pornographic material. Such complex questions of human psychology and behaviour cannot be answered conclusively. However, the qualitative evidence given to the Committee from a wide variety of sources points strongly to the dangers posed by explicit sexual and violent material. Where the theories of behavioural science, laboratory experiments and anecdotal evidence all establish serious concerns about the potential harm posed by this material, the benefit of any doubt or concern must be given in favour of the wider community.

It must be remembered that Australia's enlightened and liberal censorship laws were largely framed before the advent of home video machines, corner store video libraries and mail order video outlets. Explicit sexual or violent material was therefore confined to the printed format or through the relatively control mediums of television or cinema. We must accept that despite the recommendations of this Committee, action by this Parliament or the earnest endeavours of responsible parents, there is no satisfactory solution to the problem of children gaining access to video material. Because of the dangers pointed to by the evidence, the access to such material by young people and the degrading way in which pornography depicts women, I strongly believe that the onus of proof regarding any new category of classification rests with those who propose it. The proponents of NVE have failed to discharge that onus of proof, particularly in light of the evidence as presented to the Committee.

I would like to comment briefly on some of the other recommendations contained in the report. There are a number of recommendations regarding the display and advertising of video cassettes. Recommendation 5 will significantly toughen the requirements to label video cassettes, cassette boxes and advertising material with the appropriate censorship classification symbol, including the age description. Recommendation 8 will clarify the position regarding advertising trailers and previews to ensure that any video cassette can include previews or trailers of films only of a censorship classification equal to or lower than that of the title feature. In recommendations 9 and 10 the Committee has taken strong steps to combat the problem of young people gaining access to violent or pornographic video material. The Committee has recommended that it be an offence to show a minor an R-rated or NVE film without the consent of a parent or guardian. Further, the Committee has recommended that all R-rated and NVE-rated material be displayed in a separate room and, where that type of display is not possible, it be made available to those over 18 by catalogues at the counter.

Also of concern to me was the volume of anecdotal evidence put to the Committee recounting instances of young people having seen an R-rated video whilst visiting a friend's place. The best efforts of Federal and State governments are no substitute for responsible parental control. The Government, schools and parent groups all have a role to play in emphasising to parents the need to scrutinise the material their children watch.

Recommendations 24 and 25 relate to changes to the classification guidelines. I moved recommendation 24 in the Committee to change the language criteria for the PG category so that it will have exactly the same language criteria as the G category. After watching a good deal of PG material, it became clear that some of the language allowed in this junior category was not acceptable. I was informed during discussions with the Film Censorship Board that it classified a film M because of excessive use of what is usually referred to as the `magic word'. On appeal by the producers to the Films Board of Review the film rating was dropped to PG in a near unanimous vote of that body. I am pleased that the majority of the Committee agreed with my proposal and I trust that this recommendation will be adopted promptly.

The parental guidance classification needs to be set at a level which parents would consider appropriate for younger children. Expressions similar to the one I have alluded to are clearly inappropriate to the age range the classification is intended for. The recommendation also does not give the Film Censorship Board or the Films Board of Review any leeway or flexibility in relation to the language guidelines for the G and PG classifications. Recommendation 25 changes the classification guidelines for violence in the R category. It is a small but important change in emphasis which the Committee hopes will exclude a small amount of material which might be described as `slasher' films, where there is a large amount of violence and some degree of enjoyment expressed by the characters portrayed inflicting such violence.

I have great faith in the integrity of the Film Censorship Board under the stewardship of the relatively new Chief Censor, Mr John Dickie. I am sure that the concerns of the wider community regarding violence will be taken into account. Together with a tighter interpretation of the guidelines as recommended by the Committee, not only in the R classification but also in the PG and M classifications, we will see films and videos being classified more in tune with those community concerns and standards.

Recommendation 28 strongly supports a wide-spread education campaign. I understand that the Film Censorship Board is already looking at this matter and I can only give it my full support and hope that it is successful in increasing community awareness of the meaning of classification categories and their content.

This is an important report, and I trust that the Commonwealth and State governments are able to agree on uniform legislative action and regulation, where appropriate, on the Committee's recommendations. This report is comprehensive in its approach to this complex subject and should be read thoroughly to obtain a greater understanding of the industry, its place in our society and the substantive questions with which the Committee has dealt.

Every member of the Committee has strong views on this subject. At some stages during the more heated Committee discussions I felt that if a video had been made of the proceedings it would have been banned on the grounds of excessive violence. However, the divergence of views within the Committee is only a reflection of the wide array of views held on these controversial subjects by members of the Parliament and the community.

I trust that the House and Government will recognise that the Committee has agreed on major and important recommendations which reflect the standards and values of Australian society. These recommendations reflect and uphold those standards, while urging sensible and appropriate measures to protect young people from the very real dangers posed by explicit, violent or pornographic material. This debate is not about censorship. It is about where we draw the censorship line.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I prefix my remarks today on the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by saying that since my entry into this Parliament in 1975 I have served on a number of committees. By virtue of my membership of this Committee I have never had a more difficult job than trying to come to some conclusion on what attitude we should take to the censorship of video material. The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) was quite right in his statements. It has been difficult. Those of us who signed the majority report have tried to provide a true reflection of the real feeling about what is happening in Australian society today. In that context I hope that the Government takes some notice of the majority report. Probably the real difficulty for the Government will be the fact that we are so divided. We should point out to the community that on most of the votes in this Committee there was a 6/5 split. It was as close as that. That will cause some difficulties when the Government finally comes down with its decision about what it is going to do regarding video censorship.

SPEECH.PARA: The report will not be a panacea, by any means. One of the things that concerned me from the start was that our terms of reference were confined primarily to video material. If people think the Government is going to act on our report and ban X-rated films, let them be under no misapprehension that plenty of pornographic material will still be available in our community because the report did not cover the print media. Many of the things people believed were concerned with the video inquiry and were contained in video tapes were not because they had already been banned, but they were freely available around Australia in the print media. I was also sorry that the terms of reference of our Committee did not extend to television, especially television violence. There is a very real concern in the community about violence in some television programs and about how the violence depicted in news services these days may affect our young folk.

As I have said, it has been a most difficult report. Before I go any further I would like to express my very sincere thanks to Jane Vincent, the Secretary of the Committee, and the members of her team for the help they gave to us under most difficult circumstances. Hers has been a most courageous effort. She deserves every congratulation for finally getting this very difficult report together.

When we talk about the censorship issue we tend to concentrate principally on X-rated material. The perception in the community was that X-rated material was what we were all about. In fact, our terms of reference were much broader. There is no doubt that there is massive concern in the community about the circulation of X-rated tapes. It is difficult to estimate how many pornographic video tapes might be in circulation in Australia. I point to the evidence that the X-rated pornographic video industry in Australia is worth between $20m and $25m per year. The Australian Capital Territory is a major employer. There are 200 to 300 people employed in the Australian Capital Territory in the manufacture and distribution of X-rated videos. So we are not talking about a small, underground operation. We are talking about a large industry with a number of players in it.

Estimates vary from 17 to 24 companies in the Australian Capital Territory distributing this material. In excess of 3,000 video tape titles carry illegal, X-rated classifications in Australia now and, if we can believe the evidence that came before our Committee, the number of these tapes sold ranges between 1,200 and 30,000. This gives us some idea of how much X-rated video material is available in Australia. Unlike my colleague the member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann), I express some concern that with the banning of the material we could well see a major underground operation. We have to be prepared for that, for the reasons the honourable member for Fairfax has given us today. If we think it is impossible to control, that is no reason for legalising it. We should put ourselves on notice, however, that should X-rated material be banned there will be great difficulties.

One of the things that surprised me about the evidence given to the Committee was that there was a preponderance of submissions concerning X-rated material only and that to a great extent the R-rated violent video material did not receive as much attention in the community as I, personally, thought it should. In many respects the dangers that are involved in some of the highly violent material could well outweigh the dangers of some X-rated material. I have expressed my concern within the Committee about some of the decisions that have been made in the past by previous members of the Film Censorship Board concerning some titles.

I am not sure whether honourable members are fully aware of just what is available in the so-called `slasher' films. I could cite some classic titles, such as The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and Blood Sucking Freaks, which to my mind do nothing but promote the concept of cannibalism. This sort of stuff has been floating around the community quite often, as in the case of Blood Sucking Freaks with an M-rating-until it was upgraded to an R classification-and the stuff is sick. Although originally I took the classic libertarian line that people should be able to see and read whatever they like in the privacy of their homes, only a small exposure to this material brought home to me the very real danger that is involved in the circulation of this kind of material for our young, impressionable people. It would seem from my personal investigations that the biggest consumers of violent R-rated material are aged between 15 and 24. In the report and the evidence we have been given it has been proven that this sort of violent material has a very real effect on young people. This has been found not only in Australia but in studies in the United States and elsewhere. I hope that there will be swift action from the Government to put limits on the R-rated material we have defined in the report.

The honourable member for Isaacs also mentioned our concern about the PG and M classifications. As a parent myself I am quite aware of the attraction of young people to this sort of material. I would think that until I become really deeply involved in this Committee I would go into a video shop and think nothing of a 10- or an 11-year-old taking out a PG film and in some circumstances even an M film. The fact that we have asked for the tightening up of those classifications I think is also significant.

There is no doubt that the film distributors are pitching for a higher classification by use of language, or indeed violence, be it discreet violence or whatever, to try to get that higher classification, because there is a very real appeal to young people of that higher classified material. I think we should make sure that we are perfectly clear within the Film Censorship Board that we have an obligation to ensure that the guidelines that are given are strictly adhered to so that young people are not exposed to some of that material.

As I said at the beginning of my comments today, this has been a very long and a very difficult job. Although there have been some tremendous rows within the Committee and some tremendous discussions, I think that probably one good thing that came out was a deal of respect for the views of the forces on opposite sides and a realisation that we are very much a pluralist society in Australia, with a great diversity of views. This report certainly reflects that diversity. I just hope that when we do give this very considered thought and when the Government finally does come in, there will be a full realisation within this House that we have a very real responsibility, especially to the young people of Australia. I look forward to the day when the Government will make that decision to ban the classification of X-rated material and does go on to tighten up very severely the limits on the available violence in video material in Australia today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time that is available to me I also would like to comment on this Joint Select Committee on Video Material report and to endorse the remarks made earlier in this debate by the Chairman, the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), while regretting that I cannot agree with most of the remarks made by the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) and some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles). Also, I am sorry that I cannot always agree with the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), with whom I have a lot in common.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a very long debate in the Committee. The saga of the report is very involved. The concepts which had to be grasped were complex and the readings voluminous. By far the most difficult aspect of the Committee's work, however, was attempting to assess objectively the relative merit, expertise and authenticity of the evidence presented against a backdrop of genuine community concern, various campaigns of misinformation, misunderstanding, moral indignation, commercial interest and occasional instances of blind prejudice.

Indeed, this chamber is not without its own examples of misunderstanding, misinformation and prejudice on this particular issue. Some honourable members will recall the private members' debate on this subject a few weeks ago in which a number of members referred to material which is unclassifiable as if it were freely available or unavailable under the X category. Those members simply illustrate the difficulty of dealing with a subject upon which everyone wishes to express an opinion without the proper information base.

There is quite a lot of hypocrisy around on this question also. As with many other discussions of morality, double standards are rife. But to acknowledge that is not to deny the genuine concern of many witnesses and members of the community and their belief that such material has contributed in some way to the moral decline of our society. Neither is it to diminish in any way the contribution of other Committee members to the report and to the deliberations of the Committee.

The Committee's task would have been easier had the terminology of the debate not been so loaded and subjective. Particularly on this subject, different words mean different things to different people. As a consequence, much of our time was spent endeavouring to get witnesses to explain what they meant by the terms they were using. For instance, some witnesses used the word `pornography' in the context of bestiality and sado-masochistic material which is not classifiable under Australian law anyway and is already illegal. Others used the same word to describe material which might be better understood as `erotica' in the general community-that which does not contain violent or enforced sexual acts, but which is fairly explicit in its depiction.

Because the Committee itself is made up of people from a broad spectrum of our society, we had some of the same problems of definition, understanding and interpretation within our own ranks, and that is obvious from the debate today. This goes some way to explaining the variety of views on the Committee on the merit of certain evidence as well as on more basic philosophical questions, such as the need for censorship versus the rights of people to view material of their choice, and by `people' I mean adults. The difficulty of interpretation in this area has been raised by other similar committees in other countries as a substantive problem in their deliberations. For instance, the United States Commission on Obscenity and Pornography refused to use the word `pornography' because of the interpretive problem it posed.

In July 1986 the United States Meese Commission, which was commissioned by the Attorney-General, also indicated that the questions of terminology and definition were recurring problems in its hearings and deliberations. The definition of the word `pornography' warranted a special mention in the Commission's report:

The range of materials to which people are likely to affix the designation `pornographic' is so broad that it is tempting to note that `pornography' seems to mean in practice any discussion or depiction of sex to which the person using the word objects.
In 1985 the Canadian Fraser Committee, the special committee on pornography and prostitution, found it necessary to ask the question: `What is pornography?'. It said in its report:

Although the term (pornography) is widely used in popular and academic literature, it does not appear in Canadian criminal law, nor is this term used in other Federal legislation dealing with the control of offensive material.

The same is true of Australia. The terms `pornography' and `pornographic' do not appear in the legislation which was under review by our Joint Select Committee. Furthermore the Committee's terms of reference refer to `violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material' as if the three terms were interchangeable. In reality, all are extremely subjective, descriptive terms which are not interchangeable and which require personal interpretation. Cross-party alliances were formed on the Committee on various recommendations contained in the report, and despite holding strong, disparate and contrary opinions, the members of the Committee have almost invariably, except for latter days, conducted their deliberations in a friendly and cooperative manner. I reject the claim of the honourable member for Isaacs that violence was almost perpetrated on the Committee. I do not think it got that far.

Claims were made that a causal effect had been established between violent material and the incidence of crime in our society. However, such claims totally ignore social pressures such as poverty and oppression, which are arguably much more powerful influences than visual depictions on film. Nevertheless, the Committee was unanimous in its view that violence on video, television and cinema should be reduced, and recommended that the Film Censorship Board and the Films Board of Review should adopt a tighter interpretation of the guidelines in order to achieve a reduction in the level of violence in all relevant categories.

I would particularly like to mention, as did other members of the Committee, the contribution of the Secretary, Jane Vincent, and her staff, who worked extremely hard under difficult conditions to help the Committee produce this report. Her competence and calm in the face of adversity were commendable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order of Australia!

—What a great idea. Fluctuations in majority opinion on the Committee made Jane's job even harder, and I think the comments of the honourable member for Fadden and the Chairman on the closeness of the vote on many of the recommendations actually underline that point. Also, Jane's job was made harder by the change in the composition of the Committee after the last election, at a time when the first draft of the Chairman's report was almost complete.

SPEECH.PARA: I am proud to have been a member of this Committee. It was the first Committee that I went on when I became a member of parliament. It was rather a shock to the system. I congratulate all members of the Committee for the way they conducted themselves during our deliberations, and hope that the community understands the difficulties which we had in discussing this whole issue and trying to come to conclusions that would at least assist the Government in terms of its actions on this very important social issue.

That the House take note of the report.
