DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Prosser.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the quiet achievers of Australian primary industry, I am pleased to present this Bill to amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act of 1935 to exempt professional fishermen from sales tax on four-wheel drive vehicles and some motorcycles used in their industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I would describe it as a commonsense Bill, designed to remove an anomaly from the legislation as it now stands. This amendment will take away a financial impediment on the industry, providing incentive for fishermen to continue to pursue the task of reducing Australia's reliance on imported fish and the development of export markets.

Over recent years, major changes have evolved in the method of harvesting Australia's valuable fish resource. Like other primary producers, fishermen have striven to do the job better and more efficiently in response to market needs and a growing consumer demand for fresh fish. These new fishing techniques have also forced fishermen to update equipment. Four-wheel-drive vehicles and some motorcyles are now an important part of the fishermen's stock in trade, significantly reducing the time in getting the catch from boat to market. But it seems change has overtaken the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act because, unlike other primary producers, professional fishermen do not receive tax relief for this expensive equipment.

Basically, licensed professional fishermen are excluded from the benefits of sales tax exemption by the wording of the legislation, which allows exemptions to people engaged in the agricultural industry rather than to primary producers. It is interesting to note that, for the purposes of income tax, fishermen are classified as primary producers. This Bill would have an insignificant effect on Government revenue, estimates ranging from just over $1m to less than $3m a year. Yet, the benefits for the fishing industry would be great. Salt corrosion significantly reduces the life of four-wheel-drive vehicles in the industry. The changeover on average is between four and six years, and the value of the vehicles is obviously greatly reduced.

Clearly, this anomaly should not remain in the legislation. The need to amend the Act was acknowledged in the Parliament as far back as 1982. In its final report, the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce recommended:

Where a commercial fisherman can demonstrate that the use of a vehicle is essential to his fishing operations, he be entitled to exemption from sales tax on a vehicle to be used in earning income, and the relevant sales tax legislation be amended to provide for such exemption.

Part time fishermen would be excluded from exemptions under division 4 of the Sales Tax Act, which requires that each vehicle must be used primarily or principally for work purposes. As Australia's fifth largest primary industry exporter, fishing has a major role in helping reduce our current account deficit. In 1986-87 the value of fish exports was some $621m, mainly to Japan and the United States. However, in the current economic climate the industry recognises it must become more competitive to maintain existing markets and to expand into other areas.

It is now 10 years since the Australian fisheries jurisdiction was extended to the 200-mile limit. The industry must be encouraged to utilise this valuable resource for the benefit of Australia and with regard to proper management of the resource. Investment in equipment is vital if the industry is to meet these challenges. I urge honourable members on both sides of the House to assist the industry by supporting this Bill.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 104a, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) recognises the important role that the Government must play in natural disaster relief arrangements; and
(2) calls on all States to participate actively in the arrangements.

Various States in Australia are suffering the effects of natural disaster at present. Life for men and women on the land is difficult at times. A crop can be planted, carefully cultivated and then nature provides insufficient rain or rain comes at the wrong time leaving a crop to rot in the ground or be totally washed away. The vagaries of our climate mean that the lifestyle of many farmers is seldom predictable. Drought, flood, bushfire or cyclone may ruin the lifestyle of primary producers in any year. That is undeniable. Relief measures are required and it is the role of all governments, Federal and State, to care for the welfare of people in times of personal, emotional and financial crisis. I do not believe that we can ever overestimate the contributions that men and women on the land make to this nation and, indeed, to the pioneering of our great nation and the lifestyle we enjoy today.

The Federal Government recognises its responsibilities to these people who are in difficulty, and I believe that the natural disaster relief arrangements provide a safety net for families in rural areas when they are experiencing difficulty. This year central Queensland suffered Cyclone Charlie. There were floods in the south-eastern corner of the State, particularly in the Lockyer Valley, and in my electorate there has been drought for the past five years. It is ironical that we are suffering both flood and drought at the same time in central Queensland. That is one of the ironies of our climate. In other States there are droughts in the Wimmera district of Victoria, Eyre Peninsula in South Australia, northern Tasmania, south-western Western Australia and, for the past eight years, the Cooma area in south-eastern New South Wales. Indeed, this is a very harsh land.

A Natural Disaster Relief Consultative Committee was established to deal with the problems of primary producers who are suffering the ill-effects of a natural disaster. As I have said, my own electorate has been the victim of drought, which has affected some areas of the Burnett and Isis districts for about five years. The agreed measures in place were developed by the National Drought Consultative Committee, on which the States and farmer organisations are represented. Assistance is provided by way of subsidised loans for such purposes as stock, water and fodder, transport and the purchase of agistment, feed and water. The Federal Government funds the bulk of expenditure in the years of heavy demand under the natural disaster relief arrangements whether for drought, flood, fire or cyclone. Again, I would like to emphasise the unpredictability and the cyclonic influences that particularly affect north Queensland.

In Queensland the Federal Government pays $3 for every $1 of the State beyond the trigger point of $24.5m. This point has already passed, given the number of disasters in Queensland this financial year. The scheme is administered at the State level by the various State bodies. The Queensland Industry Development Department currently provides 4 per cent loans for both drought and flood damage and three-quarters of the extra money comes from the Federal Government. The 4 per cent that is paid by the farmers goes to the Queensland Government to cover its administrative costs. However, the Federal Government makes the money available to Queensland at no extra cost.

Given this Federal involvement, I was disappointed to read about a meeting at Eidsvold called by the National Party of Australia where the speakers alleged that the Federal Government was doing nothing to assist farmers who are hurt by the drought. The meeting was addressed by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) who criticised the natural disaster relief arrangements. Nowhere was it reported, however, that the Leader of the National Party outlined his alternatives to the current arrangements that he has found so inadequate. He told the farmers what they wanted to hear and went away and did nothing about it. The meeting at Eidsvold was also addressed by the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries (Mr Harper). Mr Harper helped make the issue political and, in doing so, overlooked the fact that the area that has suffered drought for the past five years was in his own State electorate. The State Government has deemed the drought to be so serious that it declared the area drought affected only in March of this year. The National Party had left the farmers without any aid for five years, while it called a political meeting to take the heat off itself.

We are seeing a similar story with the farmers in the Lockyer Valley who are experiencing the trauma which comes with flood. The natural disaster relief arrangements are administered by the State Government. There is mounting evidence that the Federal Government money used in the natural disaster relief arrangements is being misspent by the Queensland Government. The issue became public in Queensland in what became known as the `lousy loans affair'. The then State Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Turner, admitted he had directed a $145,000 loan be granted to a National Party officer against expert financial advice.

The Agricultural Bank and the Rural Reconstruction Board had decided that the National Party northern director and former Senate candidate, Mr Behan, should not receive the loan because he faced debts of $700,000 and $100,000 a year in repayments. After Mr Turner intervened, apparently with the approval of the then Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, Mr Behan received a loan, including $85,000 from disaster relief funds at 4 per cent.

Honourable members may be aware that the original decision of the Bank was vindicated and Mr Behan was forced to sell his family property. The significant fact for present day natural disaster victims is that this was not the first time Mr Turner had intervened and overturned recommendations to the responsible administrative bodies. He was quoted in the Townsville Daily Bulletin of 17 September 1986 as saying that he overturned them `whenever I thought it was necessary'. The number of times decisions were overturned by Turner is revealed in a radio transcript of an interview between the National Party member for Mulgrave, Mr Menzel, and the journalist Greg Turnbull on AM on 18 September 1986. Mr Menzel said he had approached Mr Turner hundreds of times on behalf of farmers whose applications had been rejected.

After Cyclone Winifred officials from the Department of Finance were asked to investigate claims of irregularities in national disaster relief arrangement approvals. A report in the Sunday Mail of 21 September 1986 said that there would be an investigation into allegations that one family was reported to have bought five new cars and another family took an overseas holiday after receiving disaster relief loans. Another case was of a farmer whose wife had real estate assets and who bought a business, putting his bank account into the red so he could get drought relief. A further case was of a farmer who used his loan funds to buy a second farm to expand his existing small holding, where he was struggling to make a living.

Because the State Government administers the scheme, the cooperation of the State Government was needed before the Federal authorities could investigate. In the Telegraph of 24 September 1986, the former Premier of Queensland was quoted as saying that Senator Walsh had no justification for shoving his nose into Queensland affairs. `Why should we cooperate?', he said. `I know what he's after. There is nothing to cooperate on.' The unwillingness of the Bjelke-Petersen Government to cooperate has cost the taxpayers of this nation dearly.

The State Primary Industries Minister, Mr Harper, last week in the Bundaberg News Mail announced that Queensland had up to $25m in bad debts and therefore could not afford to lower the interest rates for producers in his and my electorates to further assist farmers with drought relief measures-farmers that need help right now. The Queensland Auditor-General should launch an immediate investigation into the natural disaster relief debts in Queensland. The Premier, Mr Ahern, owes a duty to the farmers in Queensland to ensure that a full investigation is carried out so that there is full confidence in the administration of the scheme.

A public accounts committee promised by the Ahern Government should be set up so that the Parliament can judge whether the Queensland government has exercised due care and attention with taxpayers' money. The committee needs to examine the circumstances in which the National Party member for Mulgrave had hundreds of decisions overturned.

Let us look at the provisions within the natural disaster relief arrangements. They state that assistance is available by `a concessional interest loan by a State to a farmer . . . whose assets have been significantly damaged by an eligible disaster and who has no reasonable access to commercial finance but who has a reasonable prospect of long-term viability'. The case of Mr Behan shows that this important clause was ignored by the State Government. It appears that the Behan case and others like it have allowed a $25m debt situation to be accrued by the State Government.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have deliberately focused my remarks on Queensland because the overwhelming majority of the natural disaster relief money is spent in that State. In 1983-84, $80.6m out of a total of $138.799m was spent in Queensland; in 1984-85, $11.116m out of $11.281m went to Queensland; in 1985-86, $24.937m out of $26.197m went to Queensland; and in 1986-87, $33.422m out of $36.331m went to Queensland. From financial year 1983-84 to financial year 1986-87, over $150m has been allocated to Queensland from natural disaster funds. Slightly over half the money has been allocated for droughts and the rest has been allocated for floods, storms and cyclones. Some 70.59 per cent of all Federal outlays on natural disaster relief have gone to my home State of Queensland. It is vital that these funds be appropriated and spent in an effective way.

Those farmers currently applying for assistance should apply in the knowledge that they are all on an equal footing when seeking a loan. It should not be a mad scramble to ring the local National Party member whenever there is a knockback in the knowledge that the Minister will overturn it. Farmers must feel crestfallen when they hear from Mr Harper that the Queensland Government has run up a $25m debt in administering the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I ask the honourable member for Hinkler to withdraw his reference to local National Party members and the inference he made.
—The honourable member for Hinkler has not mentioned any members of this House by name. There is no point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member continues to mention persons by name, people who have personal loans. I ask you to listen carefully to what he is saying and to the argument he is putting forward. I believe that what he is saying is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.

—I have been listening to what the honourable member for Hinkler has been saying. I ask him, in the spirit of Thursday morning private members' debates, to try to stick more to the motion he has moved, rather than bringing up personal matters.

—I was certainly not making any inference in relation to the honourable member for Maranoa. I am sure he has never tried and never would try to overturn any natural disaster arrangements. It is just sad that it is on record that the members I have mentioned did publicly say that they got involved and did what I have said.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal assistance aims to help the States meet the unexpected costs of assisting. The arrangements recognise the States' primary responsibility under the Constitution for the administration, provision and financing of relief schemes. An amount of $25m has been provided for Federal assistance towards disaster relief in 1987-88. However, actual assistance will depend on the level of ongoing State expenditure in respect of past disasters and on the incidence and severity of any disasters.

The Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has played an important role in developing a national drought policy. He sought the formation of an expert group of State and Federal officers and rural producer organisations. With the agreement of the Australian Agricultural Council, the National Drought Consultative Committee was formed in 1984. The Committee expressed agreement on the desirability for greater uniformity between the States in the administration of drought loans, including coverage, eligibility, purpose and terms and conditions.

The general view expressed by the Committee was that individual loan levels should not be limited except to the extent of having a State average limit. New South Wales and Queensland considered a maximum limit should be established. In addition, the Committee decided that a reference should be made to the Industries Assistance Commission on crop and rainfall insurance, and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has initiated this. The procedures to assist drought stricken primary producers throughout Australia are in place and are working to assist farmers in difficult circumstances.

The track record of the Queensland Government in administering natural disaster relief arrangements does not give farmers any great hope that they will all start equal when applying for disaster relief. The lousy loans affair involving $145,000 appears from Mr Harper's own admission to have ballooned into $25m worth of lousy loans.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I would call your attention to the continued reference to a private loan given to a private individual in Queensland. His name is continually being referred to. The loan has been referred to again as a lousy plan. It so happens that it was a private loan; it was a private undertaking. This gentleman is paying back the loan in the same way as any other Queenslander. I would like you to call the honourable member for Hinkler to order.
—I ask the honourable member again to adhere to the request from the Chair and try to avoid personalities in this debate.

—I do not think that any amount of money represents a lousy loan to farmers in need. The words I referred to are not mine; they are those of the Queensland National Party that were reported in the paper. Those moneys allocated by the Federal and State governments should be directed to those farmers who are most in need. We need better accounting procedures. The State Minister for Primary Industries in Queensland has admitted that $25m has been lost. There should be more accountability. Contrary to statements made in Queensland recently, the natural disaster policy is in place. I cannot overemphasise, as I said at the beginning of my remarks, the important contribution that farmers have made to this nation. It is important to make sure that those genuine farmers who are most in need have a safety net. There is a difference between that and unaccountability.
—Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to several of the remarks made by the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) before I proceed to develop a case for what I believe is absolutely necessary in this country-that is, a major strategy to cope with bushfires, droughts and floods. The honourable member for Hinkler made a political response to the serious problems confronting those in the flood and drought areas in Queensland. It is unfortunate that he did so; but, he having done so, I now want to put the record straight.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1982, at the time of the Fraser Government, disaster relief was paid by the Federal Government at the rate of $3 for every $1 provided by the State above a threshold set at a fixed percentage of the annual State Budget sector revenue. Now the Commonwealth will pay only $1 for every $1 provided by the State above the threshold, up to a figure of 75 per cent above that threshold. Only after that higher level is reached does the Commonwealth return to its $3 for $1 commitment. In 1982 the threshold in Queensland was $3m; today it is $14m. That means that the State Government now has to expend $14m before the trigger mechanism commences to work. This is making it almost impossible for the States, which are bearing the brunt of the Commonwealth Budget difficulties, to provide that sort of cash at a time of crisis within their own State boundaries.

I am very concerned that in the forthcoming May mini-Budget-we are told that the States will once again take an enormous slash in resources available through loan programs and States grants-the States will be put in an even worse situation to meet the crises of drought, flood or fire within their State boundaries. That being so, I believe that the Commonwealth Government will have a very serious responsibility to review the formula that is presently being used. If the States are denied their share of income tax revenue collected, undoubtedly, in times of cyclonic difficulties and floods, such as we have had in the Lockyer Valley and elsewhere, they will be virtually unable to meet the expenditure levels to which they are committed before the Commonwealth comes in to assist in rehabilitating people who have been hurt as a result of floods, cyclones or droughts.

When the Fraser Government was in office the Queensland Government was probably more generous and forthcoming during the 1981-82 droughts than any other State government. It was far more flexible with the arrangements that it put in place, with the approval of the Commonwealth, concerning drought assistance and so on. I believe that the Queensland Government generally has been very mindful of the fact that that State is subjected to cyclonic disturbance and all sorts of seasonal problems and has endeavoured to meet the need from resources. It could meet it when the threshold was at $3m. Now that it is at $14m, it is very difficult for that State to make the sort of contribution that one would expect to be made in accordance with past practice.

There is no doubt that recent sudden changes to weather patterns right across the continent have added a sense of urgency to the motion moved by the honourable member for Hinkler. In my electorate of Gwydir near drought conditions before Easter gave way to rainfall which in some cases exceeded 250 millimetres, or 10 inches, in a matter of a few days. The townships of Mungindi, Collarenebri and, more recently, Walgett are facing total isolation. The river is 14 miles wide. This has caused enormous problems not only for livestock-many of which have drowned, others have been taken to high knobs of ground-but also for people including pregnant women and sick people, who have had to be evacuated.

I want to compliment the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who responded to a request that I made when it was understood that Royal Australian Air Force aircraft and other facilities were to be moved from Goondiwindi when the water had passed its peak there. I contacted his office and his Senior Private Secretary was very cooperative. The Minister was at Butterworth at the time; so he checked with the Civil Defence Organisation in Canberra and put pressure on it. It was decided to leave the aircraft and facilities there until the emergency had been overcome. On behalf of the people of Mungindi, Collarenebri and elsewhere, I thank the Minister, his Department and his office for the way in which he responded to their problem.

Australia is undoubtedly one of the most difficult countries in which to live. We have such extraordinary extremes. We have drought conditions which are part of the scene in this arid land. This is the most arid continent in the world. At times we are beset with enormous cyclonic disturbances, heavy rain-which is certainly not the norm-and the consequences that flow from it. This means that the Government needs to develop a strategy which is far more comprehensive than the one that is presently in existence. I mentioned the 1982-83 drought a moment ago. Memories of that drought are still fresh enough to be a warning that natural disasters can severely harm the economy and eat into living standards. Unlike fire, flood or cyclone, drought is more persistent and can extend for several years.

Even though the 1978-1983 drought did not produce trade deficits within cooee of the $12 billion to $15 billion deficits of the last three years, it was still savage enough to drive home the point that we must have comprehensive drought relief programs ready at all times. Today we have no such program in place. Only the widespread heavy Easter rainfalls have saved a significant portion of this continent from plunging into a 1982-83-type drought. Had those falls of rain not come, we need to ask, what would this Government have done to help establish a floor to the rural economy, save breeding stock or assist viable but debt-ridden farmers to stay in business and keep the farm economy ticking over? We would have been lectured about Budget restraints and about the States doing more. The comprehensive drought relief package of 1982-83, introduced by the Fraser Government, was designed to save essential breeding stock and to rebuild herds once the drought had broken. The Fraser Government can take great credit, as can the Prime Minister of the day, for the action that was taken and that he supervised, which was a wise public investment.

When the drought broke in 1983 our breeding herds and flocks were virtually intact. It was the first time in the history of droughts in this country that that was the case. At that time drought relief was paid by the Federal Government at a rate of $3 for every $1 spent by the State beyond a threshold fixed at a reasonable percentage of the annual State Budget revenue. Since the Hawke Government came into power total drought outlays have been scaled down as a result of the new formula. For instance, the total relief outlays in 1980-81 came to $80m; in 1983-84, $138m; in 1985-86, $26m; and in 1986-87, $36m. This year $25m has been set aside. Even so, this year the repayments from earlier loans will exceed the budgeted figure of $25m, if that is reached. Net relief outlays are likely to be nil.

I call upon the Government to take a very good look at where policy should be directed to meet the contingencies of drought which are a feature of this country. There remains a need for a thorough overhaul of Federal-State financial arrangements, particularly in view of the fact that the States are likely to have enormous grants cuts in the forthcoming May Budget. There need to be new Federal-State financial arrangements for natural disaster relief and the development of a long term drought management strategy. I do not think that enough thought has been give to the sorts of incentives that need to be applied through the tax system to encourage stock owners and others to make provision for drought on the farm in the form of fodder and water. A lot of these drought assistance measures in times of emergency would not be needed if proper incentives were given to farmers to look after themselves. If proper measures are in place, the farmers and graziers ought to be told, `we have given you an incentive. If you don't take advantage of that incentive I am afraid we will not come to your aid in time of drought'. In my view that is the way the policy should be directed, but whilever we do not have that sort of system there is a need for a Federal government initiated program. I prefer the former.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the early hours of the morning of Friday, 12 February 1988, flooding occurred in the small Darling Downs township of Cooyar, which is in the south-western corner of my electorate. The flood lasted for approximately 10 minutes, yet the force of the water which flowed through the town in those 10 minutes was so powerful that three houses were destroyed; a further three houses and a general store were either moved off their foundations or severely damaged; a local hotel and a further seven houses suffered damage through water penetration and the impact of flood debris; the very large community hall of the town, the focal point of the whole district, was completely destroyed, the only remains being the stumps in the ground; and there was extensive damage to surrounding farm land-the loss of fences and, probably even more tragically in the long term, a great loss of topsoil, which cannot be replaced as easily as fences can.

SPEECH.PARA: Several months earlier I had been to the township to attend a function. I was newly elected last July. I would be less than honest to say that the people in Cooyar and in the surrounding areas are great supporters of the Australian Labor Party; they are certainly not. The people however were polite and greeted me warmly as their new member. I went back there a few months later, the day after the flood went through. I saw the damage that had occurred, but I also noticed the determination of the people. The stories of the townsfolk of how they survived that disaster made me proud that those people were in my electorate and I had the honour of representing them. The Premier of Queensland also attended the scene. He was also obviously touched by the disaster. Both he and I made commitments for our respective governments that any action that the governments could take to help rebuild the town would be taken. From that point I began taking a very active interest in the disaster arrangements which operate between this Parliament and the various State governments.

As the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) quite correctly pointed out, Australia is a country of great extremes. It is prone to drought and to flood. It is absolutely essential that we have in place the sorts of arrangements which recognise those factors so that when natural disasters do occur a mechanism will very quickly come into place to provide immediate relief by way of emergency assistance and longer term relief in terms of rebuilding farms, homes and businesses.

Several weeks after the disaster I went back to the town to speak to the local people to see how things were going and how the disaster relief arrangements were actually working. It was a very interesting exercise. My impression from that meeting with the people was that the initial arrangements in providing cash for such things as food and clothing-people lost everything; their entire personal effects-worked quite well. After that difficulties began to arise in the assessment of the damage and how the assistance would be provided.

As honourable members will be aware, the arrangements are jointly funded by the State and Federal governments over a threshold where the States have the initial constitutional responsibility for natural disasters. In the State of Queensland there is a threshold of some $14m for which the State Government is responsible over a financial year. From that point up to $24m it is a dollar for dollar arrangement between the Federal Government and the State Government. After $24m it is a three to one arrangement whereby every dollar expended by the State in relief measures is matched by $3 from this Government. By the time the Cooyar flood occurred, dollar for dollar arrangements were in place. Despite the fact that two governments are involved, it makes obvious sense that the arrangements should be administered by only one set of public servants, if you like. The agreement is that the State governments will administer the funds and make the decision as to which residences and businesses are entitled to loans. A report is made twice yearly to the Federal Government as to what money has been expended.

In theory I think the idea is fine and that there should be only one set of public servants assessing these sorts of things. It is ludicrous for people to be looking over each other's shoulders and getting bound up in red tape. But unfortunately there does seem to be some problem with the accounting principles. After a couple of weeks, when I went back to see how things were going, I was struck by the fact that people were worried that some of the money would go into repairing roads that were not damaged in this disaster; that the local council, rather enterprisingly in some sense, considered it to be a bonanza and was going to use it to start fixing up the roads. I will not get into a great debate about road funding, but the point is that the money has to go to the people who are in need and who were affected by the disaster.

When people in the local area start to talk about concerns like that it rings alarm bells for me. I will not repeat what the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) said, but in Queensland there has been an unfortunate history of money paid under these arrangements not necessarily going where it should. That is a terrible situation. We are talking about people's lives. Two people were killed in Cooyar. Families have lost their loved ones and their homes. It is just not acceptable for any government, regardless of its politics, not to direct this money to the people in need. There needs to be a straightening out of the accounting procedures to ensure that the money we provide goes to people in genuine need and is not syphoned off into other areas, which would be a real travesty of justice.

Another point that the local townsfolk of Cooyar raised with me related to how it was decided which residents and, in particular, which businesses were to be provided with the funds. For example, the State Government, somewhat unfortunately, viewed the local post office agency, which is run by a husband and wife-and this in common in small country towns-as purely a business and not a home, yet the home was attached to the business. It was one and the same unit. These sorts of circumstances need to be looked at so that technical interpretations are not applied.

I was delighted to hear the remarks of the honourable member for Gwydir about developing a long term strategy to overcome these problems. That is the way we have to go. Obviously, the natural disaster relief schemes are not designed to be an alternative to insurance. People still have to take responsibility of themselves. One could ask oneself: What is the difference between someone losing his home, say, in a flood and someone who lives by a major road losing his home because a lorry runs off the road and crashes into the house? Both persons have lost their home but only one is entitled to assistance under the scheme. We have to ensure that we do not set up a system which takes away the responsibility of people to take out reasonable insurance.

In some cases people cannot foresee what will happen. That happened to the people of Cooyar. Cooyar is a small town built between two creeks. There had been no evidence of flooding of that magnitude in the area in living memory. Obviously from time to time the town experienced flooding but nothing like the magnitude of that flood which went through and, in 10 minutes, wiped out the town. The people there were insured under normal household insurance to cover fire and storm damage but they did not have insurance to cover flood damage. The families and their forebears had never experienced such a flood. It is not unreasonable in those circumstances to think that they would not have insurance. When the scheme is administered the State officials should keep that situation in mind and should not make arbitrary decisions saying, `You should have had flood insurance. Too bad, you are not entitled to anything'. That is a very poor situation.

On the whole the disaster relief arrangements that are in place are basically correct. They are being reviewed at the moment and letters have gone out to various States. I hope that is a helpful review. I support the thrust of the motion moved by the honourable member for Hinkler. It is very helpful that the House is now discussing these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting this motion I remind the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) that while we believe there is an important role for government-both at State and Federal level-in natural disaster assistance we should not overlook the enormous contribution that is made by voluntary help. In so many cases it is unsung. It is not given much public recognition but, nonetheless, in many cases it is far more important than the assistance given by government. As the honourable member for Fisher alluded to in his remarks, there also should be some special recognition of the importance of and the need for self-help. As the honourable member noted it is a fairly complex area. I suggest that when he begins to look at this issue he will find all sorts of anomalies which make it very difficult in administering government assistance to distinguish between those people who have done something to help themselves and those who have not and to maintain some sort of fairness.

SPEECH.PARA: In the brief time available to me I suggest to the honourable member for Hinkler that his suggestions as to how the so-called $25m of indebtedness of the Queensland Government occurred sound to me to be extraordinarily far-fetched. Maybe that discussion is for another time.

As would be expected, there is broad bipartisan support for the thrust of this motion. It is a very complex area. There will continue to be a role for the Federal and State governments to play. It is mainly the States which administer the assistance; the Federal Government merely supplies funds. When the natural disaster reaches such proportions that the State feels it can no longer fund the support, the Federal Government becomes involved. We should not overlook the fact, when we talk about natural disasters, that it is individuals who get hurt. In many cases it is devastating, whether it be from a flood, fire, a cyclone, or even from a drought as the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) touched on at some length. There is an interesting statistic in the case of fires-it probably applies in similar proportions to other natural disasters-and that is that one in three of those who have been burnt out, or devastated in other ways, never recover financially. It is a devastating statistic. It is one that is often not quoted because it does not normally occur until long after the disaster has been and gone and people have forgotten about it and something else has come along. Nonetheless, it is a figure that should be highlighted more often and it should be the one that is put in front of people when the question of insurance is mentioned. Despite the assistance of the Government, despite the assistance of voluntary helpers, it is still a fact that those who cannot make proper provision for such disasters are likely to find it extremely hard to survive financially.

There is another problem-this has already been alluded to-and that is: how do we give out government assistance in a fair manner? How do we say to the person who has made reasonable provision, who has put something aside every year-whether it be fodder for a drought, whether it be insurance or whether it be other forms of financial reserves, `You have gone without for all those years and we have only a limited amount of money for assistance so you will miss out'? It is a complex area and it has to be looked at.

The other point I would like to talk about very briefly is that we see much television coverage of natural disasters such as a major bush fire, a major flood, or major cyclone damage and if a drought runs for long enough we see the devastation that that causes. But often individuals may have their whole property burnt out or they may, in one small concentrated area, be hit by a flash flood and in many cases they are completely overlooked because it has not attracted the media attention and therefore the support from the community that would be forthcoming to those who are affected by major catastrophes.

The Industries Assistance Commission in its 1986 report titled Crop and Rainfall Insurance alluded to some of the deficiencies of the present disaster relief arrangements. As my time is limited I will not go into the details of it now, but it is a complex area and I urge all members of this chamber to take a little more time to study it because Australia will continue to be faced with natural disasters. They will continue to be unpredictable and often they will be totally devastating for those affected. Whether it be a flood, a bushfire, a cyclone or a drought, the effect on individuals can, in many cases, be equally devastating. While the support of voluntary help is always of great assistance, the role of government will continue to be very important.

As the honourable member for Gwydir mentioned, we should also be looking at other forms of allowing people to help themselves. The income equalisation deposit scheme is one example of where the Government ought to have another look at the whole issue. While the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) may talk about tax averaging being more important than income equalisation deposits, he completely overlooks the role that putting savings aside through this method can have in alleviating the devastation of a natural disaster.

This is such an important and complex issue when we look at the role of governments, both State and Federal, when we look at the role of voluntary help and at the role of self-help, those who prepare themselves so that they are better protected, that we find that it is very difficult to administer assistance, and not just for the reasons mentioned by the honourable member for Fisher. I think it is of such national importance that the Government ought to have a major inquiry to see how proper government assistance can be fairly administered. When I talk about government assistance, I include things such as allowing people to prepare for a situation by instituting self-help measures and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs for the lack of funding and the new arrangements for the distribution of funds for the 800 local government councils in Australia.

I believe it is very important today to bring this subject to the notice of the House. Local authorities throughout Australia have been very active of late in telling the Government just how badly they have done in the funding arrangements in the last two or three years. There has been a total rearrangement of the general purpose grants and a considerable reduction in road funding. Many Australian motorists are very irate that under this Australian Labor Party Government every six months taxes go up because of the indexation of fuel excise. They are continuing to pay more and more taxes not only through road taxes but through all sorts of taxes. The total tax take by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) continues to increase rapidly, yet as motorists drive around this great nation the roads are crumbling underneath them. When the Opposition is elected to government at the next election councils will get more funding for the road system. There is no point in our screaming about our balance of payments and the economy being in a mess if we are not prepared to maintain the routes that have to service the great industries of this country such as wool, wheat and beef which are helping to get this country out of the desperate state into which it has plunged since Labor came to office.

The Federal Government has become more and more important in local government funding, providing practically 20 per cent of overall collections. Local government collects 70 to 74 per cent through rates and other charges-it varies in each State-and the States contribute about 6 per cent of local government funding. So the Commonwealth has become quite important to councils and that is why this matter has been raised today. Under general purpose assistance, many councils have been disadvantaged in real terms by inflation because of the new arrangements which each State had to agree to with the Labor Minister. Some councils have been disadvantaged in dollar terms: the amounts are actually below the previous year's level. Hundreds and hundreds of councils have been disadvantaged in real terms because the Government has not kept funding up to keep pace with inflation. It is no wonder that some States are in desperate straits trying to keep their councils operating.

Unfortunately, the new funding principles seem to have disregarded isolation and based the criteria more and more on population. Remote shires have disadvantages in trying to raise more taxes through rates on rural properties because of the capital value of the land in the last few years falling due to drought and poor international commodity prices. Land sales have been down and these factors have reduced the rating base for councils. Councils have had to reduce rates because ratepayers have not been able to meet the cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a capital tax, too.

—Yes. A number of councils have been disadvantaged across Australia. In Victoria, funding for the Kowree Shire Council is down 11.6 per cent. In New South Wales, the Burwood City Council is down 4.3 per cent. In Queensland, the Wambo Shire Council-where my electorate office is situated in Dalby-is down 1.4 per cent. In Tasmania, Hobart City Council is down 6.9 per cent. In South Australia, the Georgetown Council is down 6.5 per cent. In Western Australia, the Kent Council is down 4.6 per cent and, in the Northern Territory, Jabiru Council is down 29.5 per cent. I do not know why its funding has fallen so disastrously. There must be some reason for the almost 30 per cent drop.

SPEECH.PARA: Councils are also disadvantaged because this Labor Government has introduced quarterly grants payments to councils whereas previously they were paid annually and were able to invest the money and use it as they wished through the 12 months so that they earnt a little extra.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a thimble and pea trick.

—Yes. Now the scrooge Treasurer is keeping the funds wrapped up in Treasury here and only dribbling them to local authorities every quarter. We think that is a disgrace and we will abolish that when we come to government at the next election. Surely the councils in this nation ought to know what grant they are going to get and we ought to be able to give them their full grant when it is due without dribbling it out like some measly shopkeeper as the Treasurer is. We believe in helping shire councils; the Labor Government believes in disadvantaging shire councils.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout Australia 98 councils have lost funding in dollar terms over the previous year's funding allocations and 430 councils have received a funding increase in dollar terms which was a loss in real terms. In other words, the payments have not kept up with inflation. Of the almost 900 councils, 369 received a funding increase in real terms. Therefore, 60 per cent of the 897 councils have lost funding in real terms. I will be very interested to hear an argument from the Government side in this debate as to how that is helping shire councils throughout Australia.

Tasmania has suffered the worst, as usual. Poor Tasmania really gets a clouting from this Government: if it is not knocking off its parks, interfering and flying low level bombing raids across the island it is reducing funding. Ninety-three per cent of Tasmania's councils have suffered cuts in funding in real terms. That is a disgrace. Twenty-nine per cent of Northern Territory councils suffered real cuts. Other States have also suffered, as I have pointed out.

While local government has suffered under the general purpose grants arrangements, the Government's road funding program is a disgrace. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table, has had to offer extra money to keep her pilots in the air and I can assure the Government that it will have to offer bonuses to keep councils throughout this country operating because under the Government's funding arrangements half of the councils are going bankrupt. They are not getting enough money from the Federal Government to maintain the road system let alone consider building new roads. Road funding has dropped to 1982-83 levels. It is a disgrace that after the five years this Government has been in office it has reduced funding for roads to the 1982 level. Yet the Treasurer will get up in this House every day and scream his head off. Every three months the balance of payments figures come out showing our disastrous trade figures. All the time our roads are falling to bits and we are unable to get our produce to markets as efficiently as we ought.

That is not the only concern we have. Not only has funding for roads been reduced but also there has been a horrific increase in taxation through fuel taxes. I have always been very concerned about the way we supertax fuel. It is a disgrace that it is the third largest source of revenue in this nation. The total funding from oil is nearly $8 billion-$2 billion from straight crude at wellhead and nearly $5 billion from fuel excise. It is going up daily because it is indexed to inflation. This Government is not bringing inflation under control. The official figure is between 8 and 9 per cent, and that is city inflation. The Government always uses the city figure; it never uses the figure for inflation that we have to suffer out in the bush where the further out one gets the dearer goods become. It is very expensive to construct a road. The more isolated the area, the more important the road and the more expensive it is to build. There is never any consideration given to that.

The Government now charges councils the excise on diesel, which is a disgrace-one government taxing the other. Yet the Commonwealth still does not pay any rates on the buildings and facilities it has in shires. Local authorities ought to be able to get funding in this area. But the Government forces them under the laws of this land to pay excise on diesel fuel . The local authorities throughout this country are very heavy users of diesel. These iniquitous fuel taxes were transferred from the wellhead when the price of oil dropped. I warned both the previous Government and this Government that import parity pricing was a crazy way to impose a tax on people and that eventually the price of crude would drop. We based our pricing arrangements on light Arabian crude. When this Government came to office the price of crude dropped by more than 100 per cent so it transferred the so-called supertax it was collecting from the wellhead to excise at the pump. The Treasurer taxes every fuel pump in this country. He had the idea some years ago when he was not even in government. He has now certainly brought it to fruition. Every bowser in this country is now a taxing mechanism. More than 50 per cent of the amount people pay for fuel goes in tax to the Commonwealth. Every time one fills one's car more than 50 per cent of the $10, $20 or $30 one pays for that tank of fuel goes directly to Consolidated Revenue.

I have always argued that the overtaxing of this resource distorts our economy. We would not mind so much if a bigger percentage of the money collected was given back to the road authorities. But that is not the case. It pours into the Treasury coffers, into Consolidated Revenue, and who knows where it is spent and wasted. It is mainly spent on welfare. The figures show that there has been a rapid increase in the amount spent on welfare. This is driving us bankrupt. We have the absurd situation of a free phone call operating for practically every hand-out one can think of. One can ring, for nothing, the various departments and get more of the money that is being offered. Fuel tax is where it is coming from. It is indexed and increases every six months, going into Consolidated Revenue.

By mid-1990 the roll forward figure on the indexation of fuel taxes will be 6.475c per litre, an increase of $688m. Only $220m of that will be transferred to roads. In approximate figures, $468m will go into Consolidated Revenue. The ratio is roughly 3 : 1. Of the money collected from the motorist, $1 is spent on roads and $3 goes to Consolidated Revenue. That is the absurd situation created by the taxing arrangements.

I strongly support the endeavour of local government to get more of the excise tax the Government is collecting put back into the road area. As I have said, the motorists of this nation have paid $20 billion over the past three years in petrol tax. We hear a lot about the cross-subsidisation of Telecom. We have a bus fleet running around Canberra which costs this nation $20m a year. Yet motorists cannot get out of this Government more funding for the crumbling road system. Each year the Government is going further backwards. As I said, motorists have paid $20 billion over the past three years in petrol taxes and have received only $3.5 billion in road funds. Those figures alone highlight the great problem this nation faces as far as road funding is concerned. Road funding has fallen by 25 per cent, or $300m, since 1984. Fuel attracts a 150 per cent tax at the wholesale level. That is a disgrace.

State road authorities presently spend 60 per cent of works expenditure on maintenance. This will increase to 80 per cent by the year 2000. We are not putting enough money into roads. If one continues to maintain a road and it falls to pieces obviously the money spent on that maintenance is being wasted. Half of our major roads have pavements that are at least 20 years old. This is another very pertinent figure that has come forward in the research being done, particularly by the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland. Motorists' associations throughout Australia are doing a lot of research of late and coming up with the figures that highlight the problem we are facing.

Better roads have a number of benefits. They save lives and reduce injuries. Since 1980, 24,700 people have been killed on roads. That is a disgrace. A further 248,000 have been injured on our roads. Better roads will reduce labour and fuel costs for businesses and individuals, create jobs, ease demand on the social security system, and stimulate tourism.

Community employment program grants to the States and to local authorities have been cut. We have seen a 53 per cent drop in funding. Last year the Commonwealth gave $181m to States and local authorities. This year grants of only $95m have been allocated. Some councils have suffered savage cuts in general purpose grants. Road funding is back to 1982 levels. Unemployment grants to shires have been cut. Many shires are suffering severe financial constraints. Our side of the House wishes to correct that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I found it very interesting that the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), in framing the motion, directed it to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding). It was rather Freudian of him not to direct it to the actual Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds). I am certain that one of the first things that will happen if the Liberal-National Party ever achieves government will be that the separate ministry set up by this Government to recognise the important role played by local government will be scrapped.
—They would drop it.

—I agree. With members like Senator John Stone playing a prominent part in a future conservative government, I am certain that one of the first things to go would be the separate local government ministry. This Government's appointment of a separate Minister for Local Government coincides with the Government's view of local government. This Government sees local councils as a full partner in the governmental processes. We do not see them as the poor cousin down the road. As I said, we see them as a full partner. As a result, many of the schemes and policies which have been developed by this Government bring to fruition that approach.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Maranoa decried the fact that there have been some cutbacks in funding to local government. This is the same member who sits in the party room with one Senator John Stone. What did Senator Stone have to say about local government funding? In an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 19 August 1986, our friend Senator Stone said:
The Commonwealth Government has no good reason to be involved in local government finances.

I imagine that the debates in the party room between the honourable member for Maranoa, who comes in here and says, `If we get into government we will increase funding for local government' and Senator Stone, the shadow finance spokesman, who says, `The Commonwealth Government has no good reason to be involved in local government finances and should get out of them' are heated indeed. He went on to say that there should be great cutbacks in funding for local government. This is one of the areas which would be cut back under the famous 25 per cent flat tax rate. That is the sort of policy on which the National Party went to the last Federal election. `We will give you a 25 per cent flat tax, but we will have to cut government spending to do it'. One of the prime targets identified by its own finance spokesman, Senator Stone, is local government. Yet the honourable member for Maranoa has the audacity to come in here and speak on behalf of the National Party and say, `We are concerned about local government funding'. Obviously they speak to different constituencies.

The honourable member for Maranoa goes to his local council and cries poor there and says, `We will see you right, fellows', while Senator Stone goes to another constituency and says, `We will get rid of all this unnecessary funding and spending and wasteful government. We will get rid of these local governments. We will get rid of their separate Ministry. We will hive that off and we will cut their funding'.

Let us look at exactly what the Government has done in relation to local government. First of all, we instituted a proper and full inquiry, the Self Inquiry into Local Government Finance. That involved extensive consultations with all the local government authorities-the Australian Local Government Association and the associations in each of the States, as well as individual councils. Following that full inquiry the Government enacted the Local Government Financial Assistance Act, with the result that guarantees have been provided to local government. At least for the initial period of operation of the Act they were given guaranteed real increases in their funding. Also under the terms of that Act, local government is now tied in with the States. So we have a situation where the Commonwealth recognises local government as a partner in the governmental processes of this nation. We have a grants commission and we have the Premiers meeting to decide the grants to the States. We have the same sort of processes set up in terms of local government as with the States because local government is recognised as a full partner in the governmental processes.

Certainly local government, as a recipient of Federal Government funding, has been subject to the same sort of scrutiny as have all other areas of government, but its share of revenue has been recognised and protected as much as any area of government finance. It is simply not good enough for the honourable member for Maranoa to come in here and say, `We are concerned about poor councils being cut back' and at the same time say, `Look at the wasteful spending of this Government. It has to cut back the deficit and let us get in to surplus'. We had that at the last election. Is that still the policy of the conservative parties? Maybe they have had a change of heart. Perhaps they now say, `We are genuinely concerned about local government'.

Last week we had the Business Council of Australia saying, `There needs to be something like $2.5 billion worth of cuts to Federal Government spending to get the economy going'. Then we had the shadow Treasurer saying, `They are wimps. That is not hard enough. We need to cut it even more'. Their election policy would have resulted in massive cutbacks to local government, as recognised by their own shadow finance spokesman, and the shadow Treasurer made similar statements last week about the need to cut government spending. Against that sort of scenario we have the honourable member for Maranoa crying poor on behalf of local government.

Let us not look at the theory of the conservative parties when they come to local government. Let us look at a government in operation and see how they actually work in practice. The only State that has a National Party government is Queensland. Let us see what its record is in terms of funding local government. The first point to remember is that when the Whitlam Government first started leading into expansion of the relationship between the Federal Government and local government-which I concede, and applaud, was carried on by the Fraser Government-the Queensland Government did not say to local government, `Good on you, you are getting some extra money. You go out and expand your programs and get on with your capital works program'. The Queensland Government cut back the subsidy on capital works. Its argument was, `Your are getting this extra money from the Federal Government. You do not need to get 40 per cent subsidy from the State Government any more. We will cut that back'. So that was cut back in the 1970s.

Now we have the situation that the Queensland Government has cut back the subsidy on capital works even further. Commencing in the new financial year, the capital works subsidies for Queensland local authorities are down from 30 per cent to 20 per cent and they were only in that 30 per cent category as a result of a special program put forward by the Queensland Government. That is one example of how the conservatives in action have treated local government.

The motion talks about arrangements between councils, and certainly new arrangements have been put in place. Those arrangements recognise that money should be going to the councils in most need. It has been a hallmark of this Government, in terms of its spending, that money has gone to councils in need. That has meant that some councils obviously have lost and others have gained. The honourable member for Maranoa was very slick. He produced some figures and said, `This council has been cut back by this percentage'. Maybe I should do the same and get some figures to show how others have been increased.

The honourable member for Maranoa might be familiar with the Roma Council; it might even be within his own electorate. The funding for that council, which is a council in need, has increased this financial year by 13.8 per cent. What about the Mount Morgan Council, up by 17.5 per cent, or Nebo Council, up by 15.9 per cent? Funding for Toowoomba Council, which borders on my electorate, is up 17 per cent. Crows Nest Shire in my electorate has increased funding, as have the populous shires around Pine Rivers and Caboolture. That is an example of how the new funding arrangements have helped these councils. How did the Queensland conservative National Party Government react to this? First, it did not respond to the request to get these principles in place as to the funding arrangements. It said, `No, we are not going to participate in this'. So the Federal Government was forced to put in its own principles. How did the then Queensland Premier respond to that? Did he say, `We had better get together with the Federal Government and work out arrangements so that our local Grants Commission can appropriate the money properly.'? No, he did not do that. He went to the Queensland local government conference held at Jupiter's Casino down on the Gold Coast and he said, `I do not think there is going to be a role any more for the Queensland Grants Commission in terms of local government funding'.

What that means in terms of the legislation and the way that money has to be channelled through from the Federal Government to local councils, given that there is no direct recognition of local councils in the Constitution and given the difficulties that were identified in the financial assistance cases in the 1970s, is that if there is no local government grants commission operating in any State, constitutionally and legally there are difficulties about whether the Federal Government can even make grants to local councils. So we have a situation where the former Queensland Premier was quite happy to throw away the interests of his local councils and say, `I will not even enact a Queensland grants commission. We will not even have it'. That meant, in effect, that no money could flow through to Queensland councils. Of course, there was uproar at the local government conference and he was shouted down. The chairman, Sir Albie Abbott, made the point that the Grants Commission played a very worthwhile role, and it does. Unfortunately, that has not actually happened in Queensland, but it just shows the House the contempt that the Queensland Government-the National Party in operation-has for local government. That is obviously going to be reflected in its Federal policy, because that great friend of local government, the farmers' friend, Senator John Stone, has said publicly that the Federal Government should not be involved in local government finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did he say that?
—That was on 19 August 1986.
—He was not even a member of our Party then.
—I genuinely hope the honourable member for Maranoa has some success in changing Senator Stone's ideas on that.
—What about Senator Walsh?

—Senator Walsh is a strong supporter of local government, I remind the honourable member. He certainly does not make bland statements suggesting that the Commonwealth should not be involved in local government funding at all. I hope the honourable member for Maranoa has some success in convincing Senator Stone that local government has a full role in the governmental process. I hope he has success when we discuss these referendums, probably later in the year. If constitutional recognition for local government gets up, it will be interesting to see what the National Party does. I think there will be a great temptation for half the members of the National Party to take the easy path and say, `No, we will oppose all this. We will not be interested in supporting any referendum'. I shall be interested to see what the honourable member for Maranoa does when he has all the councils in his electorate screaming for support for constitutional recognition of local government.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a basic tenet of this Government's policies. That proposal will be put and I hope it is supported by the Australian people. I will be watching with interest the actions of honourable members opposite to see what they do in regard to that proposal, because it is universally supported by local councils throughout Queensland and the other Australian States, and certainly by the Australian Local Government Association. They believe that councils require constitutional recognition as a first step in their ongoing development. To sum up the situation, I point out that it is the height of hypocrisy for the conservative parties, which are calling for large cutbacks in government spending, which as late as last week were saying that $2.5 billion was not enough and which in the last election--

TALK.START.PARA: —Welfare.

—Welfare would be the honourable member's answer. At the last election even further cutbacks were proposed. The National Party of Australia with its flat tax policy wants further cutbacks. When the Government has cut back across a range of programs and has had to do that regardless of its economic policy, it is the height of hypocrisy for honourable member opposite to come in here and say, `Look, the poor councils are missing out on funds'. It is the height of hypocrisy when conservatives in government are cutting back subsidies for capital works programs, as is occurring in Queensland. They push their politics so far that they say, `We will not even allow the mechanism whereby money is directed to local government in Queensland to apply'. That is the reality of the situation. If the honourable member for Maranoa is genuinely concerned about local government, he will stay in his own home base, in his own backyard, and sort out his own policies and his own Party's problems before trying to heap ridicule on the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to rise in this debate to support the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) in regard to the motion he has brought before the House in defence of local government. I also support his call for greater recognition of local government as the most accountable form of government administration. I welcome the opportunity to follow in this debate the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) who has, I freely acknowledge, in his own articulate way, had a great deal to say about his perspective on local government funding. However, he has very conveniently avoided what the resolution is about and what the Liberal and National parties have been about. The honourable member for Fisher said that under this Labor Administration local government is treated as a full partner. A great marriage that has proved to be for local government! If this is the way in which the Government treats a full partner, I would hate to be a partial partner of this Government. The honourable member for Fisher very conveniently chose to reflect, he thought successfully, on remarks made by Senator Stone as late as 19 August 1986, when Senator Stone called frankly for a general cutback in expenditure. From my point of view, that is not an inconsistency; it is not inconsistent with the argument floated by the honourable member for Maranoa.

SPEECH.PARA: What we on this side of the House plead for this afternoon is simply that local government be treated proportionately, in a manner that is equitable with the treatment of the other tiers of government. Of course, there have been calls for cutbacks across the board. Under this Administration we can no longer afford to spend the money that we have been spending. We can no longer afford to impose additional burdens on ratepayers in the case of local government and on taxpayers in the case of State and Federal governments. Our plea is that any cutbacks to any tiers of government be treated equitably. As the statistics I will put before the House in a few moments indicate, there has not been equity in the way in which local government has been treated relative to the other tiers of government in Australia.

It seems to me entirely appropriate and timely-and I am reminded by a remark made by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) yesterday that there are only eight sitting days remaining in which we can occupy this chamber-that the honourable member for Maranoa should move a motion that focuses on local government before we move from this place to a place that will have a great deal more physical prominence and dominance in the political system in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But without the character of this place.

—That is true; there will not be the same measure of character. I do not rise today to criticise the move to the new Parliament House; I make the point that when we move there we will have moved into a building of enormous proportions, of dominance in the Canberra and Australian landscapes. It will be easy to forget the essential role of the other two tiers of government and to pretend that some sort of automatic wisdom is conferred on us in that new location. It has been too easy to criticise local government because local government administrations have from time to time failed to meet the demands of their ratepayers. Of course, when they fail to meet those demands there is a great hue and cry, as the failure is so public. When State and Federal administrations disappoint their taxpayers, that disappointment is not quite so public. When administrators are appointed to replace local government administrative bodies, suddenly the issue dominates the Press and everyone becomes aware of it, but when we fail through an individual department to meet the requirements of the people, that is all too easily glossed over. The appointment of public administrators in local government is a reflection not on the failure of local government but on its accountability and the way in which people easily identify local government and its vulnerability, in a healthy sense, to public opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: Those of the 37 or 40 of us who have served both in local government and in this chamber know that when we were in local government we were more accessible to the electors than is the case now: whether in a silo queue, the front bar of the pub, or a public meeting, one could not escape the constituency. But when we are sitting here in Canberra and things are hot in the electorate, we can temporarily avoid the heat. I acknowledge that there have been two decades of dramatic change in local government. Whereas at one time the three Rs of local government were, as we all know, roads, rates and rubbish, I concede that under the Whitlam Administration greater responsibility was given to local government and, as a result, the three Rs of local government have become roads, recognition and rationalisation. However, I must say that, while I have freely acknowledged what was done by the Whitlam Administration, funding has not kept track with the measure of responsibility that should have gone with the rationalisation of local government.

I refer to a table showing the proportion off total tax revenue spent in each of the levels of government from 1961-62 to 1986-87. In the Commonwealth area the proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) that went in tax revenue in 1961-62 was 18.4 per cent, and that figure has increased to 24.7 per cent. In the States and Territories, the proportion of gross domestic product going in total tax revenue was 2.6 per cent in 1961-62, and that has increased to 4.8 per cent in 1986-87. However, in local government-and this is the nub of what the honourable member for Maranoa has been proposing and precisely the point that should be recognised by the honourable member for Fisher-the proportion of total tax revenue that went to local government as a percentage of GDP was 1.3 per cent in 1961-62 and by 1986-87 it has fallen to 1.2 per cent. I know that that fall is relatively incidental, but, compared with the increases in Commonwealth and State taxation revenue as a proportion of GDP, that fall is quite significant. It is precisely that fall that the honourable member for Maranoa is bringing to the attention of the House through this motion; it is precisely that fall that the honourable member for Fisher failed to recognise when he tried to deflect the blame into other areas by saying that we stand for a cut in total Commonwealth expenditure. Honourable members on this side of the House do stand for a cut in total Commonwealth Government expenditure, but it must be proportionate.
