DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: World Expo 88-Roads-Political System-Logan City Council-Veterans Affairs-Endeavour Foundation-International Humanitarian Law-Chocolate Cigarettes

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Her Majesty the Queen opens Australia's World Expo 88 this coming Saturday morning in Brisbane. I am sure that all Australia is very proud of the efforts that have been made to ensure that World Expo 88 will be one of the finest-if not the finest-world exposition ever. During the next six months, Brisbane, Queensland and indeed all Australia will be under world focus. We will never receive as much publicity as we will receive during this period of Expo, and congratulations are in order in a number of cases.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to congratulate the former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, and members of his then Government for deciding that a World Expo should be the focal point of Australia's bicentennial celebrations. I also congratulate the Queensland Government for taking on the responsibility of staging the World Expo in Brisbane. Further, I extend my congratulations to the present Government for being very diligent in providing the necessary funds to ensure that Expo could get off the ground, because it is an exposition and a great event which really covers the whole political spectrum and for which all Australia should be coming together to ensure its success.

I am convinced that it will be a success because preliminary studies show that apparently more than 800,000 international visitors will attend Expo during the next six months. I understand that those figures are on the trend upwards, so more than one million people could attend from overseas, and more than seven million Australians could visit the World Exposition during the time it will run. That is a wonderful prospect. Undoubtedly, there is a tremendous sense of excitement in Brisbane; there is a carnival atmosphere in the city. People from all walks of life have come together to ensure the success of Expo. We should also be paying tribute to the literally thousands of people who are giving their time as volunteers to ensure that Expo is a success. I believe that we will all be very proud of what happens in Brisbane during the next six months, as we show the world what Australia is really all about.

The interest generated in the event overseas is incredible. The other day I learnt that a special competition was held in this connection by the Japanese post office. I understand that the competition related to an efficiency campaign, with the first prize being a trip to Expo. I do not suppose that many people know that, apparently, 1,500 Japanese postmen will be coming to Australia. In the United States, there have also been a number of incentive programs with prizes of a trip to the World Expo in Brisbane. During the Expo period, few nations in the world will not get a real taste and flavour of what Australia is all about. I hope that we make the most of all the opportunities that will present themselves during the next six months. There will be a great opportunity to promote trade and tourism in Australia.

If successful overseas Expos overseas are any indication, we should get flow-on benefits from Expo for 20 to 30 years to come. I cite as an example the city of Seattle where a World Exposition was held in 1962. Seattle, a great city on the American west coast, still benefits from that Expo. The Expo site is still a major attraction, bringing people into Seattle to see just what it was all about. There is no doubt that the complex on the south bank of the river in Brisbane is a magnificent example of what can be achieved when Australians come together with one common purpose-to show the world what we are all about and hopefully to ensure that full advantage will be taken of opportunities to promote trade and tourism.

I do not want to be negative, but I want to draw attention during this grievance debate to a couple of aspects concerned with Expo. I have spoken before about the decision of the Federal Government not to proceed with a new international air terminal in Brisbane. Already we have seen the disastrous results of that decision, with overcrowding and delays of aircraft. We are stuck with that situation now and just have to make the best of it.

I was absolutely horrified to learn that the Federal Government has decided to impose a duty free levy on visitors to Expo. Yesterday, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) asked a question about a contract being awarded in Brisbane to one company to handle duty free purchases at Expo and to process those purchases at Brisbane Airport as people left. It would seem that an Expo tax of 1 3/4 per cent has been imposed on these purchases as a handling charge. I would have thought that would be one of the last things we would want to do, as it will give people a bit of a bad taste in their mouth after they leave Australia, following all the excitement and goodwill that Expo will provide.

Another matter has come to our attention. A moment ago, I referred to the visit of the Japanese postmen. It is estimated that more than 200,000 Japanese visitors will come to Brisbane to make their way through Expo. People who have travelled out of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport would obviously be impressed with the sale of duty free goods and especially primary products, such as fish, beef and some fruit, available there. Brisbane is fast developing as Australia's second airport, and one thing proposed by a certain Brisbane company was to ensure that such facilities were available out of Brisbane international airport. In all fairness, I should not mention the name of the company except to say that it is reputable and is deeply involved in the beef export industry and in trade with Japan. It is certainly no fly-by-night organisation.

Last November this company approached the then Commercial Manager of Brisbane Airport to ask whether or not the Government would be prepared to call tenders for a concession to supply frozen beef to visitors travelling out of Brisbane international airport back to Japan and other centres at the conclusion of Expo. As we know, the Federal Airports Corporation took control on 1 January, and the company representative heard absolutely nothing. He saw me some months ago about the matter, and I made personal representations to the Minister. I received the usual two-paragraph ministerial reply from the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) advising me that my representations had been handed over to the Federal Airports Corporation, as it assumed responsibility for Australia's major airports on 1 January.

Surprisingly enough, I suppose, not a word has been heard from the Federal Airports Corporation since that day, not even a word of acknowledgment of my representations or the representations of the company involved. To my knowledge, no reply has been given even though the Minister was good enough to hand over the representations to see whether something could be done. I really wonder what we are getting ourselves into in establishing some of these quangos. Although we are told that they will be more commercially responsible, really what is happening?

I decided a few days ago to raise this matter in the grievance debate, and I was amazed to read on page 3 of this morning's Australian a headline `PM's plea to Japan over beef'. The accompanying article states that the Prime Minister had written to the Japanese Prime Minister with a personal request for Japan to stand by its commitment not to discriminate against Australian beef exports. I would have thought that some of the greatest promoters of Australian beef exports would be Japanese tourists returning from Australia to their homeland. The amount of primary products loaded on to aircraft leaving Sydney is quite staggering. It is estimated that the average Japanese tourist leaving Australia spends no less than $100 on frozen beef to take home. This tremendous appeal is being made to places such as Japan and Korea: `Please open your markets to Australian beef'. That is all very well, but a multi-million dollar business is there for the taking in supplying these beef packs to returning Japanese visitors. Yet we do not have the wit, the will, the knowledge or the inclination to take up this business.

My grievance today is that absolutely no action on the request has been taken by the Federal Airports Corporation. While it may not be the direct responsibility of the Minister any more, I hope that he will kick some heads. It is crazy that up to 800,000 international visitors will travel through Brisbane without there being the facility for them at least to try some of Australia's primary products and take them home. The overall effort should be to promote the sale of more Australian primary products overseas. What does one have to do to get the bureaucracy moving?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I reflect on the history of road funding in this country I sometimes wonder what seems to cause a resistance in Australian governments to providing adequate funding for the road system of Australia. A cursory examination of the history of funding by the Federal Government for road construction in this nation shows a grudging acceptance of responsibility to provide funds for road construction. In the early 1920s the Hughes Government provided financial assistance to the States for road construction; but this was primarily as a means of alleviating unemployment, especially among ex-servicemen. The Main Roads Development Act 1923 was historic in that it was the first time that the Federal Government used its powers under section 96 of the Constitution to:

SPEECH.PARA: Grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as the Parliament thinks fit.

The Act provided for the grant of $1m to the States in 1923-24 for the construction of main roads between important towns where railways did not exist and for arterial roads in country areas where local authorities were unable to finance the heavy cost of road construction and maintenance. The basic argument used on that occasion to speed up the construction of main roads is still used today in support of the case for increased Federal Government road funding.

In reviewing the activities of both Federal and State governments in this country it is hard to locate one area of greater government neglect than the road building program. I do not know what the explanation is. Why is it that, in a continent of nearly three million square miles, where the people have been tormented by the tyranny of distance and where the very survival of commerce and industry and the general standard of living have depended on safe and secure ground communications, the campaign for adequate road funding seems to be neverending? How could north Queenslanders ever forget that it was not until 1962-13 years after the Menzies Government seized power-that the Bruce Highway from Brisbane to Cairns was bitumen sealed? It was a narrow and dangerous bitumen road, where intrepid motorists were confronted with single lane bridges, flood prone causeways and a bitumen seal that would crack up after a few showers of rain. Nevertheless, it was better than it had ever been and north Queenslanders were grateful for it.

In 1974 the Whitlam Government introduced the National Roads Act and the Roads Grants Act and thereby assumed full funding responsibility for roads that had been identified as being of special national significance, such as the national highways. This ambitious program to rebuild the road system in Australia was dealt a severe blow by the Fraser Government. For example, during the seven years of the Fraser Government road grants to the States were slashed by 29.5 per cent in real terms. Queensland suffered a major cut in Fraser Government funding for roads and, in a sickening display of political cowardice, the Queensland National-Liberal Party Government did nothing about it. Motorists, local governments and State governments were provoked to fury with the Fraser Government which had, in effect, made every petrol bowser in this country an office of the Australian Taxation Office. This occurred at a time when Australia's roads were cracking and crumbling under the strain of the cutback by the Fraser Government in funding for roads. Unquestionably, the Fraser Government's callous failure to allocate a fair share of road users' taxation to the upgrading of Australia's road system was a direct cause of the increased number of deaths and injuries on Australia's roads.

The slashing of road funds by the Fraser Government was an act of brutal cynicism and displayed a callous disregard for human life. Put simply, the national highway was falling apart and more and more motorists were being killed and maimed on Australia's roads. The then Chief Executive of the National Roads and Motorists Association, Mr George James, was reported in the Australian of 19 March 1982 as saying that the Fraser Government bore `a great responsibility for the failure to reduce the road toll'. He continued:

`If New South Wales wants to achieve a major reduction in the road toll, it will have to receive much better treatment from the Federal Government. In New South Wales we have now reached a crisis point. We are now seeing the wastage of our research which will take generations to repair'.

But what a damning indictment of the Fraser Government. People in North Queensland will never forget that it was the Fraser Government that trebled the price of petrol, quadrupled the fuel related tax take and slashed more than half a billion dollars from road expenditure.

On 13 November 1984 the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke) pledged to the Australian people that his Government would undertake the greatest road building and maintenance program in Australia's history. In 1985 the Hawke Government passed legislation establishing the Australian land transport program. This program was designed to ensure that there was adequate funding to meet the urgent need for good roads. The program recognised that it was essential that road funding be put on a predictable and assured basis to meet the ever-increasing pressure on Australia's road system. The program was also designed to give encouragement to State and local road authorities, the construction industry and equipment suppliers, so that they could plan for the longer term and get on with the great national task of accomplishing what has always been, and will always continue to be, a good road transport system in this country.

One often hears during debates in this House that Australia's economic future depends on the Government's ability to assist in restructuring industry, encouraging economic efficiency, promoting exports and substituting local manufacture for imports. Do honourable members share my view that a well-developed road infrastructure is vital to the success of these objectives? Will members of this House demand that road funding must be at an appropriate level to support efforts being made in the manufacturing and trade sectors? This view is supported by the transport industry which is on record as congratulating the Hawke Government for investing wisely in road projects to mark the bicentenary of Australia, but which also enjoined the Hawke Government to maintain road funding in real terms and thus maximise the social and financial benefits of good roads for every Australian.

The economic returns from road investment are substantial. The average benefit-cost ratio is of the order of 3:1; urban arterial roads as high as 12:1; and rural arterial roads 5:1. Good roads provide dramatic savings in vehicle operating costs, wage costs, accident costs and road maintenance. Savings in operating costs from using good surfaced and well maintained roads, rather than poorly surfaced and badly maintained roads, can be as much as $35,000 a year for a typical interstate freight vehicle. The economic benefits of good roads to trade and commerce are real, but if road funding is reduced, new efficient road works will not be commenced and the effects on our trade and manufacturing objectives will be reduced when the road system cannot meet demand.

Road transport related activities in Australia employ about 500,000 people, or about 1 in 13 of the Australian work force. Some 83,000 Australians are employed in design, construction and maintenance of Australia's road network, with approximately 55,000 Australians employed in rural Australia. Governments should be reminded again and again that the road sector has the highest employment generating capacity of all sectors which produce a physical product of economic value. A reduction of $1m in roads expenditure can be shown to lead to a loss of some 55 jobs, and a reduction of $1m in road expenditure will produce, Mr Deputy Speaker, only a net budget saving of some $380,000, due to income tax forgone and additional unemployment benefits payable.

Around 75 per cent of Federal road funding is spent in rural Australia, providing a significant boost to local and regional economies. If road funding is cut by $100m, up to 2,400 road jobs will be forgone in the rural sector, with another 2,000 jobs likely to be eliminated in the longer term as the decrease in consumption spending works its way through the local economies. So let there be a commitment on this Parliament to increase road funding in this country. Let the Australian people have an all-weather, dust-free and flood-free standard of highways in this country and let the growing cities and towns of north Queensland have a genuine highway standard length they need and deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend some time giving consideration to the values and the ambitions of the Australian people and trying to compare those ambitions with our performance here in this Parliament and the political system generally, to see whether our performance marries up with the ambitions that the Australian people hold for this country and for their governments. I think it is not unkind to say that at present there is widespread disillusionment with governments and parliaments throughout this country. This is not restricted to any particular political party, but one only has to talk in the community to get the feeling of widespread disillusionment that there is with the political system in Australia and the fact that it is not delivering the ambitions and the vision that the Australian people want to be delivered by the political system.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the mistake has been made by the political parties and by politicians throughout this country and over many years that we are able to provide satisfaction and stimulate the values of the Australian people by providing them with material benefits. All the political programs that have been offered over many years in this country, at least over the last 25 years have been dedicated towards providing material values for the Australian people. Those programs of the political parties have been backed up by the trade union movement, by the advertising industry and, of course, by the finance industry. The public has been bombarded over a long period by people in positions of responsibility trying to convince the Australian people that by pursuing material values they will obtain greater satisfaction in life.

The Australian people have now reached a stage of disillusionment because clearly those material values are not able to give them greater satisfaction in life. It is interesting that we are now seeing a trend of people moving back to spiritual values and greater numbers of people attending church services each Sunday and participating in their local spiritual activities. I think that that is a good trend for Australia. Unfortunately, at this stage, the political system has not adequately picked up this trend that is already occurring in the community.

It should be noted by the leaders of all political parties, at both the Federal and the State levels, that the ambitions, the visions, of the Australian people are changing rapidly and that it is incumbent upon us to change the programs that we put forward so that they marry more adequately with the ambitions of the Australian people. I was reading just recently a book published in 1934 by a former President of the United States, the late Mr Herbert Hoover. I thought that some of the things that he outlined in that book entitled the Challenge to Liberty were worthwhile quoting to remind the House, to remind Australia, to remind all our political participants because he does remind us that there are intrinsic human values that should be the very basis of all the programs that we bring forward through the political system. Hoover says of liberty:

Who may define liberty? It is far more than independence of a nation. It is not a catalogue of political rights. Liberty is a thing of the spirit to be free to worship, to think, to hold opinions and to speak without fear, free to challenge wrong and oppression with surety of justice. Liberty conceives that the mind and the spirit of men can be free only if the individual is free to choose his own calling, to develop his talents, to win and to keep a home sacred from intrusion, to rear children in ordered security. It holds he must be free to earn, to spend, to save, to accumulate property that may give protection in old age and to loved ones.

It holds both in principle and in world experience that these intellectual and spiritual freedoms cannot thrive except where there are also economic freedoms. It insists equally upon protections to all these freedoms or there is no liberty. It therefore holds that no man, no group, may infringe upon the liberties of others. It demands freedom from frozen barriers of class and equal opportunity for every boy and girl to win that place in the community to which their abilities and character entitled them. It holds that these liberties and securities to constructive initiative and enterprise alone assure the immense need of material, moral and spiritual achievements of men.

There are stern obligations upon those who would hold these liberties, self-restraint and insistence upon truth, order and justice, vigilance of opinion and cooperation in the common welfare. These are words, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we should well take to heart because of the vision that Hoover was able to exercise in the composition of this book. I remind my friends on the other side of this chamber that we should all take heed of what this great man had to say in 1934. After talking about some of the sacrifices that the American people had to endure in the course of the Wars of Independence in that country, he says:

From these sacrifices and in the consummation of these liberties there grew a great philosophy of society-Liberalism. The high tenet of this philosophy is that Liberty is an endowment from the creator of every individual man and woman upon which no power, whether economic or political, can encroach and that not even the government may deny. And herein it challenges all other philosophies of society and government; for all others, both before and since, insist the individual has no such inalienable rights that he is but the servant of the state. Liberalism holds that man is master of the state, not the servant; that the sole purpose of government is to nurture and assure these liberties. All others insist that liberty is not a God-given right; that the state is the master of the man. Herein, is the widest divergence of social and governmental concepts known to mankind.

I suggest that it is wise of all of us to think very carefully about these words of Hoover because those same encroachments upon our liberties and upon the liberties of the Australian people are very much in the minds of the Australian people at this time when we see programs being brought forward by this Government and by other governments at State level, when the liberties, the freedoms of the Australian people are being impinged upon and there is a genuine fear amongst Australian people that governments are encroaching on their rights and freedoms. But Hoover was also very conscious that governments would get out of hand in this way and that danger was ever present. He goes on:

Our system has at all times had to contend with internal encroachments upon Liberty. Greed in economic agencies invades it from the Right, and greed for power in bureaucracy in government infringes it from the Left. Its battles against betrayal of trust, business exploitations and all forms of economic tyranny have long demonstrated that it was no system of laissez faire. Its battles against the spoils system or the expansion of bureaucracy have long demonstrated its live sense of opposition to the subtle approaches of political tyranny.

If we think only at the moment of some of the programs that governments have, I am sure with the best of intentions, they may be for the betterment of the Australian people. But some of the programs that are being brought forward include one for an identification card, with the justification that people should not be allowed to evade tax. I do not think any of us could deny the fact that tax evasion is a very bad thing for society generally. But the more important thing, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that governments and political parties of all persuasions must guarantee ultimately the great freedoms of liberty, of mind and spirit for the Australian people. I suggest that all parties in preparing their programs for the next election campaign should concentrate heavily on how they can put forward programs of spiritual freedoms and guarantee those freedoms, rather than to be pursuing programs of economic and materialistic values.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to state that I am aggrieved and have been aggrieved by the actions of the Logan City Council in rejecting an ITEC-an information technology education centre-in the electorate, which was to have been funded by our Federal Government to the tune of $300,000. I can only say that I simply do not know for whom the Logan City Council now operates, if in fact it does not operate for the unemployed in our area or for small business. Logan City, unfortunately, has over 9,500 unemployed people on its books that would reach the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and this ITEC is part of a strategy of attempting to get not only people retrained but also to provide a sound industrial base on which to build a number of industries in the area and so provide realistic and long term job opportunities for its residents.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite some time back the last Logan City Council, prior to the 19 March election, decided to look at ways and strategies in which unemployment and business could be stimulated in the area. It came upon a Commonwealth-funded project, which is part of both an initiative by big business and by government to attempt to redress the problems of industry in the training area and also, to provide small businesses with a basis on which to expand into the new technology of the twentieth century. The Council hit upon the idea of a program of the information technology centres and decided that such a centre would be beneficial to that area. Hence it involved one of its own project officers to study the viability of such a program and also then to apply to the Federal Government for it.

It took on the role of being the sponsoring organisation and, in fact, lobbied me as the new Federal member for that area. Indeed, the original commitment by the Federal Government was to have been $250,000. The Logan City Council felt that this was not enough and asked me if I would make representation on its behalf to the Federal Government. This I did and was successful and so had the Federal Government's portion of the payment raised to $300,000.

It then also developed that the major corporate sponsors of the ITEC-and remember that these are national and multinational companies-wished, in fact, to have their corporate image best displayed in the central business district of State capitals because they have found that the pilot programs for ITECs work best when they are within the central business district, as in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide. However, the Logan City Council again lobbied me, suggesting that it had a special case, given a huge unemployment problem and also the fact that the small businesses in their area were subject to the vagaries of the economy and had been targeted by the Small Business Development Corporation of the Queensland Government itself, in an attempt to redress some of the problems which they seem to be experiencing.

So it was that I lobbied again and the Federal Government and the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) lobbied the large corporate sponsors, suggesting that Logan City had a special case and that the move from the central business district to Logan City-which is on the outskirts of Brisbane, halfway between Brisbane and the Gold Coast-would, in fact, be serviced by an ITEC. The Corporate sponsors agreed and so it seemed simply a matter of form that such a development would come to Logan City Council and to Logan City itself.

What in fact does the Council intend to do? What does such an ITEC propose to do? What it does is provide a series of training programs for unemployed in that area in relation to the technology. It provides very basic sorts of courses in welding and circuit making. It also provides more highly skilled courses in the word processing area, in the development of programs and systems in a wide range of courses. On the other side, on the business side, an ITEC provides space, facilities, resources and expertise for small business people to develop programs, particularly in relation to the new information technology which is relevant.

All these things were seen by the previous Logan City Council and the project officer as being worthwhile and as providing a basis for development in the area. On 19 March the new election came and the very first act of this new Logan City Council-I might add without its mayor, who is sick and unable to attend many of their meetings-was to find that it was unwilling and unable to vote for such a project. This seems extraordinary because we have had a massive number of representations by the Logan City Chamber of Commerce itself, which found the actions of the Council extraordinary in the extreme. It cannot believe that a group which initially was the sponsor organisation, which had spent $40,000 to $50,000 on a project officer to get the submission which had lobbied the Government arguing special consideration, and which had got the Government to give a further $50,000 as part of its donation, would then turn around and reject it.

However, what we might say is that the Logan City Council and the councillors will, we hope, be vilified because there is no question that the citizens of Logan City are requesting that we find a way to go about getting such a centre. The reality is that if Logan City does not pick up this centre it will never have the chance again. What I have been trying to do and what the Minister for Employment and Education Services has suggested is that we look for alternative sponsors. We are in the process of looking for people. The Logan Chamber of Commerce, the Trades and Labour Council, church groups and others in the area are all seeking ways in which they can develop a united program and hence sponsor what is obviously a very worthwhile project.

Let me say that the pilot projects and other projects which are running in Australia have a 90 per cent placement rate for their trainees. This is simply because big business is involved and the businesses which are involved provide jobs and the kinds of training and skills basis which are essential for people to work and operate in the area. The second function, of course, is that of small business. In fact, a number of small businesses operating out of the Sydney office have gone on to become national companies. One is in the international market.

What I find extraordinary as well is that I pioneered a work force strategy committee in the area with the Logan City Council, the Chamber of Commerce, the CES and others. They suggested that we bring the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) to the area. This we did and in discussions with that Minister it was decided that the kind of industry which would absorb most people and which would be most viable in that area was in the technological field. Logan City is very well placed because it is midway between Brisbane and the Gold Coast and it is also near to the University of Queensland which has its own technological development centre. It is also not far from what is going to be the Bond University and, of course, it is also on the road to the Darling Downs Institute.

So all these areas would have been serviced by such a centre. Indeed, this was where it was agreed. One can only ask what the new councillors see their role as. What is it that they want for the good citizens of Logan City? They obviously are not interested in training programs. They are obviously not interested in the unemployment in the area. They are obviously not interested in the development of small business for the area. Anybody can see that a $600,000 project, which is what the project would have been in terms of government sponsorship, corporate sponsorship and the sponsorship from the Council itself, would have meant that kind of facility in the area which currently is not provided.

So, Mr Deputy Speaker, let me just say that I am aggrieved not for myself but for the citizens; that I will certainly be doing everything in my power to ensure that those citizens are better served by me and the Federal Government than would seem apparent from the actions of the current Logan City Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this eighth last day of sitting ever in this chamber on the current schedule of sittings, I would like to grieve and lodge my entry into this grievance debate on behalf of veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel in relation to a number of repatriation matters which were crystallised by an excellent letter from Mr Gordon Reeds of the central coast of New South Wales. Mr Reeds is the president of the Central Coast and Hunter Valley Sub-Branch of the Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia. In so doing I am particularly delighted that you, sir, are in the chair today because you and I and just a handful of other members are the remaining returned serving personnel in the House of Representatives and the Senate, reflecting changing times; there are now fewer than 10 members of Parliament who have served overseas for their country in times of conflict and war.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess our responsibilities are even greater to heighten pressure on the government of the day in the interests of those veterans, war widows and others who have suffered. I am pleased that the honourable member to follow me has also at least served as a member of the Veterans Review Board in Queensland. I will therefore be interested in his contribution. In raising these matters, it was a delight to see last Anzac Day record crowds in many places turn out to watch record numbers of service personnel march in country towns, cities, capital cities and beyond. That Anzac Day commemoration is a sharp reminder to the Parliament and to the Government of our responsibilities with regard to the defence of this nation and to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to get on top of his portfolio and stop the haemorrhaging of the Navy, Army and Air Force.

It is also a sharp reminder to the Parliament with regard to the commitment to look after those who served their country in time of war. So it is that I present to the House a grievance lodged by Mr Gordon Reeds and quote from his letter of 29 October 1987, which is just as relevant today as then:

When looking through the English dictionary I could not find adequate words that would convey to you my members' total disgust at the way the Government has treated the veteran community of Australia. I would like to show you in point form just a few of the hard won rights, privileges, entitlements and benefits the Labor Government has either taken from the veteran, their wives and dependants or have condoned by not restoring them when it was elected to power:
(1) The introduction of the assets test;
(2) Changes to the onus of proof when claiming for war caused disabilities;
(3) Increased difficulties in being made a TPI pensioner;
(4) Interference with war widows' pensions and medical benefits.
So he goes on to list a number of other areas, including certain closures at the specialty wards at Repatriation General Hospital, Concord. Mr Reeds adds:

They gave you all but their life in defence of this Country. Well, we, the Veterans, wonder if it was worthwhile. Could a dictatorship or military regime be worse than the Hawke-Keating show that is running this country now? Would they treat their veterans with the contempt that Messrs Hawke and Keating do so?
He goes on:
Regarding the erosion of entitlements the point raised about the Defence Service Home Loan is a straw that broke this Sub-Branch's back.

Of course, he is referring to the massive chopping and changing of the defence service home loan scheme in the May mini-Budget, when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that the Government was going to privatise the Defence Service Homes Corporation. Here we are, nigh on three years later, and nothing has happened with regard to that. There is talk about signing heads of agreement next month. Let us wait and see the detail of that particular announcement.

In the Budget of September last year the $25,000 loan was eliminated for a period and replaced by a $10,000 grant. A week later the loan was brought back. Then in December the $10,000 grant alternative was eliminated and the maximum term reduced from 32 to 25 years. So veterans have had to put up with, and indeed serving personnel have had to put up with, massive chopping and changing of the defence service home loan scheme and that, in turn, Mr Deputy Speaker, has exacerbated the resignation rates of our senior command personnel of all ranks in the Navy, Army and Air Force. Mr Gordon Reeds goes on in his letter to say:
There is a debt owed by this country and the population of Australia. This debt was incurred in good faith by the numerous governments of this country when they committed Australians to war.
He adds:

Disability pensions, medical treatments, pharmaceutical supplies and all levels of hospital treatments. These are not welfare cases or payouts, as your Government Colleagues like to suggest . . . They are compensation payments, paltry compensation at that, owed by Australia to servicemen and women who have suffered an illness, injury or disease due to his or her service in a theatre of war on behalf of this country.

I realise that there are difficult economic times faced by this Government, in many ways created by this Government, and that it has to be responsible in its approach to the administration of veterans' affairs and other jurisdictions. But I want to emphasise to the House that expenditure on veterans' affairs falls in a totally different category from expenditure in the social welfare area through the Department of Social Security where billions of dollars are currently being expended under our Budget; in fact an amount five times that which is being expended in veterans' affairs.

Veterans affairs expenditure is an obligation owed by this Parliament, by the Federal Government of the day to those who have served their country in time of war. It should be properly honoured, rather than tracking down the range of cutbacks and changes, and very complex and disconcerting changes, which the Federal Government has brought in ever since May 1985. The current Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) is a man of great dedication to his Party and to his portfolio, but he has to run with Government policy on these matters. We face another mini-Budget at the end of next month and that is a matter of great concern to the veterans' constituency as to whether they are going to be treated in that in the same way as they have been in previous Budgets; for example, the Budget of 1986 which cut out war widows from the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, or the mini-Budget of 1985 which halved travel allowance for veterans to get to and from specialist treatment, especially from country areas; in my electorate of Farrer, from Albury or Deniliquin on referral to Melbourne or to specialists at Heidelberg Repatriation General Hospital and the like. That allowance was halved and there has been very little increase since that time.

I believe that we must provide, and indeed the commitment of the coalition is to provide, the greatest understanding, recognition and support to our veterans and war widows and other categories that responsible government can afford, administered through a separate modern department of veterans affairs. Let me just emphasise that that commitment to retain a separate department of veterans affairs is one freely acknowledged and supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), is one that was very much part of Liberal-National Party policy at the last elections and is a continuing commitment.

Those who would spread rumours to the contrary, particularly in the light of the recent Business Council of Australia document, are merely creating mischief. That is why I take this occasion to make very clear in Hansard in this grievance debate today our commitment to retain a separate modern department of veterans' affairs and to look after those who served their country in time of war. What we say is that the nature of the cutbacks imposed by the Government on veterans affairs have all been out at the sharp end, at the coalface, at the operational level, with regard to the veterans system. I do not see too many cutbacks in administrative areas of the Department's budget, which is around $89m each year, although it has had to tighten up in some areas, and that is as it should be.

I believe the nature of these cutbacks since the mini-Budget of May 1985 when this round of cutbacks started under Budgets, mini-Budgets and aspects of the Veterans' Entitlements Act has been excessive and has created very real concern and very real hardship for our veterans. At the same time, whilst there have been some improvements granted by this Government, particularly for example, to HMAS Sydney and logistical support ship personnel, one must look at the total picture. The total picture is one of anger in the veterans constituency, as reflected by this excellent letter from Mr Gordon Reeds, and I have much pleasure in bringing that communication to the House in this grievance debate today and reiterating the commitment of the coalition to provide the greatest understanding, recognition and support for those who have served their country in time of war.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to my particular grievance, I want today to raise questions about the Endeavour Foundation, which is a charity organisation and indeed a company in Queensland, not with a view at all to tarnish its reputation, a hard-won reputation in the field of servicing disabled people, but to clarify the basis of a real conflict between the Endeavour Foundation and the Government. The Foundation was set up in 1951 but now serves some 3,000 clients in Queensland and is by far the largest such organisation in Queensland and probably, I suggest, the largest charity organisation working for the intellectually disabled in Australia. To give some idea of the magnitude of the operation of the Endeavour Foundation, its operating costs in 1987 were some $23m. Its capital expenditure was $3.5m. It employed 623 full-time staff and 292 part-time staff.

I have to ask, however: Is the Endeavour Foundation doing the right thing by its clients? Is it running an efficient organisation? I ask these questions in the specific context of the introduction in 1986 into this House of the Disability Service Bill, which became an Act. The basis for that Act was to deinstitutionalise, if you like, to return as much as possible the disabled people to the community, to normalise their lives as much as is possible. But in the broader context, of course, there are very few charities in this country today that are pure models. Most charities exist with government assistance. Where the taxpayer pays, I believe the taxpayer has to have some say in the disbursement of moneys and the quality of services and in the outcomes for clients. So that is the basis for our conflict.

The Endeavour Foundation in its $26m or $27m annual turnover receives $7.5m in operational subsidies from the Government. In the past it has received fairly substantial amounts of capital, and of course we must remember that its clients are all recipients of some form of income from the Commonwealth itself. Endeavour has been vehement in its opposition to the Disability Services Act and I suspect that it perceives the Act as a threat to its ability to control its own destiny. But while Endeavour seeks to consolidate its own edifice and its own existence, it does run the very real risk of ignoring the needs of its clients and the demands of the taxpayer for a reasonable outcome for moneys spent.
The Government wants, as far as possible, disabled people to come out into the light of day, to return to the community. I will quote very briefly from the objects of the Disability Services Act:
To ensure that services provided to persons with disabilities:
(i) Further the integration of persons with disabilities in the community and complement services available generally to person in the community.
(ii) Enable persons with disabilities to achieve positive outcomes such as increased independence, employment opportunities and integration in the community.

Those are laudable objectives. Honourable members should understand that the whole concept of deinstitutionalisation has some difficulties and not all people agree with it. I will take a further quote from a worker in the field, a Mr Roger Barson, who, writing in the Australian Capital Territory's Council Social Service newsletter of February 1988, summed up the debate rather well:

Those of us who know institutions systems well face a moral dilemma. We have no confidence in these systems and are vividly aware of what it will mean for people inside if they do not get out. At the same time we know that getting out is not the simple answer some evangelists would have us believe. We are conscious that for some people who have intellectual disabilities deinstitutionalisation can mean little more than the replacement of a large institution with a small one.
He goes on to say:

However, despite the difficulties there is no doubt that the possible limitations of community living are still far preferable to the known horrors of institution life. The question is not whether to take this leap into the community but rather how to do this in a safeguarded, defensible manner.

That is a laudable thing. Now in the context of that debate and the resistance by the Endeavour Foundation, the Endeavour Foundation has to be very careful that of course with a new Act comes a new financing principle and in a finance paper released by the Minister, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), it has been made clear that there will be a new deal, especially in Queensland, for disabled people. I quote from that paper:

One possible approach to achieving a redistribution of Commonwealth assistance is suggested which involves allocating 75 per cent of new services money to States on a per capita basis and targeting the remaining 25 per cent to Victoria and Queensland, the two relatively under-resourced States.

So Queensland will certainly benefit mightily from the new Disability Services Act and for a more equitable disbursement of moneys among the States. To that, though not directly, there is the response from Mr Woolcock, Chairman of the Endeavour Foundation. He is really attempting to bury his head and return to the 1960s, I suspect, when he says in the annual report:

We are threatened by a dramatic change in the relationship between the organisation and the Commonwealth Government is relation to subsidies and services. Not so long ago there was no Commonwealth Government involvement in our services at all. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, organisations such as Endeavour Foundation sought Commonwealth Government assistance.

Therein lies the problem for Endeavour and all such charitable organisations that they are now substantially funded by the taxpayer and the taxpayer has to have some say in it. But I in turn have to ask Mr Woolcock some questions and I take all of the evidence from Endeavour's annual report of 1987. I ask him, and to these questions the taxpayer requires answers: Is Endeavour Foundation justified in spending over $4m on administrative costs a year, which is over 15 per cent of the total cost? Is the Endeavour Foundation justified in declaring a surplus for the year 1987 of over $2m? Is Endeavour justified in having a total staff of over 915 to service fewer than 3,000 clients? Is it justified in spending over $1.2m on motor vehicles in 1987? And it is justified in spending huge sums on an incredible edifice to the administration of the institution which has recently been completed at Bowen Hills? Is it justified in declaring, as it does, `The vague, broad and unrealistic notion of substantial numbers of people with handicaps being prepared for open employment is difficult to accept.'?

I have here an entire list of acceptable services around the country that are able to return disabled people to community or open employment. It seems that it is possible and I want Endeavour to listen to this word, to listen to those service providers around the country who can do it. I have to quote from a person I will call Miss K, who was a client of Endeavour at one stage:

I have worked at the Endeavour Foundation, Bowen Hills, for eight years. I was only about 18 years old, and I am now 26 years old. I felt over the years just by going there there was a whole waste of effort. I started to realise over the years that I had more capability in the tasks that were set out before me and many of the clients, and that I should be in open employment. I think that the Endeavour Foundation were very amiss by not having a training program for people like myself to train for the open market. I blame the Endeavour Foundation for those wasted years of my life, and also a waste of other people like myself with a mild disability when they are still normal people. I feel I have been institutionalised for the last eight years, robbing me of the chance of outside employment, marriage, a home and a family. To me, it was like living in a gaol. They were ruining people's lives, and do not even realise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the recent months we have had introduced into this Parliament legislation under the title of the War Crimes Amendment Bill and the Crimes Torture Bill, but we have not had legislation introduced into this House to deal with the implementation of international conventions dealing with humanitarian law. It is this that I want to talk about today. It is a great disappointment to me that in spite of many promises made by the Government, not only to members of this Parliament, but also to Australian Red Cross, the Government has seen fit to delay yet again the introduction of legislation to ratify protocols dealing with international humanitarian law. International humanitarian law, as the House would know, seeks to preserve the principles of humanity in the midst of war, where peacemakers have failed to avert an armed conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: International humanitarian law seeks to minimise the disturbance of the peace suffered by the civilian population and to promote adherence to basic principles of humane treatment of those who have withdrawn from the conflict. International humanitarian law seeks to preserve the principles of humanity in the midst of war; where peacemakers have failed, international humanitarian law seeks to minimise hardship and inhumanity. There is an urgent need for Australia to affirm its commitment to international humanitarian law. We should do this, not only by signing, which we have already done, but by ratifying the convention and more particularly, ratifying the protocols to the Geneva Convention.

We should do it by the education of our civilian population about the principles of humanitarian law. We should do it by educating our military forces concerning military law, and by taking action which ensures that these forces are prepared, ready and able to implement humanitarian law. The four Geneva conventions of 1949, together with the protocols, constitute the body of international humanitarian law. The protocols were drawn up by the diplomatic conference which met in Geneva in 1947 and 1977. The work of the conference received the strong support of the United Nations General Assembly, with resolutions supporting the protocols being passed in 1977, 1979, 1982, and 1984.

Mr Deputy Speaker, in 1986 at a meeting of the Inter-Parliamentary Union which was attended by representatives of this Parliament, that body also urged the parliaments represented at the Inter-Parliamentary Union to take action to ensure that their governments legislated to ratify these protocols. The basic aim of the Geneva Convention is to guarantee respect for human dignity of every person, taking no active part in hostilities, including members of armed forces who are sick or wounded, prisoners of war or who have laid down their arms. The Convention prohibits violence to life or person, murder, mutilation, cruel treatment, torture and the taking of hostages and outrages upon personal dignity. The conventions and protocols are aimed at the protection of the victims of international armed conflict.

Protocol 2 is concerned with the protection of victims of internal disturbances which have assumed the proportions of genuine armed conflict, which is however not international in character. Protocol 2 aims to protect civilians and citizen populations from being displaced or terrorised, from being starved or killed, from being injured through attack on installations which contain dangerous forces such as dams and nuclear power plants, as well as to give them the protections afforded to victims of international armed conflicts.

Extensive though they are in their coverage the conventions and protocols fall short of what is ideal. They represent what is reasonable, feasible and achievable in the international community up to this time. Some would argue that the conventions and protocol mean nothing because they have not always been observed. That argument is akin to saying that the law against murderers means nothing because murders are committed. The important thing is not that the law is broken, but that all nations should agree that there is a law that is common and binding upon them. Although 145 nations have ratified the Geneva conventions, only about half and in the case of one of the protocols less than half, have taken the necessary steps to ratify protocol 1 and protocol 2.

Though, as I have said, we have signed these protocols I am ashamed that Australia has not formally ratified them. We should demonstrate our concern; we should demonstrate our commitment to international humanitarian law by example. An example will in this instance be manifest only when we take the legislative action to ratify the protocols. Last year Australian Red Cross was told that the legislation would be introduced in the autumn session of Parliament. That did not happen in 1987. Australian Red Cross was told, or certainly it was implied to it, that the legislation would be introduced in the autumn session of 1988. We have not as yet seen that legislation. Action is urgently needed and I call upon the Government to give instructions to its drafting officers and to the relevant departments to ensure that the legislation is brought before this Parliament for its urgent consideration.

It is true that having signed the protocols we have undertaken that we will not do anything contrary to their contents. But it is necessary for us to give the example. Secondly, I think we should give an example by making sure that we have programs of public education into the principles of international humanitarian law. Many governments encourage and support their national Red Cross societies as we do in this country in the education of the civilian population. The efforts of the Red Cross need active support, not only by this Parliament as an institution, but also of members of parliament as community leaders.

We, as members of this House, and members of the Senate, can influence the ideas and ideals of those whom we represent. We can effect the development of a public conscience. In doing so we have a responsibility to promote the understanding of international humanitarian law and what it is designed to achieve. When the hearts of our people are motivated by humanity and compassion, adherence to these conventions and their protocols will result as a natural response to a normal human instinct and sense of decency. But if the education programs are to be effective at the community level, our military personnel will have a basic commitment to the principles of humanitarian law. It is, however, important that the armed forces personnel be particularly well-informed as to the content of the law. On most occasions when issues of international humanitarian law arise, they will be the ones who will be called upon to uphold the law and make judgments as to its application.

In the heat of battle, fuelled by fear and panic, it is not uncommon for the voice of private or public conscience to be overwhelmed. In the tumult of war perfect discipline and clear thinking are not always achieved. Aware of the problems facing military personnel, we need to construct mechanisms which help our armed forces to translate legal theory to realistic responses in actual situations which they are likely to face.

We need to ensure that our armed forces do not adopt the two-book mentality, but that the implementation of international humanitarian law and orders and instructions with regard to humanitarian law are part and parcel of the totality of the whole command system. I do not believe that enough is being done within our military forces to ensure that at every level of command, every order that is given in matters related to armed conflict contains divisions dealing with international humanitarian law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will, no doubt, have noticed the banner which has been hanging in King's Hall for the last few weeks. It was painted by an Australian woman, Dora Meeson, and was carried by herself and other Australian women in the suffragette march in London in 1911. Australian women had been granted the vote, federally, in 1901 and in all States by 1908 but their British sisters were still denied their basic right to have a say in who would government them.

SPEECH.PARA: The banner depicts Britannia being advised by her daughter, Australia, to `Trust the women, mother, as I have done', because, of course, Madam Speaker, trust was the key word. Women had been denied the vote in Britain and other countries because they were considered to be fickle and flighty creatures who could not be trusted with the grave responsibility of electing governments. However, modern research is showing that the reverse is true.

Recent studies by the Australian Labor Party and other groups have shown that women in fact are more stable in their voting patterns than men; that they think more seriously about how they vote. They take into consideration more than men do long term implications for their families and they are less susceptible to stimulation of the hip-pocket nerve. Only in the last few weeks polls have shown that in the Adelaide and Port Adelaide by-elections, where the Labor vote suffered due to a superficial and cynical campaign waged by the Liberal Party, fewer women than men swung away from the Labor Party. What better proof could we have of the essential good sense of women voters.

The suffragette banner has been resurrected, restored and handed to the National Women's Consultative Council on behalf of all Australian women by the Bicentennial Authority. I commend the Authority for its generosity and its appreciation that much of history is, in fact, `her story'.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 February 1987, a number of Acts of parliament were proclaimed which had a substantial impact on matters relating to the functions of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) and its responsibilities and accountability to the Government and the Australian people. One important aspect of the legislation was to strengthen ministerial control of ASIO and to ensure that there were means of review of certain aspects of the activities of ASIO. Two means of review were created, one being the appointment of an Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and the other the creation of a Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view the Joint Parliamentary Committee's main task would be to ensure that any surveillance or investigation of the activities of Australian citizens by ASIO was carried out properly and with the consideration of the civil rights of such citizens. The 1986-87 ASIO report to the Parliament has included in its comments on its activities during the year: `Around 50 foreign officials in Australia have an undeclared intelligence role or are otherwise engaged in acts of foreign interference'.

Clearly, such officials must in the course of their activities, be contacting Australian citizens and then possibly subjecting those citizens to the attention of ASIO. It is therefore quite irresponsible in my view that 15 months after the legislation came into force the joint parliamentary committee has not yet been appointed as a result of the failure of the Opposition to nominate its representatives to serve on the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disgrace.
—It is a disgrace, as the honourable member for Hindmarsh has said.

Some years ago, following advice that he was to be posted to the Yilgara region in Western Australia, which is some hundreds of kilometres from both Perth and the town of Claremont, he disputed the posting with the Teachers Arbitration Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: As long ago as 1981 that Tribunal decided, and proposed, that he be appointed as a guidance officer to the metropolitan Perth region and his election as mayor was taken into account. I might add that there is no lack of adequate and well-qualified volunteers for the posting in the Yilgara. The decision, Madam Speaker, and the persecution are both anti-democratic and contrary to the findings of the Tribunal.

—I say to the honourable member for Isaacs and to the House that as a country with a deep and abiding interest in stability in the region we, like other countries in the South Pacific, are deeply concerned about current developments in New Caledonia. It is certainly not the time now, and I do not seek at this time to indulge in any recriminations at all, nor is it opportune to rehearse at any length the warnings which Australia and other countries have given previously of the possibility of the emergence of violence of the kind we are seeing. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: Can he inform the House of the steps undertaken by the Government to achieve structural reform in the economy over the past five years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On other occasions I have expatiated on this topic in the House, but given another opportunity I will just put a few other changes in the context and simply say that when the Government came to office in 1983 it realised that in dealing with the problems of the Australian economy it fundamentally had to restructure the economy to make it a more market driven economy. It had to open Australia up to outside forces and to international competition to make it a more free, competitive and effervescent economy. To do all of that the Government systematically set about a number of structural changes. The first and foremost was the removal of exchange controls and the floating of the Australian dollar which let the market set the exchange rate and let there be a free flow of funds in and out of Australia so that a market could operate. It then restored the banks back to their central position of primacy in the financial structure to give Australia a proper, mature financial structure. It then set about reining in our public sector deficit to free up those savings so that we could have high levels of investment where we needed it in the traded goods or merchandise sector of the economy so that we could restore our current account imbalance. Back in 1985, at the same time as we undertook those macro-economic changes on the micro-economic side, apart from the financial changes I mentioned, we had a major reform of the income tax system to reduce marginal rates of tax, to make the tax system broader and fairer by the introduction of new bases such as fringe benefits tax, substantiation and capital gains tax, and the abolition of many other deductions and concessions which had been exploited for tax minimisation purposes. All of this has produced a better and more robust economy.

ANSWER.PARA: On the industry side, we have moved strongly and rapidly on steel, passenger motor vehicles and other major sections of manufacturing industry, not the least being broadcasting and television. The Government moved decisively to remove the out of date regulation imposed by the former coalition Government, particularly in television, of a two-station rule on the basis that any two stations in Australia had equal audience reach and were of equal value. The Government sought to give people in rural Australia the right to watch capital city television by putting the satellite in the sky in the name of Aussat and, through aggregation, allowing country people to watch capital city television and to have the same choice in television as people in the capital cities. That policy has now been frustrated by the Liberal and National parties. The National Party, seeking to maintain rural monopolies in television, is not supporting the Government's media legislation.
