SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker--
—I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. This is obviously just an attempt to deflect publicity from the video report.
—Order! The honourable member does not have a point of order.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Government for failing to accept the Opposition's initiatives to produce a more competitive and deregulatory television environment by:
(1) removing the present moratorium on the introduction of pay and cable television;
(2) streamlining television licensing procedures;
(3) providing an undertaking that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will conduct an inquiry into issuing new television licences once aggregation has been completed; and
(4) agreeing to remove all restrictions to allow a potential 100% audience reach for all competitors once those changes have been implemented.

One would not have to be a walking encyclopaedia on political science in Australia to know that the most topical issue of political debate in Australia at present surrounds differences of opinion between the Government and the Opposition on the question of broadcasting and, in particular, television policy. Over the past few days we have been treated in this House to the spectacle of the Government using Question Time not for its designed purpose, and that is to provide legitimate responses to legitimate questions from honourable members, but rather for the purpose of conducting a one-sided political debate on the question of broadcasting and, in particular, television policy.

The Opposition has moved this motion today because we want to provide this House right now, particularly in view of the ruling on the point of order raised by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), with an opportunity to debate the differences between the Government and the Opposition on television policy. In particular we want to expose the falsehood that has been peddled most particularly by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the television policy of the Government is some starry-eyed exercise in industry deregulation. He has been running around the country saying that it belongs to that long lineage of great Keating deregulatory initiatives. That view, of course, is far from the truth. If Government members want to talk about motives in television policy, if they want to talk about what people make changes in this policy for, why do they not cast their minds back to December 1985, not quite three years ago, when the Cabinet was locked in debate between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the then Minister for Communications over the direction of media policy? There was no great principle of industry deregulation at stake then. They were not arguing about whether to have a free competitive television environment. Let me remind the House of what Mr Gregory Hywood, the then political correspondent of the Australian Financial Review-hardly, I might say to anybody in this House, the president of the John Howard Fan Club in the Press Gallery-had to say on the ideological purity of the Government and the deregulatory zeal of the Government and of the Labor Party of Australia on the question of television ownership. Greg Hywood said:

It also suggests that while the Government's deliberations on television ownership may involve enormously complex regulatory and social issues, the decision is being considered very much in terms of political advantage.

Those debates were conducted within the context of a Prime Minister who was determined to do the bidding of two media proprietors at that particular time. This television debate now very much concerns whether this Parliament is to make television policy and to pass television legislation based on the interests of Australian television consumers or whether we will pass it based on the interests of individual media proprietors.

I have no argument with any capitalist in this country providing he obeys the law. I have no brief for those who would stir populist resentment against people of wealth in this country. I respect people who have the capacity to accumulate wealth. I believe, as a capitalist, that wealth accumulation is an indispensable part of the Australian community. The argument is not about that; the argument is whether we make policy for the benefit of the Australian people as a whole or to suit short term, ad hoc, political expediency. In this debate the difference between the Government and the Opposition is not that the Government favours competition and we do not; it is that the Government favours adhockery and we oppose adhockery. The difference is that we stand for competition, deregulation and an environment where the ultimate ideal of greater freedom of entry and 100 per cent audience reach is achieved.

I turn to the reason why the Liberal and National parties oppose the lift from 60 to 75 per cent. I pause almost in parenthesis to say what an insult to the intelligence of this Parliament it is for the Treasurer or anybody in the Government seriously to invite us to accept that the litmus test of whether one is a deregulator is whether one favours an audience reach lift from 60 to 75 per cent. In other words, if one favours 75 per cent one is a Friedmanite deregulator; if one favours 60 per cent one is a restrictive troglodyte regulator. What an insult to the intelligence of the Australian people. The reason that we oppose the lift to 75 per cent has everything to do with one very simple fact: under the Government's proposals there is to be no increase in competition, no promise--

TALK.START.PARA: —A decrease.

—As the honourable member for Deakin reminds me by interjection, there is potential for a decrease in competition. Is there any hope in the Government's proposals that we will have more players, more competitors, more entrants? Of course there is not. We have to look not to the policies of the Prime Minister that were conceived in adhockery and have been executed out of prejudice and not out of any long term perspective for the rightful media policy of our country, not out of concern to protect the interest of television viewers and not out of a concern to provide greater choice. No, we have to look to the terms of the policies of the Liberal and National parties to find a concern and a respect for the public interest. We stand for the ultimate goal of 100 per cent audience reach.

SPEECH.PARA: The only reason to have an audience reach limit in the first place is that we are not dealing with a genuinely free market. The former Minister for Communications knows that only too well. When I hear some of the media proprietors and commentators talk about commitments to a free market I think of the logical question: If they really believe in a free market why are they opposed to opening up opportunities for further participants? I say to the Government that if it really believes in a free market, if it really believes the Government is going to benefit from lifting the audience reach to 75 per cent, why is it not, in concert with that proposal, providing opportunities for further participants? The reality is that the Government's proposal has nothing to do with the long range media interests of this country; it has everything to do with accommodating a short term difficulty and a short term situation. I want to take the opportunity of saying one other thing on this subject: it will be a very sorry day indeed when this Parliament feels under duress to pass legislation to accommodate the particular commercial interests of any particular operator in any particular field anywhere in this country.

That brings me to the terms of the policy that was enunciated yesterday. We are asking for the immediate removal of the moratorium on the introduction of pay and cable television. Pay and cable television is not some kind of novel concept that people have been talking about in some futuristic sense; it is a concept and a proven technology that has been around for a very long period. Who is in favour of that? The Liberal and National parties are in favour of that. We are also in favour of a streamlining of the absurdly lengthy licensing procedures. The present situation, for which the Government over the last five years has to be held accountable, is an absolute farce. It will take at least, as I understand it, unless there is some special expedition involved, 15 months for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) to conduct a hearing into the Channel 7 acquisition of the Adelaide and Perth television stations. If that is the situation, as far as I am concerned the proprietor of those stations is as entitled as anybody else to have the benefit of that delay. But I put it to the House that that situation makes a laughing stock of the legislation. It makes a mockery of the Government's administration of the legislation. The Government and the relevant Minister owe this Parliament an explanation why that absurd situation should exist.

Our proposal is not as Senator Evans has alleged and not as the Prime Minister has alleged, and not as I think some people in the media have mistakenly believed. We are not demanding or suggesting the immediate granting of a fourth television licence in the metropolitan areas. We are saying that when the processes of aggregation have been completed-we understand that will be in about two years time-there should be an Australian Broadcasting Tribunal inquiry into the granting of fresh television licences in the metropolitan area. I heard Senator Evans sounding forth in his normal pompous fashion yesterday when he said that the economics of that are absolute nonsense. If he really believes that, he has the right, as anybody else has the right, to put that proposition before the ABT hearing in two years time. Or has he such a craven fear of more competition, has he such craven concern to preserve the status quo, that he is not even willing to have an ABT inquiry in two years time on the possibility of introducing further television licences?

Yet he belongs to a Government whose Prime Minister and Treasurer have the gall to run around the country saying that members of the Australian Labor Party are the great deregulators of the broadcasting and television industry. They are the great protectors of the status quo in the industry. They are the great protectors of a situation that will deny entry to additional players. They know as well as we do that the real opportunities in the next five or 10 years for more competitors and players in the television area will be in the arena of pay and cable television.

We are the only parties which have a definite commitment to the introduction of pay and cable television. We are the only side of politics that has a policy in favour of greater competition. In our policy we have provided for cross-media rules between ordinary television and pay and cable television. In that way we can guarantee that the new participants in pay and cable television will be of different identity from the people who are already in network television. In that way we can be guaranteed of having more competitors in the area. So on every count the policy that has been enunciated by the Liberal and National parties is a policy for the entire Australian community. It is a policy that has one central objective; that is, to provide more competition, to provide more opportunities, to provide more freedom of entry and to say to the entire Australian community, `If you really want to have more choice and competition in this very sensitive area, the only way to have them is to open up opportunities for more entrants'.

The policy that the Government is defending is a policy that says, `Yes, we will be increasing the audience reach limits. Yes, we will be increasing the power of existing participants. But we will do absolutely nothing to open up the market to new players and new competitors'. It is an insult to an elementary understanding of economics for anybody, let alone the Treasurer of this country, to argue that one is dealing in this industry with a free market. One is not dealing with a situation where anybody can establish a television station. One is dealing with a tightly held licensing system where there is a limited number of highly privileged players.

As a whole, the participants in the television industry in Australia have done a good service to this country. The quality of Australian television is of a very high order. I do not share the arrogant view of the Treasurer that existing television stations deliver what he calls `slop' to the community. He was quoted at a Caucus meeting the other day as saying, `Our policy is to give you three lots of slop instead of one lot of slop'. What an incredibly arrogant view. That is the measure of the intellectual depth and commitment to a visionary media policy for the Australian people that emanates from the Treasurer. In other words, the Treasurer says, `They have one lot of slop at the moment. We want to give them three lots of slop. I will let the peasants watch the slop while I luxuriate my mind with higher and more important pursuits'. The reality is that at every stage the development of media policy by this Government has had absolutely nothing at all to do with the long range interests of the Australian community. It has had everything to do with considerations of short term political advantage.

Everyone knows that this legislation has not been designed by the Government as part of some comprehensive media package. When it decided last October to go ahead with aggregation that decision was made on the basis of an audience reach of 60 per cent, not 75 per cent. The legislation which is now before the Senate and which will soon be before this chamber has everything to do with providing a short term solution to a short term problem. It has absolutely nothing to do, and it never has had anything to do, with providing an intelligent solution to this country's media needs.

The only way that we can really have a deregulated media policy in this country, the only way we can open up the market to more competition, the only way we can provide more players in the field, is to go down the path that has been spelt out by the Liberal and National parties over the past couple of days. That has as its basis a 100 per cent audience reach and, to provide hand in hand with the 100 per cent audience reach, opportunities for more competitors and more players to enter the field.

I say again to this House, and through it to the Australian public, that right now the only two parties that are in favour of more competition are the Liberal and National parties. The only two parties that are prepared to legislate on media policy for the total community interest and not for sectional interests are the Liberal and National parties. The only two parties that are committed to the immediate introduction of pay and cable television are the Liberal and National parties. The only two parties that are prepared to have an open mind on the granting of new television licences are the Liberal and National parties.

On every count, when one compares the approach of the Government to the approach of the Opposition, when one remembers that the Government's media policy was conceived in political expediency, after a protracted brawl between the Prime Minister and the then Minister for Communications, the Government fails the test of public interest. Our policy passes the test of public interest with flying colours on every count.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have heard today has been an apologia by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for the failure and weakness of his leadership within the coalition parties; an apologia for the fact that he was not able to pilot through his parties, both the Liberal and National parties, a sensible policy on television; an apologia for the fact that he is about to repeat, on a second occasion, the obstruction of decent television laws in this country that will enable country people to see capital city television, and provide a decent networking structure in television within the context of a decent media policy. The genesis of this discussion is the headlines in today's newspapers about the leadership weakness of the Leader of the Opposition and his incapacity to get his way inside the coalition parties. A headline in the Melbourne Age is `TV farce shows leadership failure'. An article by Mr Steketee in the Sydney Morning Herald, headed `Howard rolled again on TV limit', states:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal Opposition ended five days of division and confusion by reaffirming it would vote against legislation to expand television ownership limits.
The decision means a second defeat for the position supported by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard.
An article in the Sydney Morning Herald by Mr Ramsey states:

John Howard is fooling nobody. All he has done with the Coalition's television policy is take two tortured days to arrive back where his colleagues left him six days earlier . . . have now dressed up a policy that disguises 60 per cent to look like 100 per cent.

The article is headed `Formula is nothing but a pretence'. The Leader of the Opposition thinks he can cuddle up to granny with all of his sympathetic body language but she has seen right through him and put it right on the line-the failure of his leadership, `rolled again on TV limit', and `formula is nothing but a pretence'. The same thing is said by Michelle Grattan in the Melbourne Age-`TV farce shows leadership failure'. And that is what it is.

That is the view of the Australian media about the Leader of the Opposition and his change yesterday. The most disingenuous thing he said in his contribution to the debate a few moments ago was, `The ALP is the protector of the status quo in this industry'. This is from a man who was Treasurer for five years and Minister for seven years in a government that left the two-station rule-talk about the status quo-the most regulatory, iniquitous structure ever in any industry from 1956 to 1983. From 1956 to 1983, bar three years, the coalition governed this country and left the Menzies deal, the two-station rule, put on for Packer and the Herald and Weekly Times, and John Fairfax and Sons sitting on the statute books. The country stations, run by the Country Party members and proprietors, with their stranglehold and their regional monopolies, were left untouched because the National Party, through Sir John McEwen, Mr Anthony and now Mr Sinclair have said, `You won't touch our monopoly in the bush'.

That is the shocking tyranny of coalition television policy. The previous Government said to country people, `You can watch one channel and, not only that, in some places you can actually watch the channel owned by our person, read the newspaper owned by our person, and listen to the radio owned by the same person'. That was what the previous Government believed in. It presided over the worst kind of concentration in media in any country in the world. That is the vicious status quo the previous Government left in television. It supported the satellite. We put it up and changed the ownership structure so that rural people have the right to watch the same variety of programs as city people and the Opposition says, `No.'.

What did Mr Sinclair say today on the front steps of Parliament House? He said, `I am quite concerned that the product of the Government's aggregation is not going to improve viewer choice in the country'. In other words, `I know better. The country viewers can stay watching their one private channel, because I do not think that the choice will be any good'. As usual, `We know best. We will stop country people getting capital city television'. That has been the basis of everything members opposite have ever done.

But even worse in television, the Opposition had the status quo in the media generally, and particularly with print, radio and television it has these enormous empires, such as the Herald and Weekly Times and John Fairfax and Sons, with a television network, a radio network, and massive broadsheet print power, and it was happy to leave it that way forever. It was the same with Consolidated Press with its massive magazine publications and its major television organisation as well. That is the shocking status quo the Opposition left behind.

The Government has come along and introduced a cross-media rule, a milestone piece of social legislation which breaks print ownership from television and radio, and radio from print and television. The Government said, `If you want to be in radio, you cannot be in print in the same place. If you want to be in television you cannot be in print in the same place', and that is there, broken. The Government did not need the Opposition to bring down its deregulatory policy of open competition last night. We have done it. The cross-media rule is on the statute books. It is law. And it has stopped this shocking tyranny. The fact is that the Herald and Weekly Times, Packer, Fairfax and News Ltd would have owned all television, radio and print between them, because they had enough financial power to buy the lot. Members opposite were quite happy for them to own everything. Now there are new owners in television, new owners in radio and a separated print.

We have heard from Opposition members about how Murdoch is sitting on 60 per cent of Australia's print, but we did not hear anything about the Herald and Weekly Times sitting on 50 per cent, did we? We did not hear about the Herald and Weekly Times owning massive television and radio holdings, did we? No, because Opposition members thought those newspapers were barracking for the Opposition. That is why we did not hear about it. The Opposition sat down with the Adelaide Advertiser and the West Australian-this is the dishonesty of the Opposition-it never complained about that. But now that Murdoch has 60 per cent print, but no television, because the Government said no-oh, this is a shocking crime against free speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—It is true and the honourable member knows it is true. The Opposition's paltry argument about a 15 per cent cross-holding, suggesting that, for instance, Murdoch is operating Lowy's network, is wrong, and the honourable member knows it.
—It is not.

—It is wrong. As if anyone would suggest that a 15 per cent holding by News Ltd in the Channel 10s would stop Westfield from operating a station; that is rubbish. The honourable member knows; he has sat happy with the status quo all these years, like the rest of the Opposition. It is no good their coming out now, 30 years later, and saying, `We do not like what the Government has done'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has put up a sensible Bill to allow networking of the capital cities to get at least a critical mass in terms of scale, to have decent production levels, local production, local programming and decent television. Australian television is, I think, the best in the world. But the Opposition says, `No, we will not pass the Bill because we will not let people network the capital cities. We will make them network everything bar Perth, or bar Adelaide'. That is where members of the Opposition are.

The Leader of the Opposition came out last night with this pathetic document saying, `We will go to 100 per cent, but we will have more players'. Paraphrasing that, it means this: `We will say to a television owner, ``We, the coalition, will make big people of ourselves. We will let you own Broken Hill and Mount Isa, Griffith, Mildura and Port Pirie, because we know you cannot survive without those. We will let you own those to get to 100 per cent, but then we will stick in one or two major operators against you in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth and Brisbane'' '; in other words, `We will let you go and operate some minor television stations in rural Australia to get to 100 per cent. Then we will smash the economics of Australian television by having more major capital city television players. We are not opposed to competition; we are opposed to an orderly structure in television-with five networks for a population of 16 million, when Britain has four networks for 60 million'.

The Opposition is saying it wants six, seven or eight for 16 million because it has no idea of the structure of the industry and in its haste to come to a policy to save the face of the Leader of the Opposition it has decided to ditch the viability of Australian television holdings, trying to ditch the viability of running a sensible television network. That is where Opposition members stand. The question is: Will they vote for the Bill? The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) said yesterday he would vote for 75 per cent. If he is prepared to go to 100 per cent, why not go to 75 per cent? Where is the logic in that? If members opposite are prepared to say 100, why not 75? We will see whether they vote for the 75 per cent proposition, which allows sensible networking in television.

That having passed, we will have sensible capital city networks which can employ local programming, have decent critical mass in terms of their audience to be able to do so, and can be operated viably as a network. We will have 25 per cent for other minor players to pick up audience reach. We have cross-media rules in radio to separate radio companies which are specialising in radio out of the other mediums and we have now the cross rule with the separation of print. It is a first class media policy-a first class piece of social reform in terms of media diversification, free speech, and all that goes with it.

The Government owes the Opposition nothing for it. Members opposite opposed everything-always they have opposed everything to keep their vicious grip on it all, so they could leave the Herald and Weekly Times listless as it was for years with its abundant power; listless, lying there with these massive broadsheet holdings and massive television and radio holdings. Members opposite have the hide to talk about the status quo! We know what has gone on with regional television. Proprietors have been running to the National Party for years saying, `Protect our monopoly. Do not let anyone else offer services'. In some of the provincial cities they own the television station, the radio station and the newspaper. That is what members opposite call democracy. They always wanted the system loaded in their favour.

The Australian Labor Party has come along and said, `Let us have some decent diversification of ownership'. This goes for journalists as well, because if a journalist burnt his or her bridge with Murdoch or Packer he or she had nowhere else to go. Now they can go to three television networks the ABC, SBS--
Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members may laugh, but they are going there. They can go to Murdoch. They can go to Fairfax. They can go to the other independent print proprietors, such as the West Australian with Holmes a Court in Perth. That is the result. But members opposite hate that because they know media diversity works against them and for the Labor Party. They think media diversity will propagate sensible views and they do not want that. They have always wanted the loaded gun. They have always wanted the system loaded in their favour.

SPEECH.PARA: What changed all of this was the satellite. When the satellite went up the technical capacity was there to deliver three television signals right throughout this country. No matter where one was, one could pick up capital city television, and public policy had to adapt to facilitate that technological change, and it has, but it has been against the wishes of the Opposition. Now members opposite are in here talking about new entrants and cable television. As if we would be so stupid and so negligent as to say overnight --

TALK.START.PARA: —That would introduce competition. That would be terrible!

—As if we would be so negligent to say overnight, `Yes, we will go into cable television'-to make a national resource decision to go into cable television overnight. As if we would say, `Oh yes, Mr Howard has put a statement out; yes, we will have cable television, otherwise the Opposition will vote against our Bill'. Members opposite have got to be joking to suggest that we would just walk into a major resource decision. I heard the interjection from the Leader of the National Party of Australia. Look, McEwen, Anthony, Sinclair-they have all been in the rotten borough of monopoly regional television, and radio, and print-for years. They say they represent country people, but they would deny them three television stations in the country, the same as the city.

SPEECH.PARA: We reject absolutely the motion by the Leader of the Opposition as an apologia for his failure in his leadership to be able to deliver a decent policy. We reject, as we always have, the central precept of coalition media policy, which is concentration of ownership for the people who supported them and their mates in the country and country stations. We reject it and support a decent media policy of diversification for Australia in and for the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —If anyone thought that the Australian Labor Party was the party of deregulation, that belief has been totally destroyed by the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). He is pursuing a course that is designed to concentrate power more and more in the hands of a few wealthy Australians. It is not a process designed to provide diversity of choice to the consumer or to help give greater viewer choice; it is designed entirely to meet the expedient demands of a few who seek to break the present law.

SPEECH.PARA: If any honourable member on this side of the House thought there was any question about our policy in the past, that doubt has been satisfied. We heard it from the mouth of the Treasurer a moment ago. Let me quote what he said: Australian television is the best in the world. Why, I ask, is Australian television the best in the world? It is the best in the world because the coalition set in place the rules and regulations under the Broadcasting and Television Act, which generated the introduction and pursuit of television ownership, diversity and viewer choice until this Government changed the law last year. Let no-one believe that the amendments of last year have as yet come into effect. The product of Australian television, which even the Treasurer acknowledges is the best in the world, is simply the product of the laws that we introduced. We heard from the Treasurer his great claims about how last year his policy in some way provided greater choice, that all these changes in ownership have in some way provided more competition and more diversity. Let us consider that.

This is not an argument about networking-let us start with that. The Treasurer pretended that in some way networking began only when the Government's policy was introduced. What arrant rubbish. Networking has existed not only through ownership but also through specific arrangements with regional and other capital city television interests right around Australia for years. It existed because those regional arrangements and arrangements with stations in other capital cities-that is, capital cities other than Sydney and Melbourne-were designed specifically to ensure that the same access to major programs was attainable through the major networks as would occur if those networks were all owned by the same station. This is not an argument about networking. It is an argument about ownership. Let us consider the product of the occurrences.

We have heard from the Treasurer in this place on a number of occasions that he has been able to diversify regional and general national media ownership. We must understand first that there has been a greater concentration of ownership within each of the specific media areas-within television, within broadcasting and within print. Secondly, let us consider television, because this argument centres principally around television. What we on this side of the House are pursuing is viewer choice and competition. What does the Government pursue? The Treasurer claims that in some way his policy has led to the breaking up of what he calls the great media empires. We have seen his prejudice and bigotry in relation to John Fairfax and Sons Ltd. We heard it in the House today.

We all know that honourable members opposite have absolute prejudice against the media around Australia. We know that not one of them can stand any heat from the media kitchens. All we hear about is how many writs the Prime Minister has issued. When someone says something nasty about the man who is leaving the chamber, that is, the Treasurer, or the Prime Minister, do they stand up and take it? No, they do not. They run off and ring the editor and say, `That was a terrible thing you said about me. You really need to put in a retraction and, mind you, if you don't we will do something about it'. If honourable members think that there is not a little bit of the old brother network in this, all they have to do is recall the remarks of the Prime Minister in Caucus when these laws were presented: he said, `We will win the next election if we pass this'. That is what this media overtone is all about.

Let me return to diversification. John Fairfax and Sons Ltd was not dispersed because of the laws promulgated by the Government; that company was dispersed, as we all know, because one member of the Fairfax family decided that he wanted to take over the family interest. The result has been the splitting up of what was one of the great media empires in Australia. We should not pretend that Kerry Packer, the second of the major media operators, got rid of his television interest because of anything to do with Labor's legislation. He got rid of it because he was offered the money. He took it and ran, and we cannot blame him. He was offered a tremendous price, an inflated price, and that has in no way added to the value of television and in no way contributed to viewer choice. But what Kerry Packer did and must be able to do in our capitalist system was to take the money and run. That had nothing to do with the Government's media laws.

The third proprietor, and the one I find even more interesting in light of the Treasurer's remarks, is Mr Murdoch. Let us face it, the reason he divested himself of his television interests was purely the result of the provisions under the coalition's Broadcasting and Television Act which excluded overseas ownership. It had nothing to do with the Treasurer's legislation. All this talk about greater diversity and all this talk about result comes back to the fact that because of our legislation Australian television is the best in the world. It provided opportunity for choice and it provided a capacity for the growth of the system whereby there was an opportunity for independent production, whereby regional stations and those in smaller capital cities were able to produce and display programs and had the productive capacity to do so. Under the Government's policy every time there is another takeover local cameramen, local producers and others involved in producing programs go. Most of them have been sacked. We know what is happening.

The Treasurer's program is designed to concentrate power to a few. Any concentration of power in this country must be rejected as not being in the best interests of competition. What we on this side of the House have done is to provide an alternative program that is designed to enhance viewer choice, to ensure genuine competition and, above all, to guarantee that ownership of the media does not fall in to the hands of just a few wealthy Australians. The basis of the argument is that the Treasurer has absolute prejudice against a system that has worked very satisfactorily in a country that has tremendous population spread and has exhibited tremendous diversity in trying to provide alternatives on the media front. What the Government is seeking to do is concentrate those powers and remove much of the competition. Let us face it. As a result of the changed policy there has already been a reduction to about 22 players in the general television game. The result of the shift that the Government seeks to introduce whereby there is a change from 60 per cent to 75 per cent, unless one pursues the alternative course as we suggest, will lead to a further reduction of players in the field.

There is no suggestion from our side of politics that we will stop aggregation; there is no suggestion from our side of politics that we will do anything except enhance viewer choice; but there is a suggestion from our side of politics that we should ensure that even with greater choice we retain the quality that our past broadcasting and television policy has facilitated. We do not want to see standards reduced; we do not want to take every B grade movie from the United States or elsewhere. But that is what the Government wants to do. It wants to concentrate power so that a few wealthy individuals will be able to determine what is seen anywhere around Australia. This argument is not about diversity and it is not about competition: this argument is about Labor's traditional prejudice against the media and Labor's desire to ensure the concentration of power in a way that we regard as total anathema to the interests of the ordinary viewing public.

It is true that the Labor Party for a long while pretended that in some way the whole field of policy was under review, but we must remember in regard to the question of aggregation that, prior to the coalition Government's going out of office, when my colleague the honourable member for Menzies was, I think, Minister for Communications, all the laws with respect to supplementary licensing were proceeded with. As the Minister about 10 years ago I started a program to provide diversity of choice in regional areas. The reason why aggregation has suddenly been forced on people is that for four years the Labor Party did that and for four years regional viewers were denied the prospect of choice. We also know that the satellite, another one of the great achievements that we hear the Labor Party has attained, was a product of a coalition Government. The arrangements were negotiated to ensure that there would be a facility to bring television signals right around Australia, including the remote outback areas that previously had no opportunity of seeing commercial television. The reality is that Labor's policy is based on adhockery and prejudice. It lacks consistency, it denies competition, and it will not facilitate viewer choice.

On the other hand, what we have done is to look genuinely and in depth at an alternative to ensure that there is a way by which the Australian viewing public can have a choice other than through a video system. There will be no restraint in that latter respect, but that relates to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material that is now being considered by the House. Through the application of our changes to the broadcasting and television law we seek to provide not only an extension of reach but an extension of viewing choice.

In the House the other day the Treasurer (Mr Keating) spoke about how sad it would be if we rejected the 75 per cent reach rule, which, of course, is based on the principle of adhockery-and no other-that the Labor Party is now pursuing. We should remember that the other day the Treasurer said in the House that he regarded the retention of the 60 per cent limit as a menacing and ominous development. If honourable members have ever heard an overstatement that is one. What the Treasurer should have done today was to come into the House and say, `I welcome the fact that the coalition parties have presented constructive alternatives. I welcome the fact that there is to be viewer choice. We are prepared to accept that pay and cable television are good developments'. These developments are not new; they were first facilitated in reports undertaken when Tony Staley was Minister for Communications, and he has been out of the House for nearly 10 years.

The reality is that pay and cable television represent a very easy and simple way, particularly with the development of fibre optics, by which there can be diversity of choice for the Australian public. Pay and cable television need to be facilitated. They need to have put in place the programs and laws by which they can operate. It is true that in that respect we would look to `grandfather' the existing Sky networks that are already in place. We would also look at cross-media restraints to ensure that pay and cable television provide both additional competition amongst presenters and additional viewing choice for the Australian public.

Secondly, we want to streamline television licensing procedures. I heard the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Evans) say, `We are looking at this matter. We have a committee and at some time we will do something about it'. If the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy)-who I think will follow me in this debate-had still been Minister, perhaps the procedures might have been changed. What we need to remember is that his policy was a 43 per cent limit, and he has been removed from that portfolio. If the Minister is honest in what he says today he will say that Australia should proceed according to the very views and attitudes held on this side of the House. However, the Minister for Trade Negotiations was apparently wrong. The Treasurer and his powerful friends said, `You will not be able to take control of the Australian viewing public if you have diversity of choice'. We all know how in 1985 the Prime Minister set up a special little committee of his kitchen mates just so he might be able to get the Minister rolled. The product is that that Minister is now no longer the Minister responsible for the area the subject of this debate. Let me go back to what I was saying about streamlining television licensing procedures. The Minister at the table might have facilitated that, but Senator Evans says, `We are looking into it'. At some time in the future that mirror reaction might come good.

Thirdly, we want to facilitate a system whereby new television licences can be implemented. We have a proviso. Aggregation is costing the industry a great deal. There is a shortage of software. We want to ensure that at an appropriate time the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal can be charged with investigating the issue of new licences, some perhaps in VHF and some in UHF. There can be some special licences and some designed to cover local communities. This procedure would be similar to the way in which FM radio, introduced not by the Labor Party but by the coalition Government, has provided greater diversity in broadcasting. The facility of providing for the issuing of new licences ensures new entrants in a restricted spectrum. Television is different from the print media. We cannot just allow in any new entrants who want to get into it. There is a restricted environment. What we propose would allow new entrants. However, the Government does not want new entrants. It is trying to provide a monopolistic situation for a few, and that is total anathema to our side of politics. Fourthly, we would agree to remove all restrictions and to allow what in fact is a potential 500 per cent audience reach, competed for amongst those who are players in the game.

This motion has been brought forward of necessity. The Government persists in using question Time to try to present a one-sided case. In this instance, in the development of communications policy, Labor has failed. It is not improving competition or providing choice for viewers. In fact, exactly the reverse is happening. We believe that the only way in which there can be a reasonable development of good television and competitive media in Australia is by implementing the policy that this motion presents. I commend it not only to members of the House but also to the listening public of Australia wherever they may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUFFY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade Negotiations)

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Hawke Labor Government came to office in March 1983 we could not have been presented with a greater shambles in any area than I faced as Minister for Communications in looking at broadcasting policies. The former Minister in the Fraser Government, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), has just spoken in this debate, and I will deal with what he said in a moment. The fact is that the previous Government was not prepared to take action, and I will pick up now the point made today by the right honourable member for New England. He said that regional viewers are denied a choice in television. Who was responsible for that for 30 years? Who is responsible for it today? It is the result of the failure of the previous Government in that period, and even in its period in Opposition it has not been able to get together a policy on this matter. This morning, in a door-stop interview, the right honourable member for New England said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am quite concerned that the product of the Government's aggregation is not going to improve viewer choice. All you are going to do is get a bit of the repeats of whatever happened about 10 years ago in the United States.

Today, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) commended the standard of television in this country-and quite correctly. We have nothing to apologise for in this country in relation to the standard of television.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all.

—The honourable member for Maranoa says, `Not all'. No, not all, particularly in country areas. Why? The reason is that honourable members opposite for years and years protected the most desperate monopolies in this country-regional television stations. They had a total monopoly in their areas. They could pour out what they liked. People had no choice whatever; they could not turn to another station since no other commercial station was available. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation service was available in those areas and one commercial station. That is what was wrong with the system. What did we do? We decided that at long last that would come to an end.

SPEECH.PARA: It is about time that the Opposition started to understand what this Government did. One of the most important legislative changes that has taken place in this country in the post-war period was in the legislation to which we are referring today. We said that we were not prepared to tolerate any longer an absurd situation for country people. The Opposition parties had presided over a two-station rule for 30 years. I will tell honourable members opposite what they did, so that people, particularly country people, completely understand. The Opposition parties equated the ownership of television stations in Melbourne and Sydney with ownership of television stations in Broken Hill and Mount Isa.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a joke!

—As the Treasurer says correctly, what a joke! For 30 years that was the broadcasting policy of honourable members opposite, yet they have the gall to come here today criticising the Government and saying that we have refused to accept their initiatives to produce a more competitive and deregulatory television environment. That was the regime presided over by them. There were incredible monopolies which provided no choice in commercial television for people around Australia. They were deprived of that choice because of the stupid policies of honourable members opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what honourable members opposite did when we came into government. The first shadow Minister was the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). The next one was the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). We then had the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee). We then had the really sensational performance by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale). He was the man who decided that the solution was to auction the licences. Do honourable members remember that little performance? He did not know where he was going. I waited eagerly for five years to see a policy from the Opposition in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never had one.

—As the honourable member for Aston interjects, the Opposition did not come up with a policy in five years and it still has not come up with a policy. The right honourable member for New England said today, as I said earlier, that he is concerned that aggregation will not improve viewer choice. At the same time the Leader of the Opposition correctly commended-this is one thing he said with which I am not going to quibble-the very high standard of Australian television.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at aggregation and see what it is all about. For the first time in the history of broadcasting in this country the regional television stations are going to feel the cold wind of change through competition. No longer will they be able to sit on their little patches and pour out whatever they like to those five million people in the country who are not entitled to hear and see what we are able to hear and see in the cities. Why not? Because it was denied to them for 30 years by the extraordinary group of people opposite who purport-this is one of the things that really gets to me-to represent rural Australia. I refer to members of the National Party of Australia. They know nothing about it. It took a Labor government to say, `Enough is enough. We're sorry, Mr Nixon; we're sorry about Southern Cross. You just can't go on any longer down there in Traralgon and Bendigo with your monopoly markets'.

We then saw the publicity whipped up against the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) in those areas. It was pathetic stuff. It was said that there would be loss of jobs and programming would deteriorate. What was that all about? It was about one simple thing: they did not want any competition. It was about self-interest. We were not prepared to cop that.

I will run through a little of what we decided to do, because the Opposition seems to have forgotten. We said that for too long the viewing public of Australia, and in particular-I keep coming back to these long suffering people-the viewing public in regional areas, suffered from the effects of legislation which allowed the perpetuation of small monopolistic markets which could pour out whatever muck they wanted. People had to cop it. Honourable members opposite should talk to people in rural areas about what they thought about that system. I do not know whether they talk to their constituents. They have complained about it for years and years.

Another integral part of the media goal that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) kicked on this issue was the question of cross-media ownership. That was something that never crossed the minds of Opposition members. At no stage in 30 years did this happen. If it ever did, somebody would have said, `No'. So the vested interests, not only in regional television but across the whole area of the media in Australia, prevailed. We would not cop that, either. The legislation limited cross-ownership between television and newspapers and television and monopoly radio. We picked up the lot in relation to the cross-media rule. That could not operate within the service area of the related commercial television station.

What has the Opposition done at this stage? I will tell it what it has done as a result of its performance in failing to pass legislation. I will never forget as long as I live the shambles that occurred in June 1987. It was unbelievable. Opposition members would walk in and out of their offices. At first they agreed to an audience reach of 43 per cent, then 52 per cent, then 60 per cent and then it would be 70 per cent. It was like an auction. It was the most incredible performance that I have ever seen in my life. Ultimately they settled on 60 per cent, which at that stage made no sense whatsoever. If they had wanted to argue for a 43 per cent reach, there would have been some logic in that, although it proved to be wrong. But what logic is there, for heaven's sake, in a 60 per cent reach?

The capital city markets, plus the regional television markets, amount on an aggregated basis to a 75 per cent reach. That is a sensible market. It brings about economies of scale, it brings about proper production of television and it allows the industry to maintain the enormously high standards that it has maintained in this country since 1956. But the difference is that it gives a choice to the people in rural Australia who have been ignored by the Opposition for 30 years. It could not care less about them. It is weeping crocodile tears about the problems of country people, but it did absolutely nothing to help those five million Australians in rural and regional areas who were totally deprived of what they were entitled to-the right to receive the same sort of television coverage that people in city areas had received since 1956 or since three stations were established.

Let us look at what the Opposition has done. On the economies of scale, the 75 per cent figure-as the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, said in his statement of 22 April-allows strong local content in the smaller capitals, and more and better quality Australian production generally will be the first victims if this rule does not change and this legislation is not passed. The Opposition's decision quite clearly, as the Minister has stated, means that there is no chance of accelerating the aggregation process at this stage. There is not much incentive for Northern Star's Channel 10 and the Bond Corporation's Channel 9 to fast track their commitment-which they will carry out, given the chance-when the result of carrying out that commitment will force them immediately to divest themselves of a significant proportion of their holdings.

I will turn away from regional and rural Australia for the moment and look at Canberra. The people of Canberra will know, because we are going to tell them, that if this legislation is not passed, next year they will be deprived of being able to watch the same programs and have the same diversity of choice as people in Melbourne and Sydney, because of this idiotic decision that the Opposition has come up with. When those markets are aggregated some of these owners' holdings-I do not know whether this has ever entered any of the Opposition members' thick heads-will be triggered to over 60 per cent, maybe by only a few percentage points. What does the Opposition want them to do? Does it want them to sell and then start again? That is not what it was about. Seventy-five per cent was the rule. That was what was contained in this Government's legislation. The Opposition has put forward no good reason either inside or outside this House why it reverted to the 60 per cent figure. When one reads the transcripts of the interviews given by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) when he was shadow spokesman for the National Party, one sees that they were classics. They were riddled with contradiction day after day and Opposition members are still in the same position.

Let us look at the great rush towards pay television. What did the right honourable member for New England say today? He said that there is a shortage of software. Of course there is a shortage of software. That is why we are talking about economies of scale in production, allowing networking into the regional areas. No matter what the right honourable member for New England says, aggregation will bring about programming in rural Australia which virtually gives the same diversity of choice as the capital cities have enjoyed for years.
Let us just pick up the point made by the right honourable member for New England about the shortage of software. What does he think will go on pay television?

TALK.START.PARA: —Aggregation is the problem; you know that.

—It is a pity that as a former Minister for Communications-failed though he was-he will not listen now. Where does he think the software is going to come from for pay television? It is true that it is difficult to keep the quality of television up. What the Opposition is proposing is the dumping of overseas rubbish, both on free to air television and pay television. It is also advocating that one day the people of Australia will be paying to watch the Victorian Football League (VFL) grand final. The VFL grand final will become pay per view. That is what will happen. That can be sheeted straight home to the Opposition. This is a contemptible motion that has been put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—On 26 April 1988 in the Social Security Amendment Bill debate on page 2102 of Hansard, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the honourable member for Franklin is someone who when he is in his electorate pretends some concern and some compassion.

This is a totally untruthful statement and all the people of Franklin, and I am sure all honourable members on my side of the House, also know that it is untruthful. Any person who says that about me is a mendacious hypocrite.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable member to withdraw that statement.

—I have the greatest respect for you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I would not want to cause you any complications, but I am not directing the remark at any one person; I am saying that anybody who calls me that is a mendacious hypocrite. PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Audit Act 1901. The principal amendments are intended to enhance the Commonwealth's financial reporting, administration and audit and to bring certain penalty provisions into line with present day criminal law policy. Financial reporting will be facilitated through an amendment to section 49 which will enable the form of the monthly statement of the Minister for Finance to be changed by regulation. This amendment accords with suggestions made during the debates on the Statute Law Bill in October 1987 that parliamentary control over the form should be retained.

Amendments are proposed in relation to the preparation of annual financial statements and fall into two categories. The first concerns the financial statements for the financial year ending 30 June 1988. The proposed amendment will provide for departmental transactions on functions lost to another department through the Administrative Arrangements Order of 24 July 1987 to be shown in the financial statements of the department gaining the functions. In this way, the 1987-88 statements will be made more meaningful by removing the requirement that would otherwise exist for separate statements covering the period from 1 July to 23 July.

The second category involves amendments which will enhance the accountability of departments. They will establish the responsibility of departmental secretaries to prepare annual financial statements of their departments and for those statements to be audited. The statements will be prepared in accordance with guidelines given by the Minister for Finance as to their form and content and will be included in departments' annual reports. Also, since a detailed level of information will be given in these departmental reports, the need for the present detailed reports by the Minister for Finance will disappear. The amendment provides instead that the Minister for Finance shall prepare a report showing aggregate totals only. These amendments were foreshadowed in the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports tabled in Parliament in November 1987.

Currently, the Auditor-General has a discretion not to report on immaterial breaches of establishing legislation by certain statutory bodies. One amendment, requested by the Auditor-General, will permit that discretion to apply to all statutory bodies. I mention here that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has indicated that it does not support this amendment. However, I should point out that there is already a great degree of trust involved in relying upon the competence and integrity of the Auditor-General in the performance of the audit task. This extension is entirely consistent with that trust. Moreover, the amendment is in step with the statutory discretion which the Auditor-General already has not to report breaches which he considers too minor to mention. Such a discretion exists for audits of departments and a wide range of statutory bodies.

Another amendment will repeal the general `catch-all' penalty provision currently contained in section 69 of the Audit Act and substitute specific penalties in the relevant sections of the Act. The amendment stems from advice from the Attorney-General's Department on the desirability for Audit Act penalties to be consistent with the Commonwealth's policy on criminal law generally.

Other amendments concern the creation of a specific offence for the misuse of credit cards issued to the Commonwealth, clarifying the powers of the Minister for Finance to write off irrecoverable revenue and debts that are uneconomic to pursue, and minor legislative tidying up. All proposed amendments have already been considered by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and, apart from the proposal concerning rounding off the Auditor-General's discretion not to have to report immaterial matters, the Committee has raised no objection to them.

The proposed change to the future reporting requirements aimed at enhancing departmental accountability is likely to give rise to some additional resource costs, including to the Australian Audit Office. However, it is expected that the improved accountability will lead to greater efficiencies in departmental management. It is not possible, at this stage, to quantify in financial terms the costs or the benefits.

The amendment concerning the preparation of annual statements for the 1987-88 financial year's report should reduce administrative effort and costs from the levels that would otherwise have been required, by permitting rationalisation of reports to reflect changed administrative arrangements effective from 24 July 1987.

The other changes, including those effecting the penalty provisions, the duties of the Auditor-General and the write-off powers of the Minister for Finance, are not expected to have any significant financial impact on Commonwealth revenue or expenditure. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Carlton) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is an important component of the Government's program of reform in employment, education and training. The Bill establishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training; four councils to deal with specialist advising related to schools, higher education, employment and skills formation, and research; and a Commonwealth-State consultative committee. The Bill also maintains the Government's commitment to a Commonwealth Employment Service within the Department of Employment, Education and Training consistent with Australia's obligations under International Labour Organisation Convention 88; provides for grants for innovative projects and for curriculum projects as well as for administrative support for the National Board and its councils.

The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Act 1977, the Commonwealth Schools Commission Act 1973 and the Commonwealth Employment Service Act 1978 have until now provided for the statutory advisory structures in employment, education and training. These Acts are now to be repealed in this Bill.

The central purpose of the Bill is to enhance and streamline advisory structures in employment, education and training in a manner consistent with the high economic and social priority placed on these activities by the Government. The provisions of the Bill enable the Government to obtain independent advice on employment, education, training and research policies and programs within a single, coordinated framework. The functions of the following non-statutory bodies: the Australian Council for Employment and Training, the Marine Research Allocations Advisory Committee, the National Research Fellowships Advisory Committee and the Australian Research Grants Committee will also be subsumed under the new arrangements.
Background

Following the significant reorganisation of the Australian Government's administration in 1987 I established a task force, under the chairmanship of Mr Charles Halton, to report on advisory arrangements for employment, education, training and research matters. The outcome of this review and the subsequent intensive consultations is the formation of a National Board of Employment, Eduction and Training supported by four councils. The key features of this arrangement are that it provides for independent advice to Government, provides for specialist advice in four vital areas-schools, higher education, employment and skills formation and research-ensures that advice forthcoming will be coordinated and provides a mechanism through which Board and council members can bring the benefit of their expertise to assist my Department to administer its policies and programs.

The new arrangements reflect the Government's determination to complement its commitment to restructure the Australian economy by revitalising education and training policies and programs to develop a highly adaptable and skilled work force. Equality of opportunity and the fulfilment of broad social goals are integral to this strategy. Effective and timely advice to government are essential ingredients to ensure that these objectives are realised in the most effective way available. The work program for the Board will be a mix of formal references from the Minister and matters initiated by the Board itself within its area of responsibilities. The councils will advise the Board on matters in their respective specialist fields. The work programs for the councils will be based on formal references from the Minister and the Board. Councils may also initiate activities through the Board and through the Minister.

The Government's intention is to make the reports of the Board and its councils generally available for public scrutiny. Reports requested by the Minister, together with the annual report, must be tabled before Parliament. In addition councils can invite public comment or submissions on matters referred to them by the Board or Minister. The councils may also consult with persons or authorities as considered necessary and prepare draft papers and reports for external comment. There has been extensive consultation with a wide variety of interest groups about possible nominees to serve on the Board and its councils when established. Many groups consider they should be individually represented. Apart from the practical impossibility of accommodating all such requests, the Government's objective is to draw membership of the Board and its councils from high calibre individuals who can bring extensive experience and expertise to the work of the Board and the councils. As well, other mechanisms have been provided to permit all interest groups ready access to the Board and the councils. An important aspect of the new arrangements is the establishment of a Commonwealth-State Consultative Committee. The functions of this Committee are to inform and advise the Board or its councils on matters relating to Commonwealth, State and Territory policies and priorities in the fields of employment, education and training and research. I turn now to the major features of the Bill.
The Functions of the Advisory Structures

The Bill establishes a National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) whose functions encompass advice on all matters currently within the Employment, Education and Training ministry. It will inquire into and provide information and advice on matters relating to: education-other than migrant adult education-youth affairs, employment and training and national research priorities and the coordination of research policy, as well as matters arising under the legislation within the Employment, Education and Training ministry. The scope of the Board's responsibilities in these areas is defined in broad terms. The primary function of the Board is to provide advice and report on matters referred to it by the Minister.

The Board may also initiate inquiries into other matters within its responsibilities and report its findings to the Minister. Its recommendations will take account of any directions or guidelines from the Minister on the Government's broad social, economic and budgetary priorities. The Minister is required to table in both Houses of Parliament a copy of such directions or guidelines provided to the Board as soon as practicable. The Board also is given power to do all things necessary for the performance of its functions.
Councils

There will be four councils reporting to the National Board: the Schools Council, the Higher Education Council, the Employment and Skills Formation Council and the Australian Research Council. The Schools Council will provide advice and information on any matter relating to schools, and primary and secondary education. The Council will frame its deliberations against such relevant matters as the need for improving primary and secondary educational facilities in Australia and of providing increased equality of opportunity in both government and non-government schools. The Higher Education Council will advise on such matters as the general development of higher education in Australia, priorities and arrangements for the funding of higher education institutions and the overseas marketing of Australian higher education services.

The Employment and Skills Formation Council will cover matters such as technical and further education, employment and skills formation policies, programs and services and the promotion of effective training throughout business and industry. Provision is made in the Bill for the Minister to establish national, regional and local committees to advise on the operations of the Commonwealth Employment Service, under the aegis of this Council. These will be in place of the National Advisory Committee on the Commonwealth Employment Service, which is being abolished. The functions of the Australian Research Council fall into two categories. The Council will provide information and advice to the Board on matters relating to national research priorities or the coordination of research policy. However, in respect of the distribution of resources allocated to research schemes referred to the Council by the Minister and the administrative and other costs of these schemes, the Council will make recommendations direct to the Minister. The Bill specifically provides that the Board may not direct or furnish guidelines to the Australian Research Council in respect of recommendations for particular grants of assistance.
Membership of the Board, the Councils and the Commonwealth-State Consultative Committee

Board members are to be appointed by virtue of their individual skills, expertise and relevant experience rather than as representatives of associations, States or Territories or other bodies which have particular interests. The Board will have up to five full time members and a total membership of no more than 13. The chairperson will be appointed either on a full time or part time basis. All members of the Board will be appointed by the Governor-General. Close cooperation between the Board and its councils will be facilitated by interlocking membership between the Board and the councils with two of the members of each council being Board members. One of these will be the council chairperson. The composition of the Board provides for a broad spectrum of interests to be represented. The Bill provides that at least seven members of the Board have expertise in matters relating to education or training, two members have expertise relating to trade unions and two members have expertise relating to business or industry. Appointments to the remaining positions will provide for balanced advice from across interested sectors, including additional members from nominated areas of expertise. Gender and geographical balance will be further considerations. Membership of councils will also be determined on the basis of expertise first and sectoral representation second.

There have been suggestions that the consumers and providers of education and training will not be adequately represented on the Board. This will not be so. The chairpersons of the Schools and the Higher Education Councils and the Australian Research Council are most likely to be drawn from among the Board members possessing specific expertise in education and training. Similarly, the membership of the relevant councils will largely be drawn from the sectors the councils represent. Added scope in this regard is also provided for by allowing council membership to vary in size to a maximum of between nine and 11 members.
Counsellors

In addition, provision has been made for the appointment of up to four counsellors whose skills will augment the experience and expertise of the Board and its councils, giving them additional capacity to interact with client organisations in areas of focused interest. Examples of this might be the negotiation of educational profiles with higher education institutions and negotiations with unions and employers in industrial restructuring. These counsellors may be part-time members of the Board or of a council. The Bill specifically requires consultation between the Minister and the Chairperson of the Board on appointments of counsellors, their tasks and the reporting arrangements for each counsellor.
Commonwealth-State Consultative Committee

This Committee will comprise nine members: the Secretary to the Department of Employment, Education and Training, who will chair the Committee, and eight State and Territory ministerial nominees. The Committee will provide an important means of identifying broad State and Territory Government priorities in the field of employment, education, training and research and reflecting those priorities in the Board's deliberations. It will also provide the forum for early resolution of significant Commonwealth-State issues in relevant areas. It is anticipated that there will be a high degree of commonality in the agenda for the Committee and the Board. Board members will not be members of the Commonwealth-State Consultative Committee to avoid conflicts of interest and to ensure representation of the widest practicable spectrum of views.
Reporting Responsibilities

The Board will be required to provide an annual report to Parliament through the Minister. The report will include information on references from the Minister to the Board and reports prepared by the Board for the Minister during the previous 12 months. It will also include information about advice from the Commonwealth-State Consultative Committee and each of the four councils, and details of the consultative processes used by the Board and councils in the formation of their advice. The Board will also provide periodic reports as required on references from the Minister. These reports will also be tabled in Parliament.

The Bill contains provisions allowing the Board to decide that some or all of a particular report should remain confidential. I expect that this provision will be used only sparingly, for example, in cases where material would not have been provided to the Board had confidentiality not been guaranteed or where a reference relates to budgetary formulation.
Committees

The Bill enables the Minister to establish, where requested to do so by the Board, various committees to assist the Board and councils in their work. Based on the interim structures, I expect that the Australian Research Council, through the Board, will request to be assisted by four advisory committees in the following areas: the engineering, earth and applied sciences; the mathematical, physical and chemical sciences; the biomedical, biological and veterinary sciences; and the humanities and social sciences.

The composition of these committees may be established by the Minister on the recommendation of the Australian Research Council to the Board and in consultation with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I have already referred to the provision for the establishment of advisory committees on the operations of the Commonwealth Employment Service. Arrangements outside of the NBEET structure will be made to assist in the development of specialist advice on topics such as women's issues and Aboriginal employment, education and training matters.

Given the relevance of curriculum development to three of the four councils and the program nature of the work, curriculum development functions-which were formerly with the Curriculum Development Council operating under the auspices of the Commonwealth Schools Commission-have been transferred to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. A Curriculum Development Centre has been established within the Department to carry out these functions and to provide support to the Board. The scope of activities undertaken by the Curriculum Development Centre will be enlarged to include developing curricula for use in higher and further education as well as in schools. I anticipate that the Board will in due course recommend to me that I establish a Curriculum Development Advisory Committee.
Commonwealth Employment Service

The Bill maintains the Government's commitment to a public employment agency by including provisions dealing with the Commonwealth Employment Service. The Bill provides mechanisms whereby advice to the Minister on the functioning of the Commonwealth Employment Service can be given within the broader framework of employment, education and training established by this Government.
Grants for Innovative and Curriculum Projects

The Bill makes provision for the Minister to approve grants for innovative and curriculum projects. An innovative project is one aimed at encouraging diversity or innovation or designed to test new approaches and techniques.
