A curriculum project could involve research in the development of curricula and educational materials and the publication of those educational materials. The Minister can delegate to the Board Chairperson powers to make these grants.
Secretariat

Provision has been made for a small administrative support group to be provided within the Department to service the Board, councils and committees. The Bill provides for the Director of the Secretariat to be appointed by the Secretary to the Department after consultation with the Chairperson of the Board. It is intended that the responsibility to make appointments to the Secretariat below the level of Director will be delegated to the Director, subject to normal departmental procedures and subject to the Director being required to consult with the Chairperson of the Board as appropriate. The Director and his staff will function as a link between the Board and the Department, to enable the Department's resources to be marshalled and sources of expertise to be utilised to assist the Board and its councils in the most constructive way possible.
Program Delivery

All program delivery, some of which was undertaken by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and the Commonwealth Schools Commission, has now been transferred to the Department. As an integral part of the advisory role, the full time Board members and counsellors will be involved with the Department in the ongoing process of assisting with program implementation through consultation and liaison with individual sectors, organisations and institutions on which programs impact.
Working Relationships between the Board, its Councils, the Secretariat and the Department

An integral part of the proposed new arrangements for the portfolio is the maintenance of a clear distinction between responsibility for program delivery and management on the one hand and, on the other, formal advice on policy and resource allocation issues; and accordingly between the relevant lines of authority. This will provide a strong basis for teamwork and mutual trust within the portfolio. Under these arrangements the Department will serve as a resource to the Board and Councils, just as to the Minister. The Department will play a major role in ensuring that the Board and councils have the best possible basis for their advice and in assisting them to make the maximum contribution to the activities of the portfolio generally, including in the delivery of its programs.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I table the document Working Relationships between the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, its Councils and Secretariat, and the Department.
Financial impact

There will be resource savings over time resulting from rationalisation of the advisory arrangements. On the basis of the new statutory arrangements coming into operation on 1 July 1988, the net savings to the Commonwealth are estimated to be in the order of $500,000 in 1988-89. Funding in respect of curriculum and innovative projects will be decided in the Budget context. They are not expected to lead to any additional demands for resources, with the funds becoming available from the relocation of funding for existing programs such as curriculum development. The amount of $2,345,600 was appropriated in 1987-88 for curriculum development by the Commonwealth Schools Commission and will be available for these purposes.
Consequential Changes

As the Bill incorporates provision for a Commonwealth Employment Service within the Department, it therefore repeals the separate Commonwealth Employment Service Act 1978. The Bill repeals the Commonwealth Schools Commission Act 1973 and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Act 1977. Consequential amendments as a result of those repeals are included in the Bill.
Conclusion

It would be remiss of me to allow this opportunity to pass without thanking the former chairmen and members of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Australian Council for Employment and Training. These people along with the many who served on the various committees have over the years been responsible for many innovations within the training, employment and education fields in dedicated pursuit of the goals reflected in the legislation under which they worked.

While I know that the passing of these institutions is a matter of regret to some, I am confident that the new arrangements proposed in this Bill will provide a sure foundation for carrying on their work in the changed circumstances of the 1980s. The Government is determined that the education and training systems will play an active role in responding to the major economic challenges facing Australia. These challenges will make heavy demands on our human intellectual resources and labour force skills. This Bill, by rationalising the advisory structures for employment, education, training and research, will make a substantial contribution to that end.

Like other successful economies in the world, Australia must give a high priority to education and skills formation and to improving the quality and flexibility of our education and training, employment and research systems. The Government has already signalled its strong commitment to the objectives of reform in the range of activities of my ministry. These improved advisory structures will ensure that the advice received by the Government will be timely and relevant and will assist Australia in increasing its productivity, in these years of challenging economic and social change.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Carlton) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide national legislation for the clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. This is an area of regulation of critical importance to Australia's primary industry, to our international trade in primary products, to the protection of Australia's unique environment and to the safeguarding of the health of all Australians.

The availability of a wide range of agricultural and veterinary chemicals has been one of the more important factors in farm development throughout the world over the past 40 years. They rank with mechanisation of farms, the development of new varieties of plants and breeds of livestock and the improved storage of products as the more significant developments facilitating the bountiful supply of food and fibre we enjoy. The benefits have not been confined to farm production and their use for control of insect vectors of major diseases, such as malaria, or for control of domestic pests are well known.

These chemicals are however, by their very nature and purpose, biologically active. Misuse can result in unintended effects on plants, animals, non-target species, the users of chemicals, the consumers of plant or animal products or workers involved in their handling, transport or storage. Contaminants of formulated chemical products are cause for concern as is misrepresentation of the potential benefits or impact of chemical use. Consumers of food products are justifiably sensitive to residues of chemicals in food. There are some groups in our community who question the use of artificially formulated chemicals in food production at all. However, as with the motor car and the television set, the benefits of controlled use have more than justified their use.

Honourable members may be aware that since 1967 the Australian Government and the Governments of the States and more recently of the Northern Territory have cooperated voluntarily in an administratively based system for the assessment and clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals prior to their registration for use in the individual States and Territories under separate State and Territory legislation.

The increasing complexity of chemical products and the realities of international trade require that improvements be effected in the regulatory framework governing the clearance and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. To bring about this improvement the Government believes that the most appropriate step is to provide a legislative foundation for national assessment and clearance of these chemicals. The cooperation of State and Territory Governments has enabled this approach to be adopted.

A legislative approach has been recommended by the Australian Agricultural Council. The legislation I have introduced is based on the detailed considerations of a working party of that Council and on earlier recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission. It was announced in October 1986 that legislation dealing with these chemical products would be developed and since that announcement the States, Territories, industry and consumer groups have been consulted on its development. The Government has four basic objectives in developing this legislation:
(i) to ensure that agricultural and veterinary chemical products perform as intended;
(ii) to minimise any possible hazard to the public, the environment, users or to agricultural produce and livestock from the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals;
(iii) to enhance the export market potential of our agricultural products; and
(iv) to enhance the uniformity of assessment and registration of these products within Australia.

The legislation will provide the basis of the clearance process which ensures that efficacy, toxicity and environmental impact are fully evaluated, to ensure that claims made by manufacturers can be substantiated and that there are no unintended side effects from the use of agricultural and veterinary chemical products. Some newly developed chemicals are quite complex and designed to be specific in their action while others may have a broad spectrum of use. Assessment of chemicals already in use is ongoing and it is appropriate that the clearance authority have access to the results of such assessments.

The Government has a clear role through the clearance system to ensure that chemical products perform as claimed, and do not jeopardise the quality, or indeed the very production of crops and livestock. The clearance process ensures that agricultural and veterinary chemicals approved for use within Australia perform in the manner intended, producing the expected performance when used according to recommendations.

Of equal importance is the assessment of the potentially damaging effects of misuse of chemical products. A product which is perfectly safe at the correct dosage may be dangerous to the user or to plants or animals at a higher dosage. A product which works well on one crop may, if used on another crop, reduce the crop value to zero. The chemical user must be provided with practical information on the potential problems associated with use of these products outside the recommended parameters.

Honourable members will be well aware of the importance our major primary produce export markets place on purchase of high quality products. It is increasingly important to be able to demonstrate to foreign governments and their marketing agencies and to international corporations that Australia has coherent national standards for clearance of chemicals and control of undesirable residues. The Government believes that this legislation will further strengthen the international standing of Australia's clearance and registration processes, thereby enhancing the export market potential of our agricultural products. Corresponding benefits can also be expected in the domestic market, where the Commonwealth has a strong interest but for which the States have prime responsibility.

Australia has taken a lead role in the development of international standards for the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals through the Codex Alimentaris Commission, sponsored by the World Health Organisation and the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Whilst international harmonisation will take many years to achieve, Australia will be in a better position with appropriate national legislation and a national clearance system.

While there has been a high degree of cooperation between State and Commonwealth agencies in the clearance of new chemicals, for a small country such as Australia, the only cost effective way to assess these products is on a nationwide basis.

This legislation will clarify the obligations and responsibilities of both individual proponents of new chemicals requiring clearance of their products and public officers evaluating applications for grants of clearance. Present processes for clearance and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals have evolved over many years. They now need to be clearly defined in Federal legislation for the benefit of manufacturers, users, our overseas trading partners, domestic consumers and specific interest groups.

It is important to note that the regulation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals described in the Bill is similar to that in other countries comparable to Australia, including those who share a federal system of government such as Canada and the United States of America.

The legislation and supporting agreements with the States and Territories will enhance the uniformity of agricultural and veterinary chemical assessment within Australia. As might be expected, the present system, with seven separate State and Territory registration authorities, has been required to cope with sometimes marked divergence in State requirements. Honourable members may care to reflect on the difficulties of negotiating a path through the some 120 separate pieces of State and Territory legislation controlling the registration, sale and use of agricultural and veterinary chemical products in Australia. The inevitable result has been a lengthy and costly assessment process. In particular, chemical product manufacturers have been required to make separate applications to both the appropriate national coordinating secretariat and to State and Territory agencies to acquire all necessary approvals prior to marketing a product. The Government believes that a significantly more efficient system will result from a cooperative `one stop shop' for clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Enhanced uniformity, in tandem with the streamlined processing system minimising the instances of multiple submissions for approval, will reduce both the cost in, and elapsed time of, the assessment and clearance process.

To achieve these objectives the Bill provides for the establishment of an Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council. The Council will be responsible for coordinating the evaluation of chemicals proposed for registration in Australia, involving assessments of toxicology, human safety, environmental hazard and efficacy of manufacturers claims, and will grant certificates of clearance for those chemicals, the safety and effectiveness of which it is satisfied.

To support the legislation, the Commonwealth proposes to enter into agreements with individual State and Territory governments along the lines of the draft agreement attached as a schedule to the Bill. For the Commonwealth's part, the essence of these agreements will be satisfied by the passage of this legislation and the implementation of an effective and efficient clearance system. Governments of the States and the Northern Territory are being asked to amend their laws to allow the automatic registration of cleared chemicals in participating States or Territories in all but exceptional circumstances. States and Territories represented at the Australian Agricultural Council have agreed in principle with this approach. They will also continue to exercise control over the final registration process and maintain the responsibility for control and monitoring of the sale and actual use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals within their jurisdiction. I re-emphasise the cooperative nature of this venture between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories.

The functions of the Council are detailed in part II of the Bill. These functions include the issuance, variation or withdrawal of clearances for the registration of agricultural and veterinary chemical products in Australia, the evaluation of the effects of the use of these products and the development of codes of practice, standards and guidelines for their use. Council is empowered to collect, interpret, disseminate and publish information relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their use and may advise the Minister on any matter relating to them. All common agricultural and veterinary chemicals will fall within the scope of the Act, including products for the control of insects, fungi, weeds, algae, bacteria, rodents, animal parasites and a wide variety of other agricultural pests. Also covered will be products promoting growth or affecting the reproductive cycle of animals. The legislation does not, however, aim to cover such products as fertilisers, non-medicated animal feeds or individual preparations prepared by veterinary surgeons.

Aside from particular circumstances, to be defined in detail in the agreement with States and Territories, all new agricultural and veterinary chemicals must be cleared by the Council before they will be registered by State authorities. The same process will be required for variations in the use of already cleared and registered products, although this requirement, which is now undertaken fully in each State and Territory, may require phased introduction. Council will be empowered to develop a `fast track' system for minor changes. Council will issue certificates of clearance only when it is satisfied that all necessary information has been placed before it, that the product is effective for its stated uses, poses no threat to persons using it or products containing its residues, and that the product will have no unintended effects on animals, plants or any other objects. Chemicals presently in the marketplace will be treated as if cleared by the new system under conditions applying to their present State or Territory registration. Any requirement for change in their use or new information concerning their impact or efficacy will trigger Council consideration of such chemicals. Applicants for certificates of clearance will be required to provide full and factual information to Council for the purposes of its assessments and to inform Council of any change to information supplied subsequent to clearance of a product being granted. Failure to comply will result in the possible application of penalties.

The Council is to comprise up to 12 part time members appointed by the Minister. The chairperson, to be nominated by the Minister, is expected to be a senior officer of the Minister's Department. Each participating State or Territory, that is, each State or Territory entering into an agreement with the Commonwealth, shall have the right to nominate a Council member. One member will represent both the Australian Environment Council and the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers. The remaining two members will represent the National Health and Medical Research Council and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. All organisations represented in Council are participating parties in the clearance process. Appointments made by the Minister will be for periods up to three years, but members will be eligible for reappointment on the expiration of their appointments. The Minister will be writing to the appropriate Ministers as soon as possible to finalise the composition of the first Council.

In undertaking its functions the Council will be administratively supported by the Department and the Bill makes specific provision for an officer within the Department, to be known as the Chemicals Co-ordinator, to undertake the duties of executive officer to the Council. The present critical roles played by the National Health and Medical Research Council and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission in the evaluation and assessment of chemicals will continue undiminished, these bodies working closely and cooperatively with the new Council. The Council will delegate powers to the Chemicals Co-ordinator or to expert committees to facilitate expeditious clearance of products, especially where minor changes to chemicals clearance or to labels on chemical products are required. The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council also will have the power to establish one expert committee, or a number, of expert committees to assist and facilitate its operations. The Minister would expect consultative committees with industry, consumer and environmental groups now operating under the Australian Agricultural Council sub-committee system to be re-established under the new Council.

The legislation provides for fees to be levied in respect of the effort necessary to process applications. It is the Government's intention that Council operate at a cost recovery level of 50 per cent. As a corollary to the charging of fees, the Government recognises that every effort must be made to reduce the elapsed time taken to process applications. The cost of additional administrative support necessary to meet Council requirements is estimated at $600,000 over the first three years of operation. This figure includes additional staff, together with the costs of fares and travel allowances for members of the Council. These additional resource requirements are presently being progressed through the normal budget processes. Consistent with the cooperative nature of this scheme, the Department will be discussing with State and Territory departments the secondment of State and Territory officers on a rotational basis to the central secretariat.

Some other administrative aspects of the Bill are also worthy of specific mention. First, applicants for, or holders of, clearance certificates will have the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against decisions of the Council to reject applications for clearance, to impose conditions on clearance or to withdraw clearance for a chemical product. Users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals, and other persons with a direct interest in their use and safety, will also be able to raise technical evidence which disputes the manufacturers' or distributors' recommendations or claims direct with the Council under the legislation. Secondly, the Council is accountable to Parliament through the requirement to report on an annual basis to the Minister and for the Minister to table such reports. These reports will also be made available to State and Territory Ministers for the purpose of tabling in the State legislatures. Confidentiality of information will be enforced sensibly to protect sensitive commercial data. The definition of information deemed to be confidential is based on relevant provisions in the Freedom of Information Act.

Finally, the Government expects further rationalisation in the regulation of primary and supporting industries during the next three to five years. The Senate has recently moved to establish a Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, the terms of reference of which include review of the adequacy of this legislation which I have now brought forward. The Minister will be writing to the incoming chairperson of the Senate Select Committee when it is established, asking that attention be given in particular to industry concerns about proprietary rights to the data packages prepared and submitted with applications for clearance, confidentiality of data and the time taken to assess applications and also community concerns on right of access to data and adequate right of appeal on decisions under the legislation. A five-year sunset clause has also been included within this legislation, thereby ensuring a comprehensive reconsideration of the processes of clearance and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals by 1992-93.

This Bill also provides another strong plank in the Government's platform to ensure that a significant environmental issue confronting society is managed effectively and safely. Chemicals in the environment do not generate the hype of some other environmental issues but the efficiency and accountability of the provisions contained in this Bill show that the Government is not ignoring this important issue. I believe that this Bill represents a highly appropriate step in the rationalisation of an extremely complex regulatory area. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will give effect to a number of the amendments to the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development foreshadowed in the joint news release issued on 20 November 1987 by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). The decisions announced then followed a technical review of the concession, which the Government promised when introducing the Income Tax Assessment (Research and Development) Bill 1986. The review was undertaken with the assistance of external consultants and sought to identify ways in which the concession might be exploited other than as intended; and how it might be made more effective in achieving its objectives of encouraging greater investment in research and development by industry in Australia. In the context of that review, decisions were taken to curtail eligibility to the 150 per cent research and development tax concession for expenditures incurred on buildings and to clarify the law in respect of claims to costs of developing computer software. These were introduced in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to all those decisions which will directly involve the Industry Research and Development Board. The remaining decisions arising from the technical review affect only the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and will be introduced during the Budget sittings. The powers of the Industry Research and Development Board are to be extended and legislation relating to the powers and functions of that Board are, by this Bill, to be included in the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 under which the Board is constituted. More important, the amendments will give additional discretionary powers to the Board. The more significant of these are as follows:

To reduce the incidence of companies being required to reimburse tax benefits, the Board will be empowered to refuse to register a company which, on the basis of information provided for registration purposes, is found to be ineligible for the concession.

To increase access by smaller firms to expert research and development assistance, the benefits of exemption from the threshold of annual research and development expenditure and an opportunity to claim for advance payments for contracted research will be extended to Registered Research Agencies (RRAs). Registration will be provided by the Industry Research and Development Board in the field of competence of the applicant RRA. Unlike Approved Research Institutes, RRAs may be privately owned and profit-making entities.

To assist the financing of research and development ventures which are too costly or too risky to be advanced by those with the means to use the results themselves, the amendments provide that the Board may, if satisfied as to the bona fides of the venture, jointly register the participants. This is designed to give some surety of tax benefits to the participants. Joint registration will also enable them to claim in advance costs incurred in funding the venture.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the details of this dispensation, which were announced on 17 April 1988.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

DEBATE.TITLE: 150% TAX CONCESSION: CLAIMING CONTRACT EXPENDITURE AND CONTRIBUTIONS TO SYNDICATED R&D

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator John Button, today gave further details of amendments to the 150% tax concession scheme for R&D where it related to claiming for expenditure incurred for R&D performed under contract including that involving syndicated R&D.
This follows the joint statement Senator Button and the Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, made on 20 November 1987 covering amendments to the 150% tax concession provisions.

``It is taking longer to bring a Bill before the Parliament than had been expected, and it is necessary for industry to know the rules that are to apply to claims when companies incur expenditures for R&D that has not yet been performed,'' the Minister said.

As the 20 November statement indicated, companies will no longer be able to claim expenditures on R&D until the R&D had been carried out. But where R&D is performed under contract, there may be legal and practical difficulties in the claimant ascertaining what expenditures have been incurred by the contractor. It is proposed, therefore, that claims for advance payments will be apportioned over the specified term of the R&D contract. Companies, other than those to which a ``dispensation'' is allowed, will be able to claim in each income year only the proportion of any advance payment that relates to the claim period.

For example, a company for which the income year ends on 30 June that pays another company in April to undertake a three-year program of R&D on its behalf, will be able to claim only one twelfth (3/36) of the pre-payment in the first year (i.e. the pro-rated amount for the three months April to June), one third (12/36) in each of the second and third years and a quarter (9/36) in the final year.
However, in line with the earlier announcement, a ``dispensation'' will apply to eligible companies that:
contract R&D to a Registered Research Agency (until the enactment of amending legislation, an Approved Research Institute); or
invest in projects of R&D that have been given ``in principle'' approval by the Industry Research and Development Board to ``syndicate'' arrangements.
Companies entitled to dispensations may, in the first year only for which a claim is made in respect of the project, claim in advance for the following 12 months.

If the company given as an example above incurs expenditures under either of the circumstances in which a dispensation is allowed, it may claim 15/36 of the pre-payment in the first year, 12/36 in the second and the balance (9/36) in the third year.

Senator Button said that it was important to prevent companies engaging in artificial arrangements for tax planning purposes. The apportionment requirement, coupled with provisions to prevent mis-stating the term of a project, would achieve that end.

The dispensation to companies incurring ``contracted expenditure'' and to companies investing in approved syndicated arrangements was also important. Those performing the R&D would not normally be able to work without advance payments.

The Minister said that he looked to the dispensation to encourage closer collaboration in R&D and to assist those companies seeking funds for major projects the size and risk of which were too large for any one organisation to fund alone.

``It is intended that amendments to give effect to the changes announced in November 1987, including the provisions covering the matters announced today, will be introduced to the Parliament as soon as practicable,'' Senator Button said.

In that context, he noted that some legislation had already been introduced. Further legislation relating to the powers of the IR&D Board would be introduced shortly. The remainder of the legislation will be introduced in the Budget sittings.
The Minister said he hoped companies would invest in research and development that promised to increase their future international competitiveness.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr BARRY JONES

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments are also designed to better equip the Industry Research and Development Board to act against those exploiting the concessions in a manner contrary to the intent of the tax concession. The Board will be able to move against companies which claim for a project which has an insufficient Australian content; and fail, in any significant way, to exploit the results of revenue subsidised Research and Development in the required manner. The Government believes that, by virtue of its collective experience and the individual competence and integrity of its members, the Board is uniquely placed to reach decisions on the technical and commercial issues which it must decide. However, it also recognises that opinions are necessarily reached on the basis of evidence provided by companies and that this may sometimes be ill-expressed or incomplete. Accordingly, this Bill provides that the Board will not be able to move against a company until it has given that company an opportunity to make a submission in response to the stated reasons for the Board's opinion.

INTERJECT.PARA: It is also important that companies not be able to frustrate the Board in the exercise of its functions in respect of the 150 per cent tax concession. Where a company fails within a reasonable period to give the Board such information relating to its activities as the Board reasonably requires, the Board may, by notice in writing, require that information to be provided within 30 days. The Bill provides that, if the company fails to comply with the notice, the Board may issue a certificate to the Commissioner of Taxation with the effect that expenditure of the company in respect of the activities which are the subject of the notice is disallowed.

The Board's responsibilities have increased significantly since it was established and it now has six committees advising it. These cover the taxation concession, discretionary grants, national procurement development grants and each of the four declared generic technology fields for which grants are available. In these circumstances, it is considered appropriate to extend the maximum size of the Board by three members, and, further, not only should the Board be able to delegate some of its functions to its committees, but that the committees should be able to delegate functions to individual members and support staff. Amendments introduced today will permit this.

The Bill will also make certain consequential and complementary amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. The principal effect of those amendments will be to recognise the creation under the Industry Research and Development Act of registered research agencies which are to replace approved research institutes for the purposes of the tax concession. The Government intends to prevent exploitation of the benefits of incurring contracted expenditure for tax minimisation purposes or as a substitute to obtaining joint registration for certain collaborative ventures. Companies will be unable to incur contracted expenditure to a registered research agency to whom they are related. In addition claimants will be required to have a plan to use the results in connection with an existing or proposed business.

There is to be some modification by the Bill of the provisions which disallow deductions for expenditure claimed under the tax concession on receipt by the Commissioner of Taxation of various certificates by the Board. These amendments will take into account the additional powers which the Bill will confer on the Board to issue certificates. These have been outlined above. A decision of the Board, expressed in a certificate stipulating whether particular activities are research and development activities, is binding on the Commissioner of Taxation. However, if a certificate is subsequently revoked, the deduction is revived. The 150 per cent tax concession has been available to companies for expenditures incurred since 1 July 1985. The Government has made it clear that the concession will remain in place until 30 June 1991. Companies have had the benefit of the concession for three years. They will have that benefit for a further three years.

It is too soon to assess the effectiveness of the tax concession as an incentive in encouraging performance of research and development which would not otherwise have been undertaken. However, there is evidence, including that provided by the Australian Statistician's recent catalogue Research and Development, Business Enterprises, Australia, 1986-87, Preliminary, that since 1985 there has been a long welcome and overdue increase in real expenditure on research and development by private business enterprises in Australia. Anecdotal evidence indicates that much of the additional reported research and development would not have been undertaken but for the tax concession. This appears particularly true for smaller companies. The Bureau of Industry Economics has started to collect data against which to assess the effectiveness of the tax concession. This matter is to be considered by the Government in 1990. In particular, the Government will be looking closely at the return the Australian community stands to gain from the generous subsidy currently available to companies claiming the research and development tax concession.

Ministers in this Government have repeatedly spoken of the need for growth in high technology-based industries and the revitalisation of traditional Australian industries through innovation, training and application of new industrial management techniques. The world is less dependent on Australian commodities now than at any time this century. International trade is also becoming increasingly competitive. If Australian companies are to survive to the year 2000, they need to invest as much or more in researching, developing, targeting and marketing products as their overseas competitors. At present most are not. The latest statistics suggest that, typically, Australian companies invest in research and development only half that of world competitive companies. Before the introduction of the tax concession it was a third. The progress of the last three years is encouraging but not sufficient.

It is important to recognise that potential competitors are also increasing their innovation and marketing efforts. Unless industry management recognises research and development as a necessary investment for corporate survival and that investment in new technology must at least increase with the pace of technological change, Australia's relative performance may well worsen despite any absolute growth in research and development performance.

The Government's commitment to maintain the present tax concession arrangements until the end of June 1991 provides sufficient opportunity for industry to establish the technology base for new businesses in Australia. There is a goldmine of commercially exploitable research in government funded research organisations and academic institutions. There is no shortage of innovative ideas and enthusiasms in some of our smaller companies. Yet these companies often lack the funds, the development facilities, the production means and the marketing infrastructure to realise the potential of their ideas.

The provisions of this Bill establish the means for garnering funds which would not otherwise be available for research and development. It is for this reason that the Government is seeking early passage of this Bill.
Financial Impact Statement

To the extent that the amendments are successful in stimulating research and development which would not otherwise have been undertaken during the deduction period-that is, up to 30 June 1991-there will be some additional tax revenue costs in the fiscal year 1988-89 and the three following years. Offsetting this, there will be savings due to the tightening up of provisions to limit avenues by which the 150 per cent tax concession may be exploited other than as intended. It is estimated that the net funding impact of all the changes proposed as a result of the technical review will be broadly neutral.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will make one second reading speech covering this Bill and the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill 1988 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1988, because it is intended that the three Bills be read together as part of a package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indulgence is granted.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. These three Bills form a legislative package, amending Australia's anti-dumping legislation, by:

SPEECH.PARA: Establishing an anti-dumping authority, to advise the Minister as to whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed on specified products exported from overseas and to review and make reports to the Government on anti-dumping matters;

amending the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975, so as to restrict the life of dumping notices and undertakings made under the Act to a maximum of three years, and to clarify various technical provisions of the Act;
amending the Customs Act 1901 by prescribing the manner in which the Australian Customs Service (ACS) is to conduct the preliminary investigation of dumping complaints; and
amending the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 to remove that body as a body of review of dumping matters. That function will now be performed by the Anti-Dumping Authority.
The Bill implements the Government's response to the 1986 Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975-the Gruen Report, prepared by Professor F. H. Gruen.

Dumping occurs when the products of one country are exported to another country at less than their normal value in the country of export. Normal value is usually the price of like goods sold in the ordinary course of trade for consumption in the country of export. Dumping is condemned internationally as unfair trading if it causes, or threatens, material injury to the industry producing like goods in the importing country. The remedy against dumping is the imposition of dumping duties which can be up to the difference between the export price and the normal value.

Australia's anti-dumping system also deals with subsidisation. Where any subsidy, bounty, reduction or remission of freight or other financial assistance applies to the production, export or carriage of goods exported to Australia and those goods cause or threaten material injury to an Australian industry, and in that case countervailing duties, up to the amount of subsidy or other assistance received, may be levied.

Effective anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements are necessary to protect Australian industry from clearly unfair trading practices. This is in accordance with Australia's rights and obligations as a signatory to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) anti-dumping code and the code on subsidies and countervailing duties. Other signatories to the codes such as Canada, the European Economic Community (EEC) and the United States of America employ similar practices. Consistent with the GATT codes, however, anti-dumping actions need to be balanced between providing a means for effective relief from the disruptive effects that dumped or subsidised goods may have on domestic producers and ensuring that the measures do not constitute an unjustifiable impediment to international trade.

Upon this Government coming to office in 1983, a wide-ranging review was conducted, culminating early in 1984 in a number of significant legislative and administrative changes to the anti-dumping regime. Then in February 1986 the Government commissioned Professor F. H. Gruen of the Australian National University to conduct another review of the anti-dumping system to determine whether further improvements could be made and in particular to consider the inclusion of a national interest provision. After considering Professor Gruen's report, the Government has decided to:
Establish an Anti-Dumping Authority to make recommendations to the Minister on anti-dumping or countervailing action;
endorse Professor Gruen's view that there should be no `national interest' provision written into the legislation;
retain section 5 (9) of the Anti-Dumping Act dealing with certain criteria for the determination of normal values; and
introduce a mechanism under which anti-dumping and countervailing measures will cease after three years continuous application.

The Australian Customs Service still has an important role to play in the determination of dumping and subsidisation complaints. The Australian Customs Service will examine each complaint made, and conduct preliminary investigations, the results of which will form the basis of information from which the Anti-Dumping Authority commences its own inquiry. I turn now to each Bill individually.
Anti-Dumping Authority Bill

This Bill establishes an independent authority, which will recommend to the Minister whether grounds exist as to whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed, and to provide the Minister with advice on anti-dumping issues in general. Anti-dumping decisions require judgments to be made involving a mix of economic and commercial considerations. The Government considers that these judgments can best be made by a small independent statutory authority whose staff will include commercial and economic specialists. The Government believes that the Authority will bring a broader perspective to the determination of such issues as material injury and casual link.

The sensitivity of dumping complaints also requires a body operating at arm's length from the day to day administration of industry assistance by the Department of industry, technology and commerce and the Australian Customs Service. Accordingly, an Anti-Dumping Authority is established. The Authority is to:
Advise the Minister as to whether or not dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed on goods-clause 7;
recommend whether the Minister should revoke a notice issued under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975, or release exporters from undertakings made pursuant to the Act-clause 7;
review preliminary anti-dumping decisions of the Comptroller-clause 8; and
prepare and give reports to the Minister on anti-dumping matters-clause 9.

In exercising these responsibilities, clause 10 requires the Authority to have regard to the Government's intention that anti-dumping duties are not used as a substitute means of providing assistance to import competing industry in Australia, nor to shield industry from the need to adjust to changing economic conditions. The Authority is also to have regard to Australia's obligations under the GATT codes.

The Bill also provides for the responsible Minister to issue further directions to the Authority to assist it in its interpretation of the legislation where considered necessary. The aim is to ensure that the Authority is guided by the current industry policy objectives of the Government in its assessment of such issues. Any supplementary guidance will be developed by the responsible Minister in consultation with interested ministerial colleagues. Clause 12 provides that ministerial directions are to be gazetted and tabled in Parliament, and that such directions are to deal with general principles, and not with particular consignments of goods.

Assessments of material injury and the casual link must be rigorous and anti-dumping measures should not be used as a de facto form of protection: they have to be seen as a set of measures to discourage unacceptable short-term threats to knock out an industry in the importing country in order to increase longer-term market share. The Authority will take into account the influence of factors other than dumping in causing injury, such as general economic conditions, production difficulties, domestic competition or undumped import competition when assessing whether a direct linkage exists between dumping and injury to an Australian industry. In this task, the Authority will have the benefit of additional comprehensive data since the preliminary finding stage, as well as the independent examination of all the evidence by its own staff which will have specialist qualifications, particularly in the economic field.

The Government did not accept Professor Gruen's recommendation that section 5 (9) of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act be repealed. Section 5 (9) of the Act precludes normal values being based on domestic sales which have been, for an extended period, at prices which do not permit recovery of costs incurred in the production and sale of the goods; in other words, where domestic sales in the exporting country are being consistently made at a loss. The Government considers that the repeal of this section would put Australia out of step with other countries that use GATT anti-dumping mechanisms to counter unfair trading practices. Canada, the EEC and the United States all have and use sections equivalent to section 5 (9) in their legislation.

The Government proposes, however, that aspects of the use of section 5 (9) will be tightened to ensure that wherever possible market based prices are used in normal value determinations and that the application of section 5 (9) is consistent with the rationale behind the new anti-dumping provisions. The Government expects that the Authority, when using section 5 (9), will use an appropriately wide time frame over which to weigh the prices and costs which are to be taken into account. In addition, when using section 5 (9), unless there are strong reasons to the contrary, a zero profit is to be assumed by the Authority.

Consistent with its intention that anti-dumping and countervailing measures do not become a substitute form of ongoing assistance, the Government has also decided that anti-dumping and countervailing measures will lapse after three years. This means that all measures in respect of a particular commodity will expire at the same three-year time limit, irrespective of the duration of measures relating to individual countries of export. The sunset provision will also apply to voluntary undertakings which have been given by exporters or governments of the exporting countries so as to resolve satisfactorily dumping or countervailing complaints. Such undertakings are normally price related and are offered so as to remove the material injury caused without the imposition of a duty. This will maintain consistency within the system. The sunset clause will not prevent industry from seeking to renew anti-dumping or countervailing action. It will mean, however, that injury and other aspects required to justify such action will be fully retested after three years of continuous application before anti-dumping or countervailing measures can be reimposed.

The Bill provides for the Anti-Dumping Authority to commence operation on a date to be fixed by proclamation. For preliminary findings made subsequent to the proclamation date, the Authority will finalise the inquiry and recommend appropriate action to the Minister. For inquiries in progress beyond the preliminary finding stage at the date of proclamation, the Authority will, if practicable, advise the Minister on all matters where the ACS recommends the imposition of anti-dumping or countervailing measures.

Part III of the Bill provides for the establishment and staffing of the Authority. The person who is to be appointed as the member of the Authority under clause 13 will be a person with economic and commercial skills and a knowledge of Australian industry. Clause 15 permits associate members to assist the member with specific inquiries, or for a specific period of time. There is also provision for the engagement of consultants with particular expertise. The Government concurs with Professor Gruen that the anti-dumping legislation should not contain a national interest provision.

The Government considers that such a provision would add to the uncertainty of the proceedings, would lead to administrative complexity and would increase the costs to participants. The range of issues which could be regarded as relevant in each case could no doubt be broadened and the way would be open for parties with indirect interests to claim a right to present views to the Authority and have them taken into account by the Minister in making his decision. Proceedings could thus become unnecessarily complex and protracted. While it is not defined in the Bill, the Minister will take national interest criteria into account in exercising his discretion in considering the reports of the Anti-Dumping Authority. One problem which adds complexity to considering dumping in a context of national interest is that many of the imports complained of come from countries where Australia already has a large trade surplus.

The issues of dumping have both economic and political significance and circumstances can change with disconcerting speed; hence the need to maintain or even enhance ministerial discretion. However, clause 23 of the Bill requires the Authority to advertise widely the fact that it is holding an inquiry into whether injurious dumping or subsidisation is occurring in a particular industry and invite submissions from the public. Subclause 7 (6) obliges the Authority to consider such submissions made in response to the invitation. The effect of these measures is to formalise for the first time the consideration of contributions from persons other than those directly interested in the dumping action, thus adding to the integrity and openness of the review process.

I might also mention that clause 9 of the Bill will permit the Government or the Authority to initiate anti-dumping inquiries where facts produced by interests indirectly concerned with a dumping issue can justify such action. Clause 29 of the Bill requires an annual report of the Authority to be tabled in the Parliament. The report will include coverage of the Authority's operations during the year, the operation and development of guidelines, the Authority's approach to its assessments and important issues that have arisen in relation to anti-dumping action generally. This will introduce more openness to the consideration of anti-dumping issues.

The Authority is being established for five years. However, a review of the effectiveness of the performance of the revised anti-dumping system will be undertaken after three years. I believe that the gathering together of specialists, under a person possessing particular expertise to give advice to the Government in an economically sensitive area like the imposition of dumping duties on exports from Australia's overseas trading partners, is an efficient use of scarce government resources, as well as being an effective means of ensuring the Government receives quality advice in the anti-dumping field. This approach to the administration of anti-dumping legislation is similar to the procedures used by other signatories to the GATT anti-dumping codes such as Canada and the United States.
Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill

The Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill establishes the role in the dumping mechanism to be played by the Australian Customs Service, which, as I mentioned earlier, will be to examine each dumping complaint and conduct preliminary investigations, including overseas inquiries. The results of these investigations will then form the basis of information upon which the Anti-Dumping Authority may commence its inquiry. The Bill contains specific provisions-in new section 269tb in particular-to make it clear that an application for imposition of dumping or countervailing duties; that is, a complaint, may be made by any person on behalf of the relevant Australian industry affected or likely to be affected by the dumping or subsidisation. For example, primary producers may lodge complaints in respect of injury being caused to processors, and employees or their representatives might initiate action when the industry is inhibited from doing so.

It will also be possible for complaints to be made before allegedly dumped or subsidised goods have arrived in Australia where there is adequate knowledge that imports of dumped or subsidised goods are to arrive in volumes which will cause injury to an Australian industry. The Bill also imposes, for the first time, statutory time limits within which the Customs Service must determine its investigations. Where a person complains that an act of injurious dumping or subsidisation has occurred or is likely to occur, the Bill provides in new section 269tc that the Customs Service will have a maximum of 70 days to determine whether the facts alleged in the application constitute sufficient prima facie evidence to warrant commencement of an investigation. If a prima facie case is established, the Customs Service then has a maximum of 180 days to make a preliminary finding as to whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed. It should be added that, in an attempt to be fair, and where there is urgency involved it is hoped that the maximum period will not be taken. It will be done in a much shorter period. But one has to be fair to everyone, particularly as people who feel that they have been disadvantaged by a decision have the right to apply to the Federal Court of Australia. We have to get it absolutely right.

Where such preliminary findings are positive, the Comptroller-General of Customs may decide to impose securities as provisional measures in respect of any dumping or countervailing duty that may become payable, and he then must refer the matter to the Anti-Dumping Authority within seven days for its independent examination and report to the Minister. It should also be noted that decisions by the Comptroller- General of Customs that no prima facie case has been established, or a preliminary finding that duties should not be imposed, are subject to merit review by the independent Anti-Dumping Authority.
Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill

Finally, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill amends the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 by inserting a statutory definition of `like goods'-a Gruen recommendation which adopts the definition of the term as applied in GATT-allowing for the publication of the normal value of goods in clauses 9 to 12. Further, clause 13 provides that duties and undertakings will be current only for a period of three years, adopting the Gruen recommendation that dumping measures and the like should remain current only for a limited period. An industry which has benefited from short term relief under this legislation must in future rejustify the necessity for continued relief.

The Bill finally makes various amendments to existing provisions to ensure that the relief under the Act is available only if dumping or subsidisation damages an Australian industry producing like goods to the goods that have been dumped; not Australian industry generally. It should be noted, however, that there has been no change to section 13 of the Act, relating to the retrospective application of dumping duty on imported goods following the publication of a dumping notice.

The Government is prepared, consistent with its international obligations, to make full use of that section to impose retrospective duties in critical circumstances to ensure that Australian industries are adequately protected against importers who knowingly cause material damage to an Australian industry through large scale imports of a product over a short period.

In conclusion, the Government believes that the new arrangements embodied in these three Bills will improve significantly Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing system and are consistent with Australia's rights and obligations under GATT and with the Government's industry policy. The system will provide a balanced approach to protecting Australian industry from clearly unfair trading practices, while at the same time ensuring that the measures do not constitute an unjustifiable impediment to international trade.
Financial Impact Statement

The Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill have no direct financial implications. It is estimated that the establishment of the Anti-Dumping Authority will involve expenditure of $1.12m in the first year of operation and $0.92m in subsequent years. These figures include the salary costs of the statutory appointee and for a secretariat of up to 16 persons. These resources are to come from appropriations made to elements of the portfolio of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I commend the Bills to the House and table each Bill's explanatory memorandum.
