DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1988-89[COGNATE BILLS:SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1988-89SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1988-89]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 April, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Peacock had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes:
(1) Australia's $86.77 billion net foreign debt at the end of December 1987 and its continuing balance of payments deficit on the current account which increased by $1185 million during March 1988;
(2) the Government's inappropriate response, which has been to increase taxation revenue collections to the highest levels in post-war Australia; and
(3) the urgent need to reduce public sector outlays as the major element of a Government policy response to Australia's current economic difficulties'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89. Before I call the honourable member for Adelaide, I remind the House that it is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with genuine pleasure and a distinct honour that I have the opportunity to present this, my first speech, to the Parliament of Australia. There is a good mood for change away from Labor. The electorate of Adelaide showed through the ballot box and the maturity of its vote that it was disenchanted with the Hawke Labor Government and voted on issues, not with cynicism, as the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) said in this House today. The result meant that the Adelaide electorate gave a stinging rebuff to the Hawke Government on timed telephone charging-yet another stupid, insensitive tax the Government would have inflicted upon a population already reeling and suffering under a tax burden that is strangling this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate demonstrated with its vote that it has had enough of Labor's policies, whether they be on gun lobbies, conservation, law and order or aged care. It was particularly upset by Labor's tax policies. The honourable member for Makin, the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), has publicly called this week for higher taxes, showing that Labor still has not heard the message from Adelaide and, indeed, Australia.

I am committed to reducing the levels of taxation. My opposition in the debate on the consumption tax is well documented. The pay as you earn taxpayer has been carrying the tax burden for too long. Under this Government some of our taxes, for example, on beer, petrol and commodity items, go up every six months. Yet the honourable member for Makin says, `We are not an overtaxed country'. Who is he kidding?

So the historic 6 February 1988 victory was not the aberration that the Hawke Government hoped it would be. That result was manifested and repeated in New South Wales, Brisbane, Victoria, Port Adelaide and Groom. I remember entering this chamber for my induction, with my maiden question still unasked, heralded by good natured derisive cheers and abuse regarding my tenure of the seat of Adelaide. It was with a bipartisan attitude that I remarked to my newer colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) that, as we took him to preferences in his electorate, his seat-the twelfth safest Labor seat in Australia-is now a marginal one.

It is one of the great facets of political life in Australia that on both sides of this House, if the electoral mood is right, there is an opportunity for men and women of Australia to enter politics; but they can just as easily be forced to leave if the electoral mood changes. It is the electorate and my hard-working supporters whom I now applaud-the hundreds of people from Walkerville to Windsor Gardens, from Broadview to Blair Athol, who combined with my family and personal friends to form the `Pratt for Adelaide' team. That blueprint of success has now been etched in the formula for future Liberal success. I stand by that recipe, which was personal hard work, grassroots campaigning-that sounds a familiar phrase-honesty and credibility.

Twenty-four hours after winning Adelaide, on the Sunday, and without any media attention, I started to honour my commitment to the electorate. I went back to what was once the Labor heartland to fulfil a promise that I would personally thank people for their support. I went to Kilburn, Valley View and Ingle Farm, to try to erase some of that `them and us' mentality, the political mentality that breeds hatred and dislike amongst Australians. My charter is to help all my constituents and I have begun this already with the support of my excellent staff, all from the inherited base of a burnt out office shredder, one biro and no constituent records.

I do not have political hatred coursing through my veins, but I share and endorse the view that I gleaned from the thousands of people I canvassed and who expressed their concerns. They could not really believe that in 1988 this lucky country, with a population the size of New York, could seemingly be in so much trouble financially, spiritually and politically. During my campaign and in this House I believe I have cut through a lot of the old conventions. I applaud some of the programs and reforms that the Hawke Government has implemented, such as the family assistance program for struggling families and the recent child support program to establish a national collection agency for child maintenance claims, and a lot of other legislation before the House.

Yet the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) attacks us as wimps and delivers some vitriol to my Leader because we as a coalition have not seen fit to support his loaded media ownership laws. This man who lauds and magnifies himself as the champion of the working class, ponces around looking like a partner for a Barbie doll. Even though his former Communications Minister wanted 43 per cent media reach, the Democrats 43 per cent, and some of the coalition 30 per cent, the denominator was 60 per cent, by the Government's own law. I admire Christopher Skase for his initiative and networking foresight, but he knew he would be over the 60 per cent audience reach. Of course, we all know about Bob and his millionaire mates and how he has a vested interest in this issue. By raising the media reach limit and not allowing more competition, his millionaire mate Alan Bond could then set about purchasing Adelaide's only independent television station, NWS9. Subsequently, the play would be on to admit Packer back in, perhaps along the eastern and southern seaboards or perhaps to link up the footprint from Darwin to Adelaide. I wonder what the Prime Minister's reaction to media ownership would be if John Elliott were the player.

Bob Hawke, the same man, launched his family allowance supplement in the western suburbs of Sydney, then hopped in a Bond helicopter to have a rich mates' luncheon at the Opera House. This same man was booed from the stage at the Gepps Cross abattoirs last month, and then, when a slaughterman tried to ask a question, he did not even have the common courtesy to answer the man. In touch with Australia? The only thing this man is in touch with is himself.

This Government, and the Opposition, must heed the wishes of the people. The people of Australia live in an overgoverned, overregulated environment. The people of Australia want jobs. They want to take home a decent net wage to a family in a house they can afford. They want a health system that works; an education program that prepares their children for the future; and they want a law and order system that works when their hard-earned material possessions or family are violated. Australians want two things for their future: those who are encouraged to be thrifty and save want to know that their savings will be there, safe, upon retirement, and they want an aged care program that is maintained with dignity for their parents and relatives, and also in the future for them. Australians do offer the compassion that allows the poor, the impoverished, the socially disadvantaged to be cared for. That must be an objective for us all-compassion and care not for those who bludge on the system but for those in genuine need.

As further testimony to my commitment to the electorate, I am leaving the pristine and austere offices located on the thirteenth floor of a city building and going back to the heartland of my people-ground floor, grassroots level-where I will be working with the people of Adelaide. My new address is No. 78 Main North Road, Prospect, bus stop 10. I share, not only on the opposite side of the road but on the opposite side politically, a location with Senator Chris Schacht. I am pleased to inform my constituents that I am signing a contract to buy a residential property in the electorate, which I hope further demonstrates my allegiance, commitment and long term plans. It will be interesting to see how Phil and Bruce, the writers of South Australia's Labor toe rag paper the Herald, choose to attack that personal commitment.

I come to this chamber in awe of what Canberra means and has meant to Australia. I come into this House of Representatives this afternoon, 28 April 1988, the year of our Bicentennial, as the first member to make his maiden speech in this 200th year of celebration. Since 1927, when this building was opened, 564 men and women in this House of Representatives have gone before me, delivering their maiden statements and policies to Australia. My maiden speech has added significance because it will probably be the last such speech in 61 years of tradition in this hallowed chamber. We are about to ring down the curtain on this Parliament House. Next week, in the presence of Her Majesty the Queen and with the eyes of Australia upon us, we will usher in a new era, new traditions, a new Australia, a new Parliament House. I think it is pertinent to reiterate the words of Prime Minister Bruce at the opening of this Parliament House on 9 May 1927:
May those who enter this open door govern with justice, reason, and equal favour to all. May they do so in humility and without self-interest. May they think and act nationally.

That is a profound statement we should all take heed of. Availing myself of the marvellous resources of the Parliamentary Library, I called up many maiden speeches, including that of Mr R. A. Parkill, the member for Warringah, New South Wales, in 1927. It is with particular interest that I reflect on the maiden speech of the former member for Port Adelaide and his most recent book I Want to Work. Like Mick Young, I left school at the age of 15 and joined the shearing sheds of the mid-north as a farmhand and wool presser, working from Bowillia to Bungaree. We fought the fires of Clare and battled the floods as they swept across our property. My wife and I punched holes through the limestone sheetrock to fence off the eucalypts, the hakeas and the melaleucas we had planted. We preserved the heritage that my parents had built. When the bank threatened to sell off some of my farm, I engineered and built a piggery to generate some extra cash flow-something that had been eroded through poor seasons and high interest rates.

A love of the theatre and the chance to create and produce one of South Australia's major Jubilee 150 events, On the Sheep's Back-a Jubilant Revue, initiated my moving to Adelaide. Subsequently, the Australia-Japan Foundation working out of NHK Tokyo made a television documentary called Under the Shade of a Coolibah Tree. I am disappointed that the Australia-Japan Foundation has been forced to scale down, when one considers the important trade links between our two countries. However, I learned on speaking to the eminent Tokyo producer, Shoicira Sasaki, that he will be in Australia in October making a sequel to that documentary. I am sure that is good news for the Australia-Japan Foundation as well as Actors Equity of Australia. I am sure I am one of the rare coalition members who go to Labor headquarters in Adelaide to renew their trade union membership. And to help further the Herald kitty-litter writers in Adelaide, my number is 66667.
My four years domicile in Adelaide saw me employed as the sporting and marketing manager of the Norwood Football Club-arguably one of the greats of Australian rules football.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member for Kingston. So, like Mick Young, I am fiercely proud of my working-class background. Along with my staff, I have transferred that dedication and experience into the electorate. So I come to my predecessor, Chris Hurford, now the member for New York, who for so long was ensconced in his cement bunker on the thirteenth floor in the building he personally commissioned. It was his maiden speech which particularly intrigued me. His final remarks in 1970 referred to a medical system that was inadequate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I look forward to comparing my party's equitable health policy with the hotchpotch being served up by the present Government in its attempt to patch its existing inequitable health scheme.

I am sure that in 1988 that statement must come back to haunt him. I have a great concern, which is reflected in my electorate, that this Government has more interest in defending the failing institution that is Medicare than protecting the people it is designed to serve. Such claims that infer that this Government inherited two million people who were too poor to be insured are unsubstantiated and ignore the fact that many of these people simply decided that they were too healthy or wealthy to insure themselves.

Medicare in Australia is in a complete and utter shambles, the waiting list keeps growing and there is a personal cost to many Australians who trusted this Government's promises and are now having to borrow money to pay for operations to relieve them from pain and suffering. Yet the Government and the Minister are too proud, too conceited, to give ground and concede that the system is not working. Medicare, the master, has outgrown the purpose it was designed to serve. The working class, the poor and the disadvantaged are not getting the health care to which they are entitled. There should be tax incentives for middle class and professional wage earners to insure their health and, by that action, more public hospital places for the needy should be created.

The private and public hospitals in my electorate, including the Royal Adelaide Hospital, the Memorial Hospital, the Adelaide Children's Hospital, Calvary Hospital and the North-Eastern Community Hospital, to name several, amplify the concern that is repeated around Australia: our health system is not working. The Government asks us to believe that Medicare is simple, equitable and beneficial. Medicare, this complex $5.2 billion monster, is not achieving its stated objective, which is to provide affordable and quality health care.

This high taxing Government at first taxed us at one per cent of our gross income, then at 1.25 per cent, to earn a revenue of about $2.1 billion a year-less than half of the $5.2 billion that Medicare costs-and the balance must be collected from the well exploited Hawke sales tax that all Australians must pay. Our costs are escalating and our health benefits are reducing. It does not stop there. If we are lucky enough to get a hospital bed, and have any money left from Australia's monstrous institution, Medicare, this Government wants to inflict on Australia's frail aged population a loss of dignity, a fear, and uncertainty and insecurity amongst 70,000 residents of its nursing homes. There used to be extensive care; now there is classification by category. There used to be rehabilitation; now there are outcome standards.

During the by-election campaign I visited several of the excellent aged care facilities in my electorate, including the Helping Hand Centre, Bartonvale Village, the Walkerville Nursing Home, Elderly Citizens Homes of South Australia and Southern Cross Homes. I have since been back to those facilities and had contact with their administrators, including those at the Voluntary Care Association of South Australia, and was the only Federal member of Parliament representing the Liberal Party of Australia who took the time to attend the aged care rally in Victoria Square on 8 April.

I had the opportunity to sit through a debate last week, on 13 April, and later read Hansard at page 461, which recorded the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) replying to a question put to him by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). He spent time talking about unscrupulous operators and what the Opposition did eight years ago. There was some amazing rhetoric; in fact, seven times he repeated the words `striking fear and terror amongst the aged and their relatives'-words usually reserved for a hijack. And that is what it is: this Government is attempting to hijack the nursing home hours in Australia. It affects the residents and their relatives, as well as the dedicated nursing staff and administrators, and that includes the 20,000 people over the age of 60 in the electorate of Adelaide. The fact that our ageing population was dovetailed with the war veterans, war widows and Vietnam veterans as I stood at the dawn ceremony at the Prospect Returned Services League on Monday is further evidence that the dignity of Australia's ageing population must be preserved.

One of my priorities is to join with all concerned on both sides of this House to fight the Government which is trying to strip the quality and standard of care from the nursing homes. The nursing home industry says 27 hours per week, the Government says 17 hours, which it has since amended to 18 hours. The South Australian average is now 21 hours, and category 5 is rated at 10 hours. We now rate our compassion.

Is it not ironic that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care represents the seat of Jagajaga? It reminds me of the maximum security prison, Jika Jika, and includes Yatala Labour Prison. Let us compare the care and services of our aged as opposed to those in the prison system. The Department of Correctional Services indicates that it costs taxpayers $48,000 a year to maintain and keep a female prisoner. Yet, on average, government funding of nursing homes contributes only $20,000 a year per female patient. This is topped up with the patient's own hard earned pension contributions and the magnificent volunteer and family donations. I say to the Minister: Is he putting criminals' benefits above the welfare and care of Australia's aged population? Their honest and hard-working contribution to this country should be recognised with dignity and compassion, not reduced. I support the Correctional Services Department in Adelaide: it should be given tougher and stronger control. How about taking away some of the cushy prisoner benefits? What a joke-prisoners strike and riot for better conditions. It is Mother's Day this weekend. Where is the Minister's compassion? Is it with the criminals of society or with his mother, or my mother, or a million other Australian mothers?

I referred to Australia's population of 16 million. Those in our young emerging work force want a job without a greedy union boss getting in their way. They want to take home a decent wage in a car they can afford, to a family in a house that they can afford to pay off. Should they require medical help, they want the security that the Adelaide Children's Hospital or the Royal Adelaide Hospital can provide. After working hard for 30 years and being encouraged to save for their future, they do not need a greedy government to tax their superannuation. Both the Government and the Opposition-Federal and State politicians-must be aware that this is a requirement of us all, now, and not just before an election.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have trodden the boards on a few stages in my life and, as I referred to Prime Minister Bruce in May 1927 and 61 years later, may I leave this House with a reflection on its past, its people, and its future:
So just a word in closing
And forgive this clumsy rhyme
For an old and noble structure
That has bravely served its time.
It has echoed the exchanges
When the members interject
By the Brindabella Ranges
Let us treat it with respect.
Though we are going from its portals
To some luxury and space
We'll remember its immortals
As we reach that other place.
So let us toast Australia's future
With our bicentennial cup,
For here the curtain's coming down
And there it's going up.
And though the years will be challenging
We'll try to keep our nerve
For Australia that we honour,
And the people that we serve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to congratulate the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt), who has just completed his maiden speech. My advice to him is that he should keep in touch, otherwise he will find that after the next election he will not be a member of parliament. If that were the case, the people might say of him that he was mostly in touch with himself. I support Supply Bill (No. 1), 1988-89, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89. In particular I will address a couple of issues of real concern to me. In this Parliament I have already called for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to sack his shadow spokesman on social security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I repeat that appeal, because the honourable member for Bradfield has a fixation about the western suburbs in general and Mount Druitt in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat an offer that was made in the newspapers today: I am quite happy to buy the honourable member for Bradfield a Gregory's directory so that he can see where Mount Druitt is and recognise that it is not in Campbelltown, some 40 kilometres away. I recall that the honourable member for Adelaide fleetingly referred to the launching of a most important package-that is, cash for working parents-in my electorate. The honourable member for Bradfield, the silvertail from the North Shore, the shadow Minister for social security, said in this House that that scheme was launched at Campbelltown. That is like saying that the honourable member for Bradfield lives not at Pymble but at Palm Beach. I am sure that the people who live at Palm Beach would be offended to hear the honourable member for Bradfield claiming to reside there. Not content with that faux pas, which, I must say, went largely unnoticed, the honourable member for Bradfield on 26 April, in speaking on the Social Security Amendment Bill, referred to the western suburbs of Sydney as follows:

A few months ago, in one of my visits to that part of Sydney I was taken to see a caravan park. I must have seen at least 50 to 60 caravans. The occupants were not people who were just coming to the western suburbs of Sydney for a holiday. One does not generally go to places like Mount Druitt and Green Valley for a holiday.
That is very deprecating. He further said:
If one does, one does not stay in a caravan.

He went on to say that the caravan park was in Mount Druitt. However, in a personal explanation in this House the following day the honourable member for Bradfield, in reference to the Daily Telegraph article said:
That is a total travesty of what in fact was said. The details are in Hansard. I was referring specifically to one caravan park in the Mount Druitt area.

Of course, Opposition members like to bag the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), but he is frequently in my electorate. Even he knows that there is no caravan park in Mount Druitt; we do not have a caravan park. The caravan park to which the honourable member for Bradfield is referring is some 11 kilometres away. Perhaps the honourable member is improving. In one case, he made a mistake of 40 kilometres, and now he is down to 11 kilometres.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you given him a street directory yet?

—As the interjection of the honourable member for Dobell reminds me, I have offered to give him a street directory. The caravan park in question is located at Prospect; it is a locality in its own right. The national headquarters for Sharp are very close to the caravan park. There are Housing Commission homes at Prospect and there is private development in that area. The people at Prospect are proud to identify themselves as living there in the Blacktown City Council area. Why does the honourable member for Bradfield have this fixation on the western suburbs and on Mount Druitt? The shadow spokesman is supposed to be an enlightened Liberal telling the people of the western suburbs what a Federal Liberal government would do for them. In reality, all he is is the dead hand of liberalism, a typical silvertail from the North Shore who cannot even get his localities right. I object to his comparing the situation of people living in the western suburbs, Mount Druitt or Prospect to that of people in Soweto.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, I do not think that anyone who has watched television pictures coming out of South Africa that show Soweto-and there are precious few of them-can have anything but sympathy for them. Why does the honourable member introduce this racist argument and suggest that people in the western suburbs live like blacks in the slums of Soweto? That is what he is suggesting. He is demeaning every person who lives in the western suburbs. I object to that on my own behalf, because I am proud to live in Mount Druitt, where I was brought up. I also object on behalf of my constituents, who are heartily sick and tired of this constant barrage from the Liberal Party of Australia about the western suburbs and, in particular, the constant barrage from the front bench shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bradfield, who lives on the North Shore. In fact, he will not even put his address on the North Shore in any currently available document. His address in Who's Who is listed as `Parliament House, Canberra'.

I also want to dwell on some of the changes that the New South Wales Government is implementing in the western suburbs of Sydney. As I have said before, my colleague the honourable member for Riverstone in the State Parliament deserves great kudos for leading the campaign for a senior high school in the western suburbs. It is to the eternal credit of the Liberal Party that it was prepared, while in opposition, to accept the principle of a senior high school. What we were fighting for then-and still are-are some pilot senior high schools in the western suburbs and perhaps in other areas such as the Illawarra and Newcastle. We want feeder schools going to year 10 and a senior high school taking years 11 and 12.

What has the Minister for Education in New South Wales, Dr Metherell, done? He told the people of New South Wales, particularly those in the western suburbs, that the Liberal Party supported the idea of a senior high school. What he did not tell them was that he was not intending to change any of the comprehensive high schools. He did not intend to make them feeder high schools but was going to allow them to continue. Therefore, in the midst of six high schools all going to years 11 and 12, a senior high school that deals only with years 11 and 12 will be set up.

Of course, there will then have to be some selection criteria. So the best students will then go on to the senior high school and the not so bright students will stay on at the comprehensive high schools, and the morale of those high schools will be absolutely destroyed. Worse still, instead of trying to change the culture in the western suburbs, the Illawarra and Newcastle, these elite institutions will be created. This proposal will not encourage extra participation or children to reach their full potential.

I notice the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) in the chamber. Rural Australia suffers as much as some of the regional areas. What has he done about that? Does he propose a cluster system, as the Australian Labor Party always intended, to try to address some of the problems that exist in years 11 and 12 in the towns and cities in rural New South Wales? I do not know; he has not mentioned it. I gave Dr Metherell credit-and I stand by it-that before the campaign the Liberal Party adopted the principle of senior high schools. It is to the shame of the Labor Party that it never did anything about it as a government, although I have already acknowledged the role of my colleague the State member for Riverstone. However, the State Minister for Education has now given us the worst of all possible worlds, and I appeal to him to reconsider what he has done.

I also appeal to him to reconsider the proposed locations of schools. The idea of a senior high school was to have it act as a magnet and attraction, to change peer pressure and parental attitudes and to encourage students to stay on to years 11 and 12. Thus, the senior high schools need to be established in areas that will benefit most. Like any other region, the western region of Sydney has variations. Therefore, the senior high schools should not be placed, as the New South Wales Government is considering placing them, in areas where the rate of participation in years 11 and 12 is good.

I also want to refer briefly to the decision of the State Minister for Education in relation to the Higher School Certificate. Nothing has saddened me more than to see some of my high school students featured on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald. They are absolutely distraught that, in the middle of their last year of study at a high school-year 12-the Minister has changed the rules. It would be different if he had said they would be changed next year, but he said that they had been changed for students studying in 1988. He has said to the students, `You will not be getting your aggregate marks; what you have done will be a folly'. I think that is an absolute tragedy. As I have said in this House, the same sort of thing could not be done to business; people in business must be given plenty of warning. Students in my electorate have gone to year 12 under the existing rule, selected courses, and yet a change is being made in the middle of their courses. It affects not only my electorate but every Federal electorate in New South Wales. Dr Metherell ought to be absolutely ashamed of himself.

Finally, I want to refer to the Chifley University College. When a new government is elected we must respect the fact that the people have voted it in, and I certainly respect that. Often changes are introduced with which one has sympathy or which one welcomes. A new government is entitled to make changes. However, two aspects of Dr Metherell's handling of the issue of the western suburbs university cause me great concern. First, there is the pettifogging changing of the name. Nothing could have distinguished the new Minister for Education as being small-minded more than his decision to change the name of Chifley University College.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Absolutely. As the member for Chifley I share with the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), a special responsibility in relation to the outstanding contribution that was made to this nation by former Prime Minister Chifley. I happily acknowledge that. I do not think it would make any difference if the university had been named after, say, Curtin or Scullin. If the Liberals named a university the Menzies University College, I believe we would be honour bound to accept that. To suggest that the only thing Chifley ever did was ride through on a steam train actually displays Dr Metherell's total lack of understanding of history and of the original boundaries of the Macquarie electorate that Chifley was so proud to represent. So in this case Dr Metherell is being very petty. However, the State Government has publicly stated that the matter of the Chifley University College is being deferred until the production of a White Paper on higher education. While that may be disappointing for me, I think he is entitled to examine his options. But what are his options? What are the options of the Liberal Party in New South Wales? I note that we do not have one Federal Liberal Party member from New South Wales in the House at the moment.
—Hey?

—I beg your pardon; the honourable member is very interested in tertiary education. I conclude by making the point that Dr Metherell must come clean. He has obviously deferred it because he has something in mind. What are his plans? I ask him to put them on the table so that we can examine them. Let us be constructive; let us see whether we agree with them and whether they are in the best interests of students in the western suburbs of Sydney. He should come clean and tell us his plans and not try to hoodwink the people of the western suburbs of Sydney in general and the people in my electorate of Chifley in particular who are passionately committed to this college.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a very serious issue of what appears to be a breach of the law in this country regarding the illegal taping of conversations by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). However, before going into that it is worth recalling what occurred with the recent Mike Willesee case that also dealt with a similar matter. On 15 January 1986, a researcher on the Mike Willesee Channel 9 program, Jacqui Donaldson, went along with a freelance sound recordist, Mr Terry Kelly, to talent scouts offices in York Street, Sydney. There they set up an expose-type interview with the proprietor of Talent Scouts Acting and Model Agency, Mr David Miller. An interview was recorded with Mr Miller without either his knowledge or permission. A story on the agency was shown on Channel 9 during the Willesee program on 4 February 1986 which used part of this secretly recorded interview. Following this, Mr Miller launched prosecutions under the New South Wales Listening Devices Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter came before Justice Findlay of the Supreme Court who handed down his decisions earlier this month. Miss Jacqui Donaldson was convicted under the Listening Devices Act for secretly taping a private conversation and fined $500. The Trans Media Production Co., of which Mike Willesee is a director, was found guilty of causing the illegal tape to be made, of possessing and broadcasting it and was fined $25,000. In his judgment, Justice Findlay said:
If the means are illegal then they are not justifiable by the ends . . . The invasion of privacy . . . is not excused because it was done in the cause of investigative journalism.

It is against the background of that case that I wish to draw the attention of the House to the following matter. I recently received a letter from Mr Ian Cole, the Station Manager at 2WEB, the radio station in Bourke, which is a town in my electorate. The letter stated:
Dear Michael,
I am writing to follow up the ABC's illegal taping of conversations for broadcast; a matter I discussed with you earlier this year.

At approximately 9.30 a.m. on Thursday, 3rd December last, Jason Smith, a reporter from the ABC's studio rang me to comment on a matter which at that time was causing serious racial tension in Bourke. I declined, saying that I was not qualified to comment and referred him to someone who was. I politely told him as much as I knew of the matter, but said I did not want to officially comment. The receptionist at the Orana Community College also received a call and gave a similar reply.

During both conversations Jason Smith did not identify himself as an ABC reporter, he did not say which programme he represented; he did not say he was taping the conversation, and there was no warning signal to indicate the conservation was being taped.
Both conversations were taped and went to air on national radio on the ``Australia today'' (?) programme after 11.30 a.m. on the same today.
I am not embarrassed about any of my comments-but this approach is highly illegal, dishonest and rude!!

I have since contacted the ABC, including the Executive Producer of ``Australia today'' Ian McNamara, to complain about the incident and to ask for an apology. However the ABC's response has been very sarcastic and cynical. Mr McNamara says I should always expect to be taped whenever talking to anyone from the ABC. He has refused to apologise and has added insult to injury by saying the public is stupid to expect to be treated any other way.

As you know, I work for radio station 2WEB. Like all other community and commercial radio stations in Australia, we are bound by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunals ``Radio Program Standards'' and to Federal Laws and Telecom requirements which forbid illegal taping and broadcasting of telephone conversations.
Section 7 of the Tribunals Radio Standards say:
``A licensee must not transmit the words of an identifiable person unless:
(a) That person has been informed in advance that the words may be transmitted; or
(b) in the case of words which have been recorded without the knowledge of the person, that person has subsequently, but prior to the transmission, indicated consent to the transmission of the words.

(Note: Licensees are referred to the requirements of Telecom Australia, in particular the requirements that when a telephone conversation is recorded both parties must know that the conversation without the use of a recorder-connector which provides a suitable warning signal to both parties is illegal).''
I realise that the ABC is not regulated by the A.B.T. but should have some sort of code of behaviour pertaining to taped telephone conversations.
As my local Federal Member I would appreciate you following up this complaint and specifically, getting the ABC to answer the following questions:
1. Is the ABC free to operate outside the laws relating to the recording of telephone conversations?
2. Should Australian citizens expect to be recorded without warning when speaking to the ABC?
3. Will the ABC continue to get away with this sort of behaviour?
4. Can I withdraw my 8 cents per day?
Please let me know if you can get any answers-as I only came up with rude replies to my questions.
Yours sincerely,
Ian Cole
Station Manager

I believe that that is a very serious letter. I take what he says in the letter very seriously as he has a reputation as a decent and honest person who is highly regarded as one of the leading citizens in the Bourke community. Since receiving this correspondence, I have spoken to Ian Cole, who is considerably upset about the whole incident and in particular the manner in which the ABC has behaved. He reiterated the story as told in the letter and filled me in on some other detail. Apparently after the ABC reporter spoke to Ian Cole he rang the receptionist at the Orana Community College in an attempt to speak to the principal there about this matter. At the time of the call the principal was out so the receptionist, Nerida Stevens, informed the ABC person of that. She did not realise she was being taped. Ian Cole told me that a sergeant at the Bourke police station, Allen Bassett, was also rung by this ABC reporter and did not realise he was being taped until half-way through the interview. When Ian Cole was by chance listening to the ABC radio later in the morning he was amazed to hear his voice coming over the airwaves. He says that they also played the interview with the Orana Community College receptionist, including her hanging-up the phone, and did it in such a way as to make it appear that there was a cover-up and that the principle was avoiding speaking to the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Illegally.

—Yes. The whole story was a beat-up trying to make Bourke look like a racist town. When Ian Cole rang the ABC to protest about this he says that it was not at all helpful to him in registering his complaint. In fact, it was not only rude but it refused to acknowledge it had done anything wrong. I find the behaviour and attitude of the ABC in this whole matter quite extraordinary. What has been done is clearly wrong. The behaviour of the ABC staff is unethical, unprofessional and certainly appears to have breached the law. I have written to the Director of Public Prosecutions asking him to consider this matter and have also forwarded a copy of Ian Cole's letter to the Attorney-General. I hope these complaints will be fully investigated and, where appropriate, acted upon. The privacy considerations of our citizens deserve more than the way in which the ABC has treated them in Bourke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to make some remarks about the importance of our effort in the Antarctic. I do so with a background of having been privileged earlier this year to have been one of two members of parliament who sailed to two Australian bases, Mawson and Davis. My parliamentary colleague travelling with me was the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson). I think it would be appropriate for me to say that each of us was enormously impressed both by the work that was being conducted at the bases and by the morale of both those who were serving as summer expeditioners and those who were planning to stay on as winter expeditioners over the long Antarctic winter.
—The Icebird is a good ship.
—The Icebird is certainly a good ship. I am sure that all those who have had the experience of going with that vessel to Antarctica will agree with remarks I am making.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a couple of points arising out of that visit. For the interest of Parliament I want to flag two issues of principal concern that will need to be addressed in the near future. The first is the question of mining. On the not so distant horizon is the adoption of the mining convention whose formulation many nations have been working towards. It would be reasonable to expect that within a year or less Australia will be put in the position of either ratifying or rejecting proposals that are being developed towards a minerals convention. It is important in terms of the development of a minerals convention to ensure that the minimum possible disruption to the very fragile Antarctic environment is countenanced. I am sure that that is the view of the Australian Government delegations that attend the Antarctic Treaty convention meetings. Those of us who are concerned with the future of Antarctica should bear this in mind over the months to come. It is an issue which will press in upon us very quickly and we must be prepared to respond quickly in this Parliament to ensure that the concern which I am sure we all share is made clear internationally and that that very important and paramount consideration is borne in mind.

The second area of concern, an area which has not yet been the subject of even draft or proposed international regulatory measures, is the prospect of international tourism. The Antarctic continent is one of great beauty. It is staggeringly beautiful. When one sets foot on it one is surprised simply by the scale and the magnitude of the place and then dazzled by the way in which Antarctica dominates one's thinking for the time one is there. It is an experience that I would be the last to deny my fellow Australians, but any thinking about the possibility of tourism needs to be approached with the greatest of caution. The ice-free regions of Antarctica, which would be most subject to the pressure of tourism, are a very small part of the total Antarctic land mass. They contain a very fragile biological environment. Part of that environment is the mosses and lichens, which can be destroyed simply by a footfall. There are also large colonies of penguins, seals and other marine life on that small stretch of coastline. In that environment man is a new and potentially destructive element. For that reason I think it is appropriate, if we are looking at the possible development of tourism, to ensure that tourism is not impactive, that we restrict tourism as far as possible to ship-based tourism and do not permit ourselves to move down the path of building onshore facilities to look after tourist arrivals in Antarctica.

It may seem a little premature to be raising this issue, but in the course of my discussions aboard the Icebird and subsequently it has been made very plain to me that there are real commercial pressures already in existence leading towards the development and exploitation of Antarctica as a tourist destination. Very significant financial figures within Australia and overseas have commissioned feasibility studies into both ship-based tourism and also tourism based on air services and the possible construction of international hotel facilities in the Antarctic area. Given that that interest has already been expressed, and given that significant commercial operators have flagged their real interest in that possibility, it is important that we think now about an appropriate response to ensure that that very fragile environment is not destroyed or hurt by unregulated or uncontrolled tourist activities.

In making these remarks, I must also draw attention to the fact that Tasmania has a particular interest in Antarctic-related activity and development. The location of the Antarctic Division in Hobart is very important economically for the State and, through various spin-offs, including the provisioning of the ships that sail to the Antarctic regions, both from Australia and from other nations such as France, it causes us to have a very significant economic interest in the future of Antarctic development. I have been very much at the forefront in trying to make sure that we maximise the possible benefits to our State from these developments. For example, I am delighted to be able to praise the Australian Government on its decision to build in Australia a replacement vessel for the Nella Dan, which sank so unfortunately during the last Antarctic season. In my opinion, there are opportunities which we need to seize and we need to be vigorous in taking advantage of them.

One proposal which is now under review by the Australian Government is a proposal for an Antech centre whereby spin-off industries taking advantage of a potential market in the Antarctic might be developed in Tasmania. About two years ago the Australian Government commissioned a report on this matter. It was commissioned and completed by consultants working on a committee under the chairmanship of Mr Neil Batt, the present Leader of the Tasmanian Opposition and Labor leader in Tasmania. The report was announced by me on behalf of the Federal Government in mid-1987 and since then I have been seeking to have the report implemented. I have done so in a number of ways. I understand from the public announcements that have been made on this issue that the matter has already been before Cabinet and further investigations are proceeding to see whether or not the consultant's report is economically viable.

It is against that background that I raise one particular concern I have relating to what I see as rather crude opportunist politicking by a colleague senator from Tasmania, Senator Paul Calvert. Late last week in the Senate, Senator Calvert asked a question of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) relating to the Antech proposal and then seriously distorted the answer Senator Button gave. That was very unfortunate. He had asked Senator Button what had been the course of the representations he had had and what action was being taken in relation to the Antech report. Senator Button quite naturally said that he was not completely aware of the details and that he would give a detailed answer in due course. Immediately following that, Senator Calvert saw fit to put out a Press release, which stated:

Senator Button advised that he was unaware of the report or its progress and in response to further questioning from Senator Calvert, said he was unaware also of any representations from Denison Labor MHR Duncan Kerr, about the matter.

Some cynical people might jump to the conclusion that Senator Calvert had told a deliberate lie in regard to the matter, but I think the simpler conclusion is that he was unable to recall, when he put out the Press release an hour or so after he asked the question in the Senate, whether he had asked one or two questions. In fact, he had asked only one question; there was no supplementary question. He entirely distorted the answer given by the Minister. Subsequently, the Minister cleared the matter up. He said:

. . . I have received representations from the honourable member for Denison, Mr Duncan Kerr, in this matter and he certainly has played a key role in the Government's consideration of Antech. The matter has received a continuing consideration by the Government, including at Cabinet level, where preliminary decisions were made about this issue in February.

I am delighted that the Opposition has now taken a very belated interest in this matter. I would welcome a constructive input on this matter by Senator Calvert and by the Liberal Party's science spokesman, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith). Unfortunately, so far we have seen only cheap political point scoring, which does no credit to those involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to comment briefly on Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89. I will try to be briefer in these comments than I was in my question at Question Time today. It seems to me, however, that if the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other Ministers can take 20 minutes to answer a question we should be able to take 20 minutes to ask one.

SPEECH.PARA: I comment on these Supply Bills in the context of the present very difficult economic circumstances in Australia. As the Treasurer has conceded, quite openly, particularly in response to the release of the March balance of payments figures, the Australian economy is overheating quite dramatically. This is confirmed not only by our import data but also by recent national accounts data. It is overheating at a time when our balance of payments a couple of more reasonable months in the early part of the year-is still deteriorating quite significantly. If we look at the national accounts for the December quarter, we can see that the balance of payments, excluding the very advantageous movement in commodity prices, actually deteriorated in real terms. In recent months we have seen some of that deterioration show up in the monthly nominal balance of payments figures as well.

Traditionally in Australia we have run into very much of a crunch situation in precisely these sorts of circumstances, where the economy overheats and pulls up imports, and those higher imports are then sustained as world activity flattens and as commodity prices decline. Essentially, that is the situation we are moving into at present. World activity is flattening out, commodity prices will fall in the latter half of this year and into early next year and, the way our economy is bubbling along, we will sustain our import demand. A crunch is now almost inevitable. The Treasurer, amazingly, seems quite complacent about this prospect. If I were in his shoes I do not think I would sleep at night, because his track record in this regard is not a very good one. On each occasion where this has happened we have had the traditional Australian crunch. We have had an exchange rate crisis, and we are heading for another one unless the Treasurer makes some very significant adjustments to policy in the near term.

But if we look at what he has said on policy in recent days we realise that it is a cause for great concern. It should be, at least to every member of this House. He has told us that he will not tighten monetary policy. Apparently, he does not follow too closely what the Reserve Bank of Australia has done. The Reserve Bank has actually tightened it a little in the past week or so. But the Treasurer says he is not interested in tightening monetary policy and putting up interest rates. He has also made some statements in recent days about how he is intent on holding down our currency. He put it in terms of supporting the Reserve Bank in its intervention in the foreign exchange market. It is interesting that a man who claims to have floated the currency and to willingly accept the judgment of international currency markets is heavily intervening, through the Reserve Bank, to hold our currency down. The Reserve Bank probably has spent something over $1 billion so far in April in the spot market alone. It has done some very heavy forward market intervention as well.

But that is not enough for the Treasurer. He is also running around the country promising to raise living standards. He is supporting wage deals that will give wage outcomes well in excess of those of our trading partners. How can he do this in the current circumstances? Is he totally irresponsible, or does he have something up his sleeve? I do not think he does. In effect, what he has done is put a lot of weight on the forthcoming Premiers Conference and the forthcoming mini-Budget. If he does not deliver in tough economic decisions on those occasions, and exercise significant expenditure restraint, both on the States and on his own account, the system, in my view, will come unstuck. We will head fast down the road to the traditional Australian crunch.

He would have us believe that this record suggests that he has been very successful in restraining expenditure. But he tends to refer just to the last couple of years, those years for which the numbers show some decline in aggregate Budget outlays in real terms. He forgets of course, to mention that in his first three years in government he went on a spending spree. In fact, over his entire period in government, Budget outlays have increased by about 60 per cent, which is about a 20 per cent cumulative increase in real terms. In some of the earlier years the increases in his expenditure were 6 to 7 per cent or more in real terms.

The Treasurer therefore tends to focus on the expenditure restraint he has achieved in the last couple of years. But he has exaggerated that as well. He makes his figures look better than they are. For example, he has included $1 billion worth of asset sales as expenditure restraint. He has imparted greater restraint on the States than he has on his own expenditure. While he has received State expenditure, that is, expenditure from the Commonwealth on the States, in real terms, he has not cut his own expenditure in real terms. He has also focused his cuts on capital rather than on recurrent expenditure. As a result we are probably heading for a very significant problem in this country, judging by the extent to which we have cut back capital expenditure and eroded some basic infrastructure, all in the name of protecting a significant level of recurrent expenditure.

He has also skewed recurrent expenditure in favour of the big ticket items. In particular, items such as education, health, social security and welfare and public administration are all going up quite significantly in real terms this year. So he has been very misleading in trying to paint a picture of overall expenditure restraint. The fact is that he has not delivered very much expenditure restraint at all.

He has now put all his eggs in one basket. He has to go into the forthcoming Premiers Conference and Loan Council meetings and the mini-Budget with a very genuine and desperate need to cut expenditure. Yet he does not seem to understand the significance of the task he has left for himself.

Instead the Treasurer prefers in this House and in numerous places all over the country to spend his time bucketing us for daring to suggest that there should be fairly significant expenditure restraint in present circumstances. It is he who should be worried about that, given the fact that he is not prepared to adjust any of the other areas of policy and given that he has now put all his weight on fiscal policy. He should not in any way be bucketing us for the orders of magnitude we have talked about; he will have to deliver much more expenditure restraint or his policy stance will come unstuck. Not only has the Treasurer bucketed us but also, in a recent interview on the Channel 9 Sunday program, he conceded, in the light of the New South Wales election results in particular and also in the light of a series of electoral mishaps from his point of view-I guess he would call them unintended consequences-that he might now have to increase welfare and social security spending. If he is going to sustain those big ticket items he has no realistic understanding of the magnitude of the expenditure restraint task that is in front of him.
How can he be so complacent? I guess the reason is that he has plenty of revenue. He intends to do quite a lot of spending in the next few months or years.

If we look at some realistic estimates of where the Australian economy is going in the next 12 months and translate those into Budget revenue figures we see that the Treasurer can start the 1988-89 Budget process with a $3 billion to $3 1/2 billion Budget surplus on a no policy change basis. That is plenty of revenue. If his outcome for this year is, say, a $1 billion or $1 1/2 billion surplus he has $1 1/2 billion to $2 1/2 billion in his back pocket which he can spend in the forthcoming mini-Budget. But do not get me wrong; he will be very pious about this. He will go around talking about expenditure restraint. He will claim credit for the greatest restraint since Artie Fadden, or whatever example he likes to use, but he will not deliver the sort of expenditure restraint that is required to get the job done in the present circumstances.

He is going to talk tough, of course. He is going to point to overall numbers that in one way or another broadly support his case, but he will not actually significantly cut expenditure. And he cannot. If one looks around this House at any time during the day one sees various groups that have already put in their claim for expenditure in particular areas. The Treasurer will have to face up to the reality that, while he might have had a reasonable political power base, due to the strength in New South Wales of the right wing of the Party, at the time of the last Budget, he no longer has that political power base in present circumstances. So he will now have to buy his way through this process. He will have to buy off the left wing, the Centre Left and others with increases in various areas of expenditure that they feel are important. So the $2 billion that he now has in his back pocket will have to be pulled out on several and various occasions in the next few weeks in order to placate his mates.

In these times I guess we ought to ask honourable members to contemplate the economic consequences of having waited five or six months on Barrie Unsworth. I suggest to the House that that will prove very expensive. The Treasurer should have taken the opportunity provided by the stock market crash to initiate, in political terms, a very significant quickening of the pace of macro- and micro-policy adjustment. He should have moved decisively to a mini-Budget, but he was not prepared to put his mate Barrie at risk. So he did virtually nothing. And he has seen his political power base eroded over the last five or six months. He has also seen economic circumstances start to move against him. One can imagine that he will be Mr Sweaty Palms for the next few months when it comes to dealing with some of these issues. The magnitude of the policy adjustment that he has now set himself is significantly beyond what his political power base will allow him to achieve.

I return to what I started: I urge the House to remember the sorts of economic crunch situations we have experienced in the past. As economic circumstances become more difficult internationally this year, as commodity prices taper off, as we sustain through an overheated economy a more rapid growth of imports, look for the double whammy that will come on the balance of payments and just watch Mr Sweaty Palms.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The Schedule, page 17, Division 310, omit subparagraph (b) (i) of the statement of purpose set out in the Division, substitute the following subparagraph:
`(i) that the Minister for Finance is satisfied is expenditure that is urgently required and:

(a) was unforeseen until after the last day on which it was practicable to include appropriation for that expenditure in the Bill for this Act before the introduction of that Bill into the House of Representatives; or
(b) was erroneously omitted from, or understated in, the Bill for this Act; and'.

This statement applies to amendments to this Bill, the Supply Bill (No. 2) and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. The amendments widen the criteria for the use of the Advances to the Minister for Finance (AMF) and the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. They are necessary to overcome restrictions on the use of the Advances brought to notice by a recent legal opinion on the interpretation of the urgent and unforeseen criteria which must be met before an issue can be made from the contingency Advances. The Advances are provisions authorised by the annual Appropriation and Supply Acts and are necessary for the smooth running of government because they provide flexibility, particularly for urgent and unforeseen expenditures.

The current wording was introduced into Appropriation Acts on the recommendation of the 1979 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Advance to the Minister for Finance. However, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, during the course of its most recent inquiry into the Advance to the Minister for Finance, has obtained legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department that indicates that, where due to clerical error or inadvertence only, an amount for expenditure has been omitted from an Appropriation Bill, that amount cannot be regarded as unforeseen and therefore should not be funded from the AMF. It has been assumed by successive governments that the criteria for the use of the Advances do not preclude a situation where expenditure was foreseen, but through clerical error or inadvertence no provision was made in the relevant Supply or Appropriation Act. The AMF and the subsequent Advances to the President and Speaker have been administered on this basis prior to and after the introduction of the present wording.

In order to overcome the restriction on the use of the Advance it was recently brought to notice by the legal advising that it was necessary that the clauses relating to the Advances in the Supply Bills (Nos 1 and 2) 1988-89 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89be amended to reflect the intention that clerical inadvertence be regarded as unforeseen. The only alternative to this course of action would be to introduce for urgent passage additional Appropriation Bills to meet each occurrence of an admission of an amount in relevant Appropriation Bills where a government was inextricably committed to meet payments.

The Parliament will be provided with details of amounts issued from the Advance to the Minister for Finance to cover errors and omissions by the addition of this category to those currently shown in the monthly tabling of issues from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. This document is tabled pursuant to recommendations in the previously mentioned 1979 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the Government's amendments to the three Supply Bills. As the Minister has indicated, the Government is seeking to amend the clauses of the Bills which deal with the application of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. This course of action, as he said, follows a legal opinion from the Attorney-General's Department which considers that the Department of Finance guidelines in applying the advance are outside the legal definitions. The Advance is a provision authorised by the annual Appropriation and Supply Acts to allow the executive arm of government to make extraordinary expenditures without the immediate need to go before Parliament. The current legislation, as I understand it, provides that the Advance is to be used for expenditure that is `urgent' and `unforeseen'.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past the Department of Finance has interpreted this as accounting for clerical errors or inadvertence. However, again as I understand it, after questioning by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts the Attorney-General's Department now advises that these instances are not strictly `unforeseen' and, therefore, are not covered by the legislation. What is transpiring here is that the Government is extending the legislation so that expenditure can be made if it is urgently required and `was erroneously omitted from, or understated in, the Bill for this Act'.

However, in our view this goes completely against the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. That Committee has been very concerned at the potential abuse of the Advance and the extent to which the executive arm of government is usurping the role of Parliament to watch over government expenditures. When the Committee became aware of the Department of Finance's erroneous application of the Advance it clearly sought tighter controls. The Committee's report No. 289 on the Advance states in paragraph 2.29:

Although the Attorney-General's Department suggested amending the wording of the Advance, if it is intended that clerical inadvertence be regarded as unforeseen, the Committee is not in favour of widening the use of the Advance.
The Committee therefore recommended:
To ensure conformity with the law and effective scrutiny of all expenditures, the guidelines issued by the Department of Finance be revised in respect of the terms `urgent' and `unforeseen'.

The Joint Committee clearly wanted the guidelines to be changed to match the law because they did not reflect the law and therefore were ultra vires or seemingly illegal. What is transpiring here is that the Government is seeking to make the law match the guidelines. Quite clearly, it is the guidelines that ought to fit within the law, rather than the other way round. The Committee considered that amendment of the guidelines and and stricter documentation requirements would reinforce that expenditure from the Advance must be for both urgent and unforeseen circumstances as specified by the Parliament.

With respect to stricter documentation, the Committee made two more recommendations. They were that a standard form be used for all applications for urgent and unforeseen expenditures from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, whether or not they will remain as a final charge to the Advance. That recommendation was made in paragraph 2.13. It was also recommended that the monthly statement from the Department of Finance to the Parliament have appended applications made on the standard forms for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance so that the Parliament can see clearly for what purpose advances are applied. That was recommended in paragraph 2.18.

I understand that the Committee has written to Senator Walsh saying that it will forgo its original recommendation and support the Government's amendment, but only if these other two recommendations are adopted. The Government has refused to adopt them. Therefore, the coalition, in agreeing with the analysis and recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, will be opposing the Government's amendments. Rather than acquiescing in an extension of the executive powers, we call for a tightening of those powers. We call on the Government to adopt the three original recommendations of the Joint Committee. They were substantial, they were important and they ought not, in our view, to be ignored. Lest it be thought that, in voting against these amendments, we are voting against Supply Bills, I add that that is not the case. It is not our intention, nor would it be our act. We are simply voting against the amendments proffered by the Minister and are not voting against the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past two days as the Supply Bills have gone through this chamber-they are now in the committee stage-I have listened with interest to comments made by members of the Opposition, both Liberal and National Party members. I have always admired the ability of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) as a professional politician and the way in which he approaches his task even though there is no policy to substantiate what he says.
—I am waiting for the sting in the tail.

—I admired him yesterday. I say this with all sincerity. He stood in this House and spoke for the half hour or so that he was allowed and violently attacked the Government's approach. I listened with interest, thinking I might gain something of what the Opposition's views are on consumption taxes or cuts to expenditure, but with regret I say to the honourable gentleman that I was very disappointed. I say again that I admire him. I heard today with a great deal of interest that there is a very strong rumour in the State House in Victoria that the honourable gentleman will shortly be challenging Mr Kennett for the leadership of the State party. I hope he gets the chance to deny that in this place and scotch those rumours very quickly. The Supply Bill is a fundamental arm of government and is very important in the administration of the fiscal and economic policy of this Government. I listened, as I said, with a great deal of interest to comments from the Opposition in the course of the debate and have been somewhat puzzled by comments from some spokesmen who say that they are going to cut expenditure all over the place, yet today we had the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) calling for increased funding for local government and increased expenditure on roads. I do not know how that fits with the shadow Treasurer's viewpoint on expenditure cuts. Certainly today the honourable member for Maranoa was calling for substantial increases in funding for local government and substantial increases in road funding.

SPEECH.PARA: The new honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt), in his maiden speech, made a very impassioned plea for increased expenditure in the aged area. I listened with interest to him because he is part of a party that says it is going to slash expenditure all over the place. Here was another example of an Opposition member calling for increased expenditure, which I do not necessarily disagree with. I think it is a wonderful concept, but I wonder how within the confines of the Opposition approach we are going to cut expenditure in these areas.

I suppose the gem of all speeches that I heard today was from the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who made what I guess one could almost say was his maiden economic speech in this House. I listened with a great deal of interest and a great deal of worry because I did not hear from him any details of what the Opposition economic policy really is. I thought that from someone with such an eminent background as the honourable member's we might hear something to inform the Parliament, the media and the Australian public just what the Opposition economic policy is and what are the parameters the Opposition would place in the economic debate, so that we can get into a really serious debate about the economy of this country.

Let me say that I do not agree with the propositions of the supply-side economists. I do not agree with those who run with the theory that one can simply cut taxes and somehow there is a magic incentive placed in the marketplace that then increases the gross domestic product, that then increases jobs. It seems to be a nonsense. Let us look for example, at what has happened in the United States-and I am always interested to hear those calling for cuts in company taxes. In the United States the Government reduced the rate of company tax to 28 per cent. Those who use that as an argument in this place do not inform the House and neglect to discuss the fact that it was a revenue neutral activity for the American Congress and the American President. The net effect of dropping the rate of tax to 28 per cent was to increase the tax take in the corporate sector by 23 per cent.

Is the Opposition suggesting here that we cut company taxes, while on the contrary side we decrease the concessional deductions for corporations and increase the revenue take? I wish someone in the Opposition would clearly detail to me and other members of the Parliament and perhaps to the business community-who are watching this debate with interest-what the Opposition means by a reduction in company taxes. Is it the American model? Is it a very shallow position where you cut taxes, but raise revenue so that it becomes a revenue neutral exercise? If one looks at what happened in New Zealand, again one finds that, while the New Zealand Government has dropped rates of tax, it has increased the net yield from taxation. I understand that before September we are going to get an Opposition tax policy. I hope that will be the case, because I want to see whether we are going to a supply-side economic theory, whether we are going to have a revenue neutral proposal on the tax side of the policies, or whether the tax cuts will be funded by cuts on the expenditure side of $16 billion or $2.3 billion or $10 billion.

The Government is quite clear on where it stands on these matters. I support the Confederation of Australian Industry in its support of the Australian Government's approach to economics. It is an economic miracle-there can be no argument about that. It stands to the credit of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the economic Ministers of this Government that, despite the fact that we suffered the worst trade turnaround since the 1920s and the early 1930s, this country has survived it very well. There has been pain in the electorate. The Government cannot cut real wages and expect the average Australian not to react to that. The Government cannot take the necessary difficult steps in monetary and fiscal policy and expect that as interest rates rise the people will not react to that.

One cannot expect wages forever to stay down. But this Government took the hard decisions. It overcame the terms of trade turnaround. It stuck to its guns. It exercised, in my view, a great deal of bravery and I am very proud to be a part of that Government. In conclusion I again say to the shadow Treasurer, a man I have admired from afar for many years, that I wish him luck with his policy. I enjoin him to come into this place with clean hands, as any equity lawyer should, and produce the policy so that one can have a debate on policy, rather than to be always negative and always saying that the Government is doing the wrong thing. I come here to debate, and I look forward to the day when we get that chance.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment before the Committee relates to the schedule, page 17, division 310. There are two things I want to say. All of that is buried in the small print in the last phrase of the amendment where it uses words like, `(B) was erroneously omitted from, or understated in, the Bill for this Act'.

As such, it is a shabby trend, one that is dangerous for the direction of parliamentary democracy, that the bureaucrats will have yet again scope to manoeuvre down paths that they chose, without coming properly to the Parliament and without properly stating the intent in the legislation in the first place. I support strongly what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong, has said. The second point I would like to raise concerns the style of drafting. One has to read it very carefully with the parent Bill before the chamber to work out precisely which lines will come out. I would suggest that as a style of drafting it would have been more accurate to say, `Omit subparagraph occurring under (b) (i)' or, alternatively, `omit subparagraph (i) (a)', as a different style of drafting from the one which has been adopted by the Minister in moving this amendment.
