DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW COMMONWEALTH OFFICES, MELBOURNE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of new Commonwealth offices, Melbourne.

The Government intends to construct a 60,000 square metre Commonwealth office accommodation building on the existing Commonwealth Centre site in Melbourne. This is in accordance with the Government's policy of increasing ownership of its office accommodation requirements. The proposal is the first of a two-stage development and will utilise some 6,000 squares metres of the south-east corner of the property. The site is well situated within the Melbourne central business district (CBD) and is well serviced by public transport. There are no site constraints affecting construction of the building, although it has been agreed with relevant State and local government authorities that a number of buildings of heritage interest will be retained. The design solution adopted for this stage of the development allows for a building of 42 storeys above ground and three basement levels below ground. The above ground design consists of a nine-floor podium with a tower section of a further 33 floors, all set back from the site boundary. The tower section provides 31 floors of office space and the remaining two floors will house plant and equipment. Office areas will accommodate about 4,000 public servants, while the basement will provide parking, storage space, plant rooms and other service areas.

The design is based on guidelines established for the development of Commonwealth office buildings and relevant Commonwealth construction standards and codes of practice apply. The anticipated construction period is 48 months. In keeping with commercial practice, staged occupancy of lower areas will be arranged. In this way, the podium areas will be available for fit-out about six to eight months earlier than the highest floor. As a consequence of the importance of time in this proposal, contractual arrangements will be adopted which minimise the risk of delay and associated costs. These arrangements will protect the Commonwealth and provide a building of the standard and quality required and maximise the expertise of the contractor in the documentation process.

Documentation to allow the proposal to go to tender is now nearing completion. Given the approval of the Standing Committee on Public Works, the Department of Administrative Services Construction Group is now in a position to tender in May, only nine months since the initial development was approved in the 1987-88 Budget. That is a great record. I think the Construction Group of my Department deserves congratulations, as does the Public Works Committee. The estimated cost of the proposal in the 1987-88 works program was $143m based on April 1987 prices. The proposal was referred to the Public Works Committee at this price. The current estimate, updated to April 1988 prices, is $154m. This estimate excludes costs for internal fit-out, which was referred to the Public Works Committee at $20m at April 1987 prices. This estimate, updated to April 1988 prices, is now $22m. I understand the changes are solely as a result of inflation.

The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) said on Tuesday in this House that he believes this proposal is not consistent with Government policy. I do not know how the honourable member for Barker claims to be an authority on Government policy, but I can assure the House that this proposal is consistent with Government policy, including that of rationalisation of its property holdings to achieve a more efficient utilisation of its assets. As part of this rationalisation the Government has sold the Melbourne Commonwealth Centre, releasing to the private sector a prime development site. If this building had been retained by the Government, a very costly refurbishment would have had to be completed to restore the building to an acceptable standard. While disposal of the Melbourne Commonwealth Centre also reduces the level of owned accommodation by about 29,000 square metres of occupiable space, this proposal provides for a development of about 60,000 square metres of office space. The net result will be a substantial increase in the Federal Government's stock of owned accommodation in Melbourne. It will also enable departments currently accommodated in high-priced leases in private sector accommodation and who continue to require a fringe CBD location to be relocated into modern office accommodation with considerable saving in rent.

A financial analysis of the proposal, which has been made available to the Parliamentary Public Works Committee on a confidential basis, clearly demonstrates the advantages of the proposal over private sector pre-commitment leasing. It indicated that on a discounted net present value basis the proposal will conservatively result in a saving of many millions of dollars, even over a relatively short period of 15 years. I would like to thank the Committee for its prompt consideration of this important proposal, and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose this proposal but, as the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) pointed out when the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Public Works was tabled in this House, we do have some concern that the Government appears to be going about the process of planning future office accommodation requirements, in the major capital cities, and in particular in Melbourne and Sydney, in a very ad hoc way. The homework that is required to determine the future requirements in both of those major cities for the departments concerned does not appear to have been done. It may be more efficient, and more convenient to the public, if Public Service operations were located in the suburbs, but we have not been able to establish whether a review to determine where the most efficient operations could be based has been undertaken by the Government. We note that further building programs are coming forward, particularly in the Melbourne area, at Oakleigh and also at Frankston. But we are not certain how those projects might dovetail with an overall program of planned redevelopment and reaccommodation of some Public Service functions.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst we do not oppose this project, we urge the Government to plan its future operations far better than it has in the past, rather than simply pulling out ad hoc programs to suit its own convenience. We note that the major form of building in Melbourne was part of the Government's sell-off program which did nothing to help the Government balance its budget in this financial year. Now we are seeing a further building program to reaccommodate Public Service departments. This all seems to be part of an ad hoc program by the Government. It is not part of any planned, long term visionary program by the Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW COMMONWEALTH OFFICES, HAYMARKET, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of new Commonwealth offices, Haymarket New South Wales.

The proposal before the House if for the construction of about 50,000 square metres of office accommodation at Haymarket in Sydney on Commonwealth land known as the Australian Gas Light Co. site. The proposal is in accordance with the Government's policy of increasing ownership of its office accommodation requirements, therefore reducing the overall rental outlays in Sydney. The site is a complete city block at the southern end of the central business district (CBD) bounded by Pitt, Barlow, Barker and Hay Streets. It is well positioned in relation to public transport. It is only five minutes walk from Central Railway Station and the bus interchange at Railway Square.

The site contains a number of historic buildings. The proposal will provide for the restoration of the significant buildings and their incorporation into the overall development. The site also contains a number of retail facilities. To take advantage of the full development potential of the site, the project will include some 1,600 square metres of retail and commercial facilities which will be leased on the open market. The proposed office development will comprise a main tower of 31 levels at the southern end of the site linked to a medium rise building of nine floors along the western boundary. A two-storey podium to the north-east will incorporate the three historic buildings. The development will accommodate some 3,000 public servants. On-site parking will be provided for about 130 vehicles. Access and facilities for the disabled will be provided.

The estimated cost of this proposal in the 1987-88 public works program was $180m at April 1987 prices. The proposal was referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works at this price. The current estimate, updated to April 1988 prices, is $231m. This estimate excludes costs for internal fitout which was referred to the Public Works Committee at $18m at April 1987 prices. This estimate for fitout updated to 1988 prices is now $20m.

Contrary to the assertions made in this House recently by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) and the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), this proposal is, like the Melbourne proposal, consistent with government policy. It rationalises the Government's property holdings to achieve a more efficient utilisation of assets. The proposal provides for some 50,000 square metres of office space.

Even allowing for the reduction of space resulting from the sale of 20,000 square metres of office space in the Commonwealth Centre at Chifley Square, the net result is a substantial increase in the Government's stock of owned accommodation in Sydney. This sale has raised $306m, compared to $118m which this building will cost. So we move up from 20,000 to 50,000 square metres and we make hundreds millions of dollars in the process. The opposition says that that is not effective rationalisation of office space. If it is not, I do not know what is. As I have just said, substantial revenue gains have been made.

The revenue that has been obtained from the sale of Chifley Square certainly more than offsets the cost of this magnificent Haymarket proposal. Its development will also help to revitalise this part of Sydney, consistent with urban planning objectives of State and local authorities. I certainly believe that even the new State Government in New South Wales will stand back and applaud the Federal Labor Government's initiative in helping to revitalise this run-down area of downtown Sydney.

The proposal as developed also offers major savings over the alternative of leasing equivalent accommodation. I understand that the honourable member for Lyons asserted that the rental savings are insufficient to justify the cost. What must be remembered, however, is that the rental savings which are achieved on initial occupation of the building will increase over time as rental costs escalate elsewhere in the Sydney region. Rental costs for leased accommodation over a long period, of, say, 15 or 20 years, in the end are dead payments, whereas if one builds and consequently owns a building, the building generally appreciates in value over time and at the end of the 15 or 20 years one still has an asset which has long since been paid for and which has escalated in value in line with inflation.

Members of the Public Works Committee, including the honourable member for Lyons, were provided with a confidential financial analysis of this proposal. The analysis clearly showed its superiority over a leasing alternative. So I do not know what the honourable member was talking about the other day. Even over a relatively short period of 15 years, the analysis showed that, in discounted net present value terms, the proposal will conservatively result in a saving of many millions of dollars when compared with a leasing alternative.

The office development proposed will meet a significant proportion of the justified office accommodation requirements of the Sydney region. Specifically it will meet the needs of a number of potential occupant departments currently accommodated in high-priced CBD leases. It will also meet the needs of the Australian Taxation Office, but I stress that the accommodation is not dependent on the Taxation Office for its successful and complete occupation. Any suggestion of delaying its implementation while the Taxation Office completes some further planning of its future needs would, therefore be counterproductive, cannot be justified and would lead to increased costs.

Documentation to allow the proposal to go to tender is proceeding. Tenders will be called to enable construction to commence on completion of site preparation, expected in November of this year. I would like to thank the Committee for its prompt consideration of the proposal, and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the construction of this particular government project at Haymarket, but the comments that I made earlier about the Melbourne project are doubly appropriate to this project at Haymarket. The project for the construction of a building at Haymarket proposes a building of 50,000 square metres, and it is proposed that 30,000 square metres of that building will be occupied by the Australian Taxation Office. Yet in evidence to the Public Works Committee it was pointed out by the Taxation Office that it was uncertain whether it wished to occupy that building. The Taxation Office is currently doing a review of its office accommodation requirements in the Sydney area and it pointed out to the Committee in evidence that it might be more efficient for it to be located in various suburbs rather than to be centrally located in the central business district.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition feels that it is premature for the Government to go ahead with this project while that review by the Taxation Office, which is intended to be the major tenant of the building, is still under way. While I pointed out earlier with regard to the Melbourne project that this Government is going about its office accommodation requirements in an ad hoc way, we claim that in relation to the Sydney building it is even more ad hoc than is the case in Melbourne.

The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) pointed out that the Chifley Square building, which was the major government-owned building in the central business district of Sydney, was sold earlier this year as part of the Government's program to balance its budget this year. We maintain that if the Government wants to sell off its assets simply to be able to boast of balancing its budget in one year, it is no justification for extending the spending program over a number of years.

I pointed out earlier in the House something that the Minister is rather testy about, that in evidence to the Public Works Committee it was pointed out by the Department of Administrative Services that the cost of leasing 50,000 square metres of rental accommodation in the Sydney area at present is $13m. Yet the construction cost plus fit-out cost of $135m for this building will cost more to service than what it would cost to lease property in the central business district.

We do not oppose this particular project, but we accuse the Government of going about its office accommodation requirements in the major capital cities in a most ad hoc way. What we ask the Government to do is nothing more than review its program, plan where it is going to accommodate public service departments and public service functions, look at where the Government can offer the best service to the public, and come back to this Parliament with a planned and cohesive program for the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF RADIO AND ORCHESTRA FACILITIES FOR AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION AND SPECIAL BROADCASTING SERVICE, ULTIMO, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of radio and orchestra facilities for the ABC and SBS at Ultimo, New South Wales.

Currently the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) operate their radio and orchestra services from 24 separate premises around the central business district of Sydney, all but two of which are leased. The ABC has costed the savings likely to be achieved by collocation within a single-purpose designed facility at approximately $10.2m a year. This takes into account projected rent and staff savings and other operational efficiencies. These savings will be sufficient to meet the cost of annual repayments required under the instalment purchase arrangements intended to finance construction of the building.

Sale of the two remaining ABC-owned properties will meet the $14.8m cost of purchasing the Ultimo site. The Committee supports collocation on the Ultimo site and expresses the view that, notwithstanding the current review of national broadcasting policy, the solution offers sufficient flexibility to cope with possible future changes.

As recommended by the Committee, the proposal provides for construction of a 39,800 square metre building over nine levels, comprising offices, studio-production suites and a 700-seat rehearsal and recording hall, plus other public and support facilities. A feature of the building will be the central spine, designated as `studio capable' floor area, which will incorporate special provisions to ensure full acoustic isolation of studios. The `On Air' studios will also have views over the city and Darling Harbour.

The building includes all normal engineering services, plus comprehensive provisions to ensure an appropriate acoustic environment and to maintain essential power supplies in the event of mains failure. Special attention will be paid to building security. Design has been undertaken by private sector consultants and further design documentation and construction will be undertaken on a project management basis with construction packages to be publicly tendered.

The proposal also includes construction of a 520 space car park on the balance of the site. One hundred of these spaces will be permanently required for use by the ABC and SBS. The additional car parking spaces, when not required for ABC or SBS purposes, will be available for commercial hire and, together with occasional hire of other facilities, are expected to produce an annual income of approximately $1.28m. The Committee supports this inclusion in the project, given the scarcity of parking in the Ultimo area, but recommends that the ABC investigate the possibility of operating the car park itself. Subject to endorsement by Parliament, it is planned that site works commence immediately. The main building construction is scheduled to start in mid-July 1988, with an estimated total building construction period of 30 months. This is the most significant public work to be undertaken by the ABC in recent times and one which should materially improve both operational efficiency and staff amenity. Accordingly, I am confident that the ABC will heed the advice of the Committee by ensuring closer consultation with the ABC staff union on those operational issues which still require resolution. Given that these do not affect the substance of the proposal, I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the construction of this building for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio operations in Sydney. We agree wholeheartedly with the Government that it is vitally necessary for the ABC radio operations to be relocated and that it will be much more efficient for the ABC to have all those operations based in one building. Up until now the ABC radio operations in Sydney have been spread over, I think, six different buildings in the William Street area, which has led to inefficiencies and extreme difficulty for the ABC in maintaining the service it has to the public.

SPEECH.PARA: I compliment the programmers and all of the other staff of the ABC for maintaining the quality of the radio services that they have in the past under extreme difficulties. I think the relocation of the radio operations to the Ultimo site will be very beneficial to the staff and hopefully will help them to provide even better quality radio services in the future. The orchestra facilities that are also to be provided in this building will be complementary to the radio operations. The Opposition notes that there has not yet been any decision made as to the long term future of the ABC orchestras, not only in Sydney but in the other centres as well. We would certainly encourage the Government to the extent possible regarding private or sponsorship funding of orchestras. We take the view that, regardless of what the future funding arrangements for the ABC orchestras might be, there will always be quality orchestras in Sydney and the other capital cities and that those orchestras will need a home. The building planned for Ultimo will certainly provide a very good base for the ABC orchestra in Sydney, and we wish it well in its future functions in that location.

There is just one matter that we ask the Government to consider in the future: we note that no financial impact statement has been provided in regard to this building, and we would be very interested to know whether in the financial sense the Government will be better or worse off as a result of the relocation to this site as compared to leasing and the other financial arrangements that have been required in the past in relation to the various locations. I ask the Minister, in regard to future programs such as this, the provide the Parliament with a financial impact statement so that honourable members and the public can obtain a better appreciation of the total financial impact of these proposals.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 April, on motion by Mr Staples:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is seriously concerned about the practical consequences of the Government's aged care proposals. Like many of the Labor Government's policies, the slick packaging that accompanied this policy announcement hid a great number of shortcomings. The Government is trumpeting about more staff care hours. The industry calculates that the Government's initiative in this area amounts to no more than 36 seconds per hour per day. The Government is talking about better quality care for nursing home residents but, as a consequence of the application of this policy, many existing nursing home residents will be forced into hostels. There is considerable doubt in the industry whether hostels, even with improved facilities, will be capable of providing the standard of care that is necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the industry is concerned that the resident classification instrument (RCI) is designed to allow only the standard of service that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) is prepared to allow the industry to provide. As well, the Government is trumpeting about $130m worth of extra funding, yet on questioning by the industry it is unable to provide detail about what that $130m in funding represents. The Government also talks about a crackdown on fraud. That is nothing more than a public relations exercise and an extension of the Government's politicisation of the aged care debate. Massive powers are already provided in existing legislation, and the industry does not believe that the Government has the true resolve to address those malpractices that occur at present.

Perhaps the most serious criticism by the industry of the proposal relates to the resident classification instrument. According to the industry, all sections of the industry, both private and voluntary care, will find it almost impossible to put patients into the top category of care-category 1-so that in many cases the total number of staff care hours available in many institutions will be reduced. That is contrary to the Minister's and the Government's assertion. Compounding all these criticisms is the fact that the Government is playing politics with the introduction of this measure. It knows that it will cause a reaction in many States, in particular in Victoria and South Australia, and the phasing in of the proposals is deliberately designed to avoid any political backlash for the Labor Government's colleagues in Victoria. Honourable members opposite are playing politics with members of that section of our community who can least afford to have their lives manipulated for the transparent political advances of a cynical government.

I do not really want to politicise this debate tonight. I would like to put on the record the views of experienced practical care providers to ensure that the Minister and honourable members are aware of the concerns of those people who work in many instances out of a genuine concern for the well-being of their fellow human beings to provide aged cared in this country. I would like to cite a number of statements that have been made by people with acknowledged and detailed expertise in this industry. The first relevant quote is from the Age newspaper of Monday 25 April, a statement by the Executive Director of the Villa Maria Society for the Blind. The article is headed, `New system for subsidising care for the elderly is a sham'. Mr McKernan, the executive director of the organisation, said:
Under the proposed new system of categorising patients, it is almost impossible to have any patients in the top scoring bracket.
He further said:
The categorising procedure gives no consideration to any allowance for sensory loss . . .

That organisation deals with blind patients, and some patients are also deaf as well as having other geriatric problems. That is its criticism of the Government's proposal. The Baptist Union of Victoria, a non-profit organisation, has also criticised the proposal. The Union comprises people who are motivated by a genuine Christian concern for the well-being of their fellow human beings. It talks about a statement made by the Minister and it is rather disparaging of the basis of that statement. It says in part:
For some reason unknown to us-
that is, the Baptist Union of Victoria-

the Hawke Government refuses to listen to the workers in this matter. The basic problem is not to be found in the principles expounded by the Government, but in the way it is going about its business. How can anyone have confidence in a Department which now claims it has allowed, according to Mr Staples, `a 91 per cent mismatch between resources and the nursing and personal care needs of residents' for years.
That is for the five years it has been in office. The Union makes a number of detailed criticisms of the Government's proposal. As I said, a major industry concern is the RCI, and the Union stated:

There is no undertaking to review the system used to classify nursing home residents into five categories, despite the demonstrated fact that in its present form, very few nursing home residents come into category 1 unless the form is misinterpreted.
The second point it makes is as follows:
The statement that residents in Victorian nursing homes would receive an average of 20 hours per resident per week means nothing until the level of Commonwealth payment per hour has been settled.

Of course, that only serves to emphasise the incomplete nature of the statement made by the Government last week and of the overall policy for this most important phase of the Government's aged care program. The Union goes on to criticise the number of exempt beds. It also comments about the new system to crack down on fraud and sharp practices. It is very cynical about the Government's announcement in this place and about its true intentions. The Union's final point relates to the very germane question of where the $130m extra that the Government proposes to provide in this area will be spent. It states:
The reform measures announced by Mr Staples totalling $130m cannot be detailed by departmental staff, except in broad terms.

Of course, the Minister in summing up the debate later tonight will have the opportunity to provide a detailed statement in relation to that $130m which was not included in his original announcement last week. Of course, that was very glib and very well packaged and in relation to the Australian Labor Party we have become accustomed to recognising that, when something is well packaged and when it involves a lot of glitter, we should have a good hard look, because there is not much substance.
The Union goes on to say:
. . . it is not unreasonable to expect the details to be available . . .

It questions whether the announcements were based on an uninformed guess by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). While it is quite reasonable for those involved in the industry to make that request, I believe that the Government has an obligation to this Parliament to detail its policy in this area. Of course, it has not done that. Many other criticisms are made by, for instance, the Voluntary Care Association of Victoria, an organisation that represents the overall grouping of voluntary, charitable and church-based organisations that provide aged care. It states in part:
The full impact of the decision is still unable to be determined because the Government has yet to decide on the funding of-
this is the same criticism made by the Baptist Union-
allowances for tolerances in under-utilisation or over-utilisation of nursing and personal care hours, and expenditure;
allowances for annual leave, sick leave and long service leave.
the mix of nursing hours and the standard hourly rate . . .

That criticism underlines further the fact that the Government is very short on detail. It is moving for politically motivated reasons to hose down an issue before what was building up to be a major political campaign against the Labor party, and the Cain Labor Government in Victoria, got out of hand. Regrettably for the Government, it has not been able to fool the experts in the industry. I am illustrating the reaction that the Government is getting to a very superficial statement that was not even tabled last week by the Minister. Most of the detail was saved for a Press conference, and all the Parliament received was a second reading speech which was long on rhetoric and short on detail.

I have referred to comments made by the voluntary care organisations, the non-profit providers of aged care. Of course, there are people involved in providing aged care who are concerned to make a profit. One of the more respected operators in the industry is the Moran Healthcare Group, which has made a very detailed commentary on this Bill. The first item it addresses is the notorious-if it is not notorious now it will be so in a few months-resident classification instrument (RCI). The Moran Group states:

The Resident Classification Instrument is basically designed so that service needs of residents fit into what the Minister is prepared to allow. Subjective assessment has replaced the objectivity of the Resident's General Practitioner.
What basis is that for an aged care policy to apply on a uniform basis around Australia? The Group goes on to talk about the RCI:

We have documented proof that the weightings applied to a person's skills are heavily skewed towards achieving a high number of category 4 and 5 residents who would be eligible for hostel placement. Category 4 and 5 residents represent 40 per cent of the population of nursing home patients earmarked for hostel accommodation. Very few residents will achieve category 1 status;
That is the same comment made by the other groups to which I have referred tonight. The statement continues:
therefore, only two categories are left. The current scheme has two categories.
The Moran Healthcare Group, like many other operators in the industry, questions the bona fides of the RCI. The Group goes on to refer to some of the statements made by the Minister:
The Minister's claim in the Sydney Morning Herald on 22/4/88 that an across-the-board increase of 1 hour per patient week, translates to 36 seconds per hour per day.

That is what I stated in my opening remarks. The Moran Group will not get excited about that increase in the Government's generosity. That Group, like the entire industry on a national basis, is critical of the way in which the Government went about developing this program. It states:
We consider that the consultations held were of little value.

It goes on to make some very disparaging remarks about individual officers in the Department of Community Services and Health. It is not appropriate for me to name those officers, but those criticisms are not confined to the Moran Group. In fact, they are general criticisms that have been made to me, and I hope to the Minister, and to his senior Minister, by people in the industry. One thing that is important if the Government's aged care policy is to succeed is for it to have the goodwill of the care providers throughout Australia. There is no point in picking a fight with the people who have to do the job because if the Government gets them off side no policy will work.
The Moran Group comments about the impact of this program on small nursing homes:
We firmly believe that the government is intending to close these homes gradually.

That statement is of great significance to people who live in country or remote areas or to those nursing homes that cater for minority or ethnic groups. The Government is being very cunning in terms of its implementation of this program. A further transitory period-an option to back off from this program-is provided, so that the Government can ensure that the political flak that will inevitably arise from these proposals will be minimised in terms of State elections and probably even the Keating May 1989 election option, when he replaces the current Prime Minister.

The Moran Group comments about the Government's proposals for exempt beds, that is, beds where people who want a higher standard of care and are prepared and able to pay for it can make those payments. The Group states:
Many Nursing Homes that would request Exempt Bed Status are becoming less viable daily.

As an aside, I point out that the proprietors of about 950 nursing home beds in Victoria alone are currently in liquidation. As a result of some of the measures contained in this program, that number will increase significantly. According to the Moran Group, the proprietors of these nursing homes cannot wait until they become insolvent. What is likely to happen is that nursing homes will close as a result of the introduction of this program, not because of its philosophy or principles but because of the mechanics, the standards, that are part and parcel of its implementation.

As I hope the Minister and his Department know, we have a major aged care problem in this country at present that is getting worse day by day because of the gradual ageing of our population. The last thing we can afford is a reduction in the number of nursing home places available because people voluntarily leave the industry when their viability is affected. The Moran Group also comments on the duplication of inspection proposed by the Commonwealth.

This program represents phase four of the Government's aged care policy. There is genuine cross-party concern in this Parliament about providing quality aged care. I do not intend, on behalf of the Opposition, to oppose this Bill. However, I intend to make it abundantly clear to the Minister and to the Government that we have the gravest reservations about the way in which this policy will be implemented. We are concerned that the standards on which phase four is based will in fact prevent the implementation of the philosphy and principles that are the underlying basis of this overall program.

The Opposition believes that, as far as possible, the aged in our community should be supported in their own homes and in their own communities because that gives them the greatest quality of life and, perhaps, the greatest expectation of a longer life. We further believe that aged people should be supported by residential service only where other support services are not appropriate to meet their needs and that, where services are provided, they should promote rehabilitation.

The Government first announced its policy direction in this area in 1986. At that time, the Opposition supported the direction of this policy. Since then, a number of legislative and other initiatives have been taken to introduce this policy on a phased or staged basis. As each of these initiatives has come to the Parliament, the Opposition has not opposed them. We have often supported them criticising the detail, making suggestions and moving amendments.

The Bill before the House causes us more concern than any other provision we have been asked to consider as part of this program. The concerns we have, and they are the concerns of the industry overall, relate to a reduction in the quality and standard of care for some aged people throughout Australia through the use of inappropriate classification standards. We are also concerned about the provisions of inadequate staff levels. The reduction in the standard of staff qualifications as a result of many of the Government's proposals has the potential for making fewer experienced nurses available.

We are concerned that overall the reduction in the levels of financial support for the aged care industry could threaten the financial viability of many facilities. I have referred to that before. The last thing we can afford in this country at present-and our problem will get worse and worse on a daily and monthly basis until about 2020-is a reduction in the number of aged care places. We are also concerned at the very arbitrary 6 per cent limit on the number of exempt nursing home beds. That arbitrary 6 per cent limit shows that we have a government or a department that is trying to second guess the market. It is trying to work out in an ivory tower in Canberra, through sampling and surveys, what the market demand for exempt nursing home beds will be. I think that is a futile exercise. Of course, it is not just a question of providing an arbitrary limit of 6 per cent. There are many other restrictions, including a tender requirement for the provision of exempt nursing home beds, all of which will compound the problem for those aged Australians or their families, their children, who want to provide a higher standard of care than is provided for in the Government's policy.

The industry is seriously worried about the resident classification instrument. It believes that the standards contained within that instrument have been artificially manipulated in the interests of providing a regulatory mechanism for controlling the number of people in nursing homes rather than determining the quality and standards of care required by people in nursing homes. The industry is concerned that the categorisation provided for in the RCI does not reflect the realities of the population of the aged needing care throughout Australia. There has been major criticism of this five category classification system. Category 5 is supposed to represent 20 per cent of people; category 4, 20 per cent; category 3, 30 per cent; category 2, 20 per cent; and category 1, 10 per cent. It has been said that the entire program of developing this RCI began with very poor instructions to those who were charged with the responsibility of collecting the data.

A very serious accusation has been made by people in the industry that there has been manipulation of the statistics gathered to suit the objectives of the Government and the Department in this area. These objectives may be political and could be determined by financial constraints but are certainly not determined by a concern to provide the best quality care for those frail aged Australians who at that stage of their lives should be least subject to political convenience. It has been asserted that the aim is to remove categories 4 and 5 from nursing home care into hostel care. Certain problems are presented if people who are currently nursing home residents are to be moved into hostels. There are insufficient hostel places. The Government has said that it will create more places over a period. But the type of patient who will be moved into hostels will need far more intensive care-care based on more staff hours-than is currently available.

There will also be a need to change and upgrade many of the facilities within hostels. The Government has not yet announced how it will cope with the funding requirements associated with that. I will give you a very simple example, Mr Deputy Speaker. Under these proposals many incontinent nursing home residents will be moved into hostels. Many hostels do not have what is colloquially known as a pan room. That will have to be provided. Many hostels have carpeting on the floor. That is totally inappropriate, if that is the nature of the resident that they will be coping with in the future. The carpet will have to be pulled up and linoleum or vinyl tiles put down.

These are very superficial changes but they are indicative of the type of restructuring and alteration by the industry that will be necessary on a massive basis right across the country. They are issues about which the Minister and the Government have provided no answers and no statements. The Minister will have the opportunity to correct this tonight, because he will be able to sum up at the conclusion of this debate. The Opposition is prepared to facilitate as long a summing up as the Minister wants. The industry wants the answers, as much as we want the answers and as much as the tens of thousands of residents in nursing homes around Australia, their relatives and the staff who look after them want the answers, to these important questions.

As I have said the industry has expressed major concern about the basis on which the RCI was drawn up. I will give some examples of its concern. There is one church-run nursing home that currently has 140 beds. If the RCI is applied to that nursing home, only three of the residents in those 140 beds would be in the highest dependency category. The Minister and the Government are trying to tell the industry that at present they do not know how to categorise their patients; they do not know how to provide care levels for the patients based on their need. I will translate this into a particular human example: there is a person-perhaps it is best not to go into too much detail which would identify him-who is constrained to a foetal position in bed, unable to do anything whatsoever for himself. Under the Government's classification system that person would be in category 4, not category 1. The person cannot do anything for himself. Under the Government's proposal he would be in category 4.

There are other examples. There are certain problems in terms of discussing them. They are not particularly comforting issues to debate. It is important that people understand that we are talking about real Australians, not statistics and not people who can be categorised by some insensitive, cold thing known as a resident classification instrument. These are people, parents of children, who have feelings, who have made a contribution to our community over many years, and in the last few years of their lives the standard of care and the security available to them is seriously under threat by the detail-not the philosophy-of the Government's proposal.

I will cite another example. Mary I is a frail, depressed lady with severe arthritis, very poor eyesight, who walks with a frame, requires full assistance with showering and dressing-and generally with transfer-and needs ongoing reassurance and encouragement with walking and sight. According to the RCI, Mary I would slot into category 5. That is the bottom category. Category 1 is the top category.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your people are lobbying us.

—That shows how much the honourable member knows about it. He should not go back to his electorate until he has read about this because he will get a serve back there, particularly in Victoria. Mr H is a 51-year-old man with cerebral palsy and gross spasticity, who is unable to speak and do anything for himself except hold a spoon and feed himself under supervision. He has been a resident in a nursing home for the past 23 years. Under the RCI he is placed in category 4, and that classifies him for hostel placement.
—You are trying to scare them.

—I can understand that the honourable member for Burke and perhaps a few other members of the Labor Party here are squirming, because I do not think they really understand the political backlash they will get as a result of this policy and as a result of the failure of the Minister and the Department to consult and listen to people with practical expertise in the industry. It comes down to the fact that the policy, the direction and the principles are fine. That is why we supported them. What the Government is doing now will put the whole policy in jeopardy. It will threaten the security of the lives of tens of thousands of Australians. It will put stress on those people who provide care for them. It will cause tension and stress for tens of thousands of families throughout Australia and there will be a political backlash as a result of it.
—You are doing that.

—I am not doing anything. I am reading what the industry, the Baptist Union and the Voluntary Care Association are saying. The honourable member finds it mighty uncomfortable. But the fact is that that is what the industry is saying.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable members on my right are listed to speak in the course of the debate. I suggest that they reserve their comments for their formal period for rebuttal.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate your protection and I will listen to the apologists on the Labor Party side later tonight when they try to justify their position. It will be more interesting to hear what they have to say about this policy in 12 months time because that is when the political backlash will be coming.
—Order! I amend the comments I made to the honourable member for Burke because he will not have an opportunity to speak later in the evening.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sad that the honourable member for Burke will not be speaking later in the evening. There are other problems with the Government's RCI program. It was developed in isolation because the consultative process was a joke. The Minister is smiling at his advisers. I wonder whether his advisers have shown him the comments of the industry on that. The industry feels that the sample that was the basis of this RCI determination was too small. They did not comprehensively examine the practical implementation of the appropriate level of care hours needed. The RCI cannot indicate the quantity or mix of care to be given to individual people to achieve the Government's standards and the standards of the RCI make it almost impossible for people to get into the most dependent category.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for these reasons, and a whole host of other reasons that unfortunately I do not have time to go into tonight, that the Opposition is moving an amendment at this second reading stage expressing our grave concerns at the implication of the Government's policy and calling upon it to conduct an immediate review of these parameters which are the basis of its RCI and to engage in some genuine consultation with the industry that will be reflected in the detailed implementation of its policy. For that reason, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) is concerned that aspects of the Government's aged care policy will result in:

(a) a reduction in the quality and care standards for some aged persons through the use of inappropriate standards for the classification of nursing home and hostel residents in the Resident Care Instrument (RCI);
(b) the provision of inadequate staff levels to provide appropriate standards of care for many frail aged patients, particularly those with sensory loss;
(c) reduction in levels of financial support for the aged care industry which could threaten the financial viability of many facilities; and
(d) insufficient exempt beds through the imposition of an arbitrary 6% limit; and
(2) requests the Government to not only consult closely with the industry, but conduct a review of the standards for classification incorporated in the RCI'.

The Opposition believes in the philosophy that I explained earlier in this debate, but we have the most serious reservations about how this stage of the Government's aged care policy will be implemented. Let me give an assurance on behalf of the Opposition that we will not stand idly by while the security and quality of care available to aged Australians is threatened by a government that is insensitive to their needs and insensitive to the needs and expectations of the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes, I second the amendment, Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) really had his heart in his speech this evening. He was a bit concerned about the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) who are out doing the numbers and doing a bit of wining and dining of the troops. The Opposition has decided not to oppose the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. I am staggered at this. I do not think that anything has changed in the past week. This is the same Bill on which the honourable member for Richmond said that patients would be washed less often and would be left in bed longer, that nursing homes would use more chemicals and physical restraints, that they would cut communications with the patients and their families. This is the same Bill.
—Who said that?

—Charles Blunt is the chap's name. He said that nursing homes would use non-individual continence maintenance and, in addition, some nursing home beds may close and residents will be forced to look for alternative accommodation in our already overcrowded public hospitals, but more likely with their families. Nothing has changed. Those opposite have decided not to oppose all this. Last week all these things were there. What has happened to them all? Suddenly they are all gone. Well, he sort of changed his mind. I can appreciate members of the Opposition changing their minds. They are always doing that. They cannot make up their minds on television-name something and I--
—Tax.

—That is another one. They just cannot do it. The honourable member for Richmond has now changed his mind; he is going to agree to the Bill. Those opposite are not going to oppose it. If all the things stated in his Press release had been correct, I would have opposed this Bill; but they are false. The Opposition is about scaring people; that is what it all boils down to. Once again we are witnessing an Opposition with no policies, nothing at all that will benefit members of the community. All they can do is scare them. They do it pretty effectively too. I have not been around since 1901 but I am afraid that I would have to say that this Opposition would have to be the worst since Federation. There is no doubt about that. At the moment members of the front bench are being dictated to by John Howard. They are gagged; they are not allowed to speak freely. What has happened to the Liberals--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The matter of relevance has raised a lot of debate in this place. Furthermore, we are talking about the fate of elderly people and the honourable member wants to run politics. It is a shame.

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor has made his point of order. The honourable member for Dunkley should be mindful of the requirement to be relevant. The Chair has tolerated some introductory remarks, but I think it is high time for him to become more relevant to the Bill.

—Certainly, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for O'Connor said that I want to play politics. He has been playing it for weeks now. What does he think the Opposition has been doing with all these Press releases it has been putting out about the nursing homes? There are scaring headlines-`Aged under threat'; `Threat to care of the elderly'; `Frail aged policy autocratic; Blunt'. We have Press releases from Mr Reith in my electorate-`Nursing home standards will drop'. Those opposite have been playing politics for weeks. That is all they do. They do not know anything else. That is their job. Fair enough; but they should get the position right; they have it wrong all the time. Mr Blunt has just gone on and on. He is saying all these things to scare the elderly people. That is what those opposite are all about. That is the only thing they can do. Mr Blunt--
—Order! The honourable member has erred several times. He will address members by the electorate they represent.
—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for Richmond said that there will be no-one in category one.
—He did not say that.
—What did he not say?
—Order! Honour- able members on my left are fully aware that in this place every member has the right to be heard in silence.

—The honourable member for Richmond said that there will be no-one in category one. That is wrong. There is a letter from the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) to the Age actually refuting that sort of allegation. The Minister was replying to a letter from Mr Maurice McKernan and said:

SPEECH.PARA: I was concerned to read Maurice McKernan's suggestion . . . that it will be `virtually impossible' for Victorian nursing home residents to be classified as `Category 1' . . .
Contrary to Mr McKernan's suggestion, some 15 per cent of Victorian nursing home residents are expected to be classified as `Category 1' residents.
Some 15 per cent-that is a lot different from what the honourable member for Richmond said. The Minister continued:
A further 25 per cent are expected to be `Category 2', also requiring a very high level of care.
That adds up to a few. It is not zero, is it? The Minister went on:

From 1 July, new `Category 2' residents will be funded for 23.5 hours of nursing and personal care per week-again, much higher than the current average for Victorian nursing home residents of 19.6 hours per week.
So the honourable member's statements are wrong. He just does not know what he is talking about. The Minister continued:
These estimates of likely resident numbers in the new needs-based funding categories are based on a national survey of over 17,000 residents in 1,200 nursing homes in November last year.
The assessments of residents' needs were made by people in the best position to know . . .
Not by people like me. I cannot evaluate whether a person requires care or not. These decisions were made by the directors of nursing in the homes. The Minister went on:
The new system, which Mr McKernan dubs a `sham'-
and which the honourable member for Richmond has also said is a sham-
is in fact based entirely on what the Directors of Nursing believe are the factors that most influence a resident's needs for nursing and personal care services.
It has been shown to accurately match residents' needs in 94 per cent of all cases-
that is a lot of cases, and they are pretty right-
compared with only 9 per cent under the old system it replaces.

So for years and years nursing homes have been forgotten and tucked away. Some nursing home proprietors have used this as a way of abusing some of the privileges and benefits that the Commonwealth and State governments forwarded to nursing homes.

The honourable member for Richmond spoke about a letter he received from the Villa Maria Society for the Blind. I received a letter in my office today and I would like to point out to the honourable member and other Opposition members what they are doing to the community with the fear, mistrust and I believe outright lies that they are disseminating throughout the community. The letter I received today states:

My mother who is 97 years of age has been a resident at the . . . Centre for three years. When she entered the Centre, she was relatively independent, but, particularly in the last six months, has become totally dependent upon the care given by the dedicated staff at the Centre.

I am very disturbed to learn that the Commonwealth Government is proposing to change the basis of funding of nursing homes which will result in a dramatic cut in nursing and personal care staff hours in Victorian nursing homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who told her that?
—This is what I am getting at. These sorts of lies and furphies--
—Order! The honourable member should know that the term he used is unparliamentary. I require him to desist.

—Yes. These sorts of mistruths are being used to scare people such as the person who wrote this letter. She is obviously a dedicated daughter of this woman and goes to see her quite often because of her age. She has been scared into writing this letter to me. Her last sentence probably boils down to what it is all about-the political context for the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: As a lifelong Labor voter, I am extremely disturbed that a Labor Government should contemplate funding cuts of this kind-
we have just increased it by $130m-
affecting elderly citizens who are not in a position to themselves make an effective protest.

This is what Opposition members set out to do and this is exactly what they have done. They used these scare tactics before on the assets test and they were proved wrong. This campaign will be proved wrong too. The main thrust of Opposition members is to scare people, to get them upset and to change their vote. However, it will not work because after a time, when this program gets under way, they will find that people will accept it and they will be very grateful for it. These scare tactics have caused quite a bit of trouble in my office. It has caused a lot of trouble to the residents of Dunkley.

I take this opportunity to apologise to them all for the trouble that the Liberal Party and some unscrupulous nursing home owners have caused them. Someone has put a lot of work into going around and asking people to sign petitions for me to present here. However, I could not present the petition-and I apologise for this to them all-to Parliament because it was worded incorrectly. I have taken it to the office of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). He has seen it and I have brought it to his attention.

I can assure them all that I will be writing to each and every one of them pointing out that the trouble that they have gone to has not been caused by the Labor Government but by the conservative side of politics. The honourable member for Richmond quoted from a letter from the Voluntary Care Association. I do not know what letter he had but I would like to quote from the Voluntary Care Association of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. The letter written by Mr Keats states:

My Association is extremely concerned at rumours that are circulating in the industry that the Federal Government is contemplating a weakening of its position to introduce a national uniform policy for Nursing and Personal Care arrangements in nursing homes across Australia based on assessed needs.
We are not weakening. He can be assured that what we have said we will implement. The letter goes on:

I need not remind you of the extent and depth of the consultations, the number of submissions and the broad spectrum of input from across the entire community that resulted in, and subsequently stemmed from, the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review. Out of this has evolved the Care Aggregate Module.
This letter is from the Voluntary Care Association and it supports what we are doing. The last paragraph of the letter states:

The consumers of aged care in nursing homes must be the ones to lose out in the long term if anything less than a uniform national position is adopted. Many of us now designing policy may be residents in such facilities in the years ahead, but it would be an indictment of us as responsible Australian citizens to back away from anything less than equity in the quality of care for our elderly people. There are no cheap options when it comes to making proper provisions for the needs of our senior citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —We agree with that.

—I am glad that the honourable member agrees with it. That sentence encapsulates what we are about. We are trying to give equity and proper facilities to our elderly. I have another letter from the Australian Council on the Ageing dated 22 April. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: ACOTA broadly supports the proposals contained in the statement as they are clearly in the best interests of older people. We are concerned, however, that some of the more controversial proposals are being used to create anxiety in the minds of nursing homes residents and their families.

That is what the Opposition is all about-anxiety and fear. It is the only way the Opposition members can get anything into the papers these days. They create some sort of controversy to scare people. As I said before, it amazes me that we have such an Opposition here. Words fail me in regard to the Opposition. The Government's strategy involves a combination of funding, legislative and policy changes which will significantly affect all elements of aged care.

Our philosophy is that aged people should, as far as possible, be supported in their homes and in their communities. One has to look only at the home and community care program that is in operation to know we have changed things recently. We will continue to support people to live in their own homes as long as possible. Aged people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to their needs. Services should promote rehabilitation for residents. The manner in which services are provided should develop and enhance personal freedom and independent functions of all residents. Services should be based on a recognition that for many people a move to a less supported residential service or to a community based support vehicle would be possible and desirable.

Our Government has done much for our aged. There is a lot more to do. They have been left in neglect for many years and we are all aware of the changing circumstances in the demographics of our society. We have a lot more work to do. We are starting these reforms. I am certain that they will assist many people in the latter stages of their lives. The major reforms that the Bill introduces in brief are: better quality of care; lower fees; improved training for the care givers; an extra $130m which is not a cut; increased hours of care of up to 27 hours per week; funding based only on need; 4,000 beds set aside for short term respite care; crackdown on fraud by a minority of nursing home operators; and legally enforceable consumer rights for all those residents.

I repeat: the Opposition has based its whole case on trying to induce fear and anxiety in the community. We are out to refute this and I tell all those who are listening to this debate tonight that this Government is about providing fair and equitable services to all within our community-not just a few.
