DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As shadow Minister for Health I rise to speak specifically about clause 30 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill as it relates to matters of health insurance. Before making my few remarks on that I shall refer to the remarks of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), on a line which has now been flagged to us because of the interjections that have been made from various areas, that the nasty old Opposition is actually going out to scare people.
—That is right.

—I hope before this speech is over to be able to read the honourable member some of the Press releases the Government has been putting out recently on the health policies and proposals that I have raised. The Press releases have been specifically aimed at scaring people. The Government has been telling the elderly they will be charged more. It has been telling women of child bearing age they will be charged more when in fact I have stood in this Parliament on a personal explanation and told people that is not the case and has never been my intention. So if honourable members opposite want to criticise people for scaring--
—Is this the Bill you are talking about?
—I am responding to the remarks that were made a few minutes ago. If you want to talk about scaring, play the game.
—Order! The honourable gentleman might address his remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I do address my remarks through you and I point out to you, on the matter of relevance, that before I rose a moment ago we were starting to get to a debate on the leadership of the National Party of Australia. I am now referring to and commenting on the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dunkley. Of course, we will get this rotated. We know the rule that exists in the Australian Labor Party: if one repeats things often enough someone eventually believes them. Of course, this principle was first expounded by Mr Goebbels. Labor has picked it up and in the first Government speech on this Bill tonight we were told time and time again, `You are trying to scare people'. Honourable members opposite can try scaring people but they should not be so hypocritical as a party as to suggest that they are not doing it now. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) nearly every day puts out a Press release making this statement. It is totally untrue and it is contrary to the remarks I have made.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—It is starting to hurt, is it?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, time is limited. I am wondering whether the honourable member for O'Connor is going to talk about the Bill at all tonight.

—Order! I construe the honourable gentleman's point of order to be on the matter of relevance. He might express it more precisely on future occasions. The honourable member for O'Connor is enjoying the indulgence extended to the honourable member for Dunkley to make a few remarks by way of preface. The honourable member for O'Connor is responding to the remarks of the honourable member for Dunkley. I am sure that he has virtually exhausted his responses and now will become more relevant to the Bill.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is certainly my intention. I wish to talk about clause 30 and to point out to the House that it deals with an instrument applicable to the health insurance industry; namely, the pre-existing ailment rule. As far as I can gather, since we have had health insurance there has been a pre-existing ailment rule for people entering a health insurance arrangement for the first time. The rule says that when one joins one must wait 12 months before one can be refunded, rebated or receive a benefit for any ailment that one had at the time of joining the fund. The law is specific on this. It refers to having signs or symptoms at the time of joining. One does not necessarily have to have identified those signs or symptoms; that is established by a medical referee if there is a dispute. There is a very good reason: health is a little different from one's house burning down. It is improper for a person to think that he can wait until he has an illness before he joins a fund. Health insurance is very much about the healthy subsidising the sick, and of course it would not work under those arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, prior to 1984 another simple principle applied that said that if one was insured but chose to change to another fund it was reasonable not to have the pre-existing ailment rule apply. One was insured and just wanted to change the company with which one was doing business. That seemed quite reasonable. Unfortunately, it did suffer a problem. Historically, the longer a fund is established and the longer the contributors stay in that fund, the more likely the contributors are to be ill. They get older and, as we know, it is primarily the elderly in our community who put demands on the health system. What occurred prior to 1984 was the establishment of a very large new fund, namely Medibank Private. There is evidence that some of the other funds suddenly discovered that the new starters in health insurance were going off to this new fund because they perceived it as offering better benefits, lower premiums or whatever.

All of a sudden, some of the established funds saw their portfolios getting out of balance. They no longer had sufficient young, non-claiming contributors to balance the costs of the older, claiming contributors. They took a simple solution. It is known in the industry as dumping. They started to induce or encourage-or by just plain bad service, discourage people from renewing their membership-people to join the other fund and take their illnesses with them, since there was no pre-existing ailment rule when transferring from one fund to another. That became a problem to the extent that in 1984 this Government decided to apply the pre-existing ailment rule to transferring from one fund to another. There is evidence that to stop the process of dumping, people were being offered one year's free contribution to the new fund if they would shift. Other inducements were offered to private hospitals and other places to encourage long-time chronically ill patients to leave.

What the amendments before us tonight, in clause 30, propose to do is go back to the situation pre-1984, because another new player has entered the field, a firm called Health Australia. I am not sure where Medibank Private stands presently in the debate because it is now about 12 years old and is probably halfway down the track to the problems I have explained. The older funds are claiming publicly that Health Australia is taking all their good non-claiming business and they are unable to operate and that Health Australia should be prepared to take a higher proportion of the high claimers. That is quite a simple proposition and one with which the Opposition agrees. We believe in the right of the consumer to have that choice, for whatever reason.

Unfortunately, we have some difficulties with what the Government has done. We understand the situation, for instance, that the current pre-existing ailment rule requirement creates a situation where some chronically ill patients are locked into a fund which they would like to leave. A circumstance which was drawn to my attention the other day was of a husband and wife with a family membership, with one being quite healthy and one having a pre-existing ailment-yet neither can shift. Coming back to the point, the Opposition agrees with the rights of consumers to shift. The Government has attempted, nevertheless, to resolve the problem of dumping. It wishes to give people this right, whilst recognising the opportunity for one fund to dump on another. There is quite a lot of argument. It does not matter to which fund one talks, it will always say that someone is dumping or is going to dump on it.

But whilst the Government has recognised the problem of dumping, it has failed to use this legislation to guarantee that dumping will not occur. Consequently, I foreshadow an amendment that I will move during the committee debate which is aimed purely and simply at tightening the legislation to ensure that dumping does not occur. I expect the Government to agree that it also does not wish to encourage this improper practice. The reason the Opposition feels it necessary for us to tighten the legislation is our almost amazement at the cavalier fashion in which the Government has approached this problem. One of the companies most likely to be dumped upon is Medibank Private.

There is another problem in all of this, which I will attend to in a moment. Firstly, let me point out that the Government has two propositions in this legislation which attempts to stop dumping. The first is that if a contributor chooses voluntarily to move from one fund to another-presumably a contributor would do so because the benefits available at the second fund are better than those offered by the fund he is in-the contributor must do so with the understanding that, for the first 12 months he is a member of the new fund, that fund will be obliged to pay him benefits only at the rate applicable in the fund that he has just left. So he does not get an additional benefit for the first 12 months.

In those circumstances one would wonder why someone would want to leave a fund. This brings us back to dumping. Because many people, particularly the elderly, have traditional links with their insurance companies, I do not think many people will leave voluntarily. The funds that believe that this will be their salvation will be sorely disappointed, unless they resort to dumping. So the first point is that people are to be discouraged somewhat from leaving a fund, which I think is reasonably fair. Secondly, the Government has said that funds will not dump. There are two clauses to this effect in the Bill. They are very simple. Clause 30 (lg) states:
The organisation-
meaning a fund-
will not, and will not authorise or induce another person to:
(i) offer to a contributor to a health benefits fund conducted by the organisation an inducement; or
(ii) subject, or threaten to subject, such a contributor to a penalty or disadvantage;
for the purpose of encouraging the contributor to cease to contribute to the fund conducted by the organisation and become a contributor to a health benefits fund conducted by another organisation.

End of story. There is no apparent penalty for a fund that undertakes this disgraceful dumping procedure. The point about that is quite remarkable. The Government might be prepared to argue that that is not the case. It would refer us to section 73ba of the National Health Act, which refers to the schedule we are amending in this legislation. It states:

The registration of an organization shall, whether the registration was effected before, or is effected after, the commencement of this section, be deemed to be subject to the conditions set out in the Schedule.

A simple explanation of that is that if someone is a naughty boy and breaks the rule of the schedule which we are amending tonight the Government will take his registration away. That sounds like a powerful weapon, but it is a feather. The Government will never do it. To deregister one of the large health funds in Australia would be to tell all its contributors that they are out on the street, that they have to go somewhere else. The Government would not do it. So the funds, if they chose to do so, could go on dumping. The Government does not appear to be putting in place any mechanisms to identify whether funds are doing so. It has not chosen a proper mechanism to stop them.

As a solution to this situation our amendment makes an offence of dumping. It inserts the necessary financial penalty. The financial penalty suggested in my amendment is a $10,000 fine for the first offence and $100,000 thereafter. The Government might be astounded to think that we would suggest figures of that size but let me put it to the Government that the getting rid of one chronically ill patient could represent a saving to the expenditures of a health fund of between $5,000 and $10,000 a week. It is big stakes. The penalty must be appropriate. For the Government to suggest that it will have policemen checking whether funds are dumping is most unlikely. A big fund would laugh at the Government because it would not have the courage to deregister the fund any more than this Opposition in government would have the courage to do so. The Government lacks this courage. We need to have a financial penalty to make it fair.

I hope that the Government can see the merit in what I am proposing. I will describe the details of the amendment during the committee stage. It is quite simple. It also tightens up considerably on the dumping provisions. We propose four subclauses here, as compared with the two that I have read out to the House. This is truly an attempt by the Opposition to accommodate the Government.

I think I have explained this clause in a way that can be understood, but I would defy anybody other than a highly qualified lawyer to draw the correct conclusion from reading it. It is a most complex and remarkable thing. It refers to comparable funds and is very confusing. I wish that it was not so confusing, but that is beside the point. I got a briefing from the department, and I believe that I understand it quite clearly. My immediate reaction on reading the clause was to say that it was a fraud. We know why in 1984 the Government introduced the pre-existing ailment rule for people transferring from one fund to another. It was because dumping was occurring, primarily, on Medibank Private, and I think it will again.

Let me point out another consequence of dumping and the objective of those funds that so badly want this arrangement. As I say, apart from the matter of dumping I do not know why they are so frantic to get it. Clearly, it is not in the interests of their contributors. It is not very often in business one can tell one's customers to leave. But the reality is that under this proposal the contributor in year one gains nothing. As to meeting the objectives of the other funds, I have had correspondence with them, and they say that they want the rates stabilised-I am afraid to say, stabilised upwards.

In Victoria-I address my remarks particularly to honourable members from Victoria-where Health Australia and Medibank Private are the big competitors, the market leaders, if the other funds can force them, by dumping, to take a huge percentage of extra claimers the premium levels of their contributors will rise, as will the premium levels of those people who have just shifted over for the cheaper premiums. So, this measure is not very smart, and it is less smart for the people who have to explain it to all those in Victoria in particular who have bought cheaper insurance for the very obvious reason why we all might do so.

What we are saying is that the Government should protect its legislation. If it believes that it is necessary to go back for the purpose of giving people a better choice, to give people the right to transfer from one fund to another without application to the pre-existing ailment rule, the Opposition will support it. However, we call on the Government to support our proposal to toughen up and guarantee that there will be no dumping. I have talked to the representatives of the funds that want this. They have told me that that is quite satisfactory. They say that they have no intention of breaking the law, and consequently do not have to be frightened by the fines. That is a very satisfactory position as far as I am concerned. I do not want any of them in court; I do not want any of them dumping on the other funds. I ask the Parliament to consider that, as I think it is most important.

I shall conclude my remarks by reading from a Press release put out on 20 April by the Minister for Community Services and Health. I also have some other news cuttings here, one of which states `Health proposal labelled shonky'. The news release from the Minister states:

Mr Tuckey would do better to stop misleading the medical profession and instead try to explain his disastrous health proposals which would result in women in their child-bearing years, the chronically ill and the elderly paying far more for their health care.

I have pointed out that that is in complete conflict with my remarks and the explanation that I have given in this Parliament, but the Minister is still making such statements. I do not want any further mention of a policy of scaring people. Honourable members opposite have made an art form of scaring people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill is aimed at rectifying anomalies in the funding and operation of the nursing home system in Australia. These anomalies have for many years come under criticism from the nursing home owners and managers, from residents and their families, and from staff and other groups involved in the nursing home industry. The anomalies include unfair distribution of funds, poor standards of care in many homes, inconsistent levels of staffing, inappropriateness of the amount of kind of care provided for many individual residents, and the lack of flexibility and discretion accorded nursing home management and directors of nursing.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill addresses these problems and its provisions are based on a careful and comprehensive two-year study into the Australian nursing home system. The passage and implementation of this Bill will mean that for the first time the aged in Australia will benefit from a system of geriatric assessment and nursing home funding which is rational, accountable, consistent and, above all, fair. Under the new system every aged person in Australia, irrespective of his or her socio-economic status or place of residence, will enjoy equal opportunity of access to the kind of care which is appropriate to his or her degree of dependence.

I would like to concentrate my remarks on the situation that prevails in my own State of South Australia. The prospect of these new provisions has caused a fair amount of consternation over the last few weeks among people involved in some way with nursing homes in that State. In particular, in my own electorate of Hawker hundreds of people have approached me, in person, by phone or by mail, expressing concern at an anticipated fall in the number of hours of care provided in South Australian nursing homes. I must say that I share their concern for the future care of our aged citizens in South Australia. But study of the Bill has convinced me that the present and future residents of South Australian nursing homes will in fact be better off under these new provisions.

The perceived problem in South Australia derives from the fact that that State has hitherto been receiving a disproportionately large slice of national funding for nursing homes. Per capita funding to South Australia-and also to Victoria-has been higher than in other States. This was caused largely by stricter regulations and conditions set by the State governments in those States. With new nationally standardised systems of assessment and funding, it is a fact that the average number of nursing and personal care hours for nursing home residents will fall slightly in South Australia. If the new arrangements were implemented in full on 1 July 1988, and assuming the nursing home population was the same then as in November 1987, the average nursing and personal care hours funded in the State for homes with more than 20 beds would be reduced from 19.8 to 17.8 hours a week.

However, the new system of nursing and personal care hours is being phased in and this reduction will occur very gradually. But we need not be too concerned about this reduction in the average number of hours in South Australia, because under the new system the funded hours-although fewer-will be distributed more fairly and appropriately amongst the nursing home population.

What are the benefits which will accrue to South Australian nursing home residents under these new provisions? First, nursing and personal care funding will for the first time match the individual needs of individual residents. This means that South Australian nursing home residents will be funded for up to 27 hours per week of nursing and personal care, based on their dependency level and individual care needs. The most dependent residents will receive funding support of either 27 or 23.5 hours of care per week in all cases. This new funding system will replace a scheme which until now has produced a 91 per cent mismatch between funding and resident needs. In other words, only 9 per cent of South Australian nursing home residents have been receiving the proper level of care. Some South Australian home proprietors have been receiving funds far in excess of their residents' care needs and of the services provided by the home. The corollary of this is, of course, that there has been a substantial underfunding and hardship for other residents in South Australian homes.

This new legislation is fairer and more equitable and will ensure that all aged people will receive the number of hours of care that they need. In addition, as average South Australian residents' dependency levels increase in the future, the new funding system based on individual needs will automatically increase the average hours funded for South Australian residents. In addition, this new funding system will ensure 24-hour registered nurse care in every home. Until now many homes have not had a registered nurse on duty at night in particular. This legislation makes special provisions to enable homes to provide this essential service. From now on every nursing home director will, for each resident, be provided with at least one hour per week of time available for his or her role as manager of nursing and personal care. This will allow him or her to dedicate an appreciable amount of time to the planning of care arrangements, the guidance and direction of staff and staff training and development.

In addition, a program of gerontic training will be funded with $0.3m provided for this purpose throughout the State. A management support consultancy will be commenced to assist directors of nursing and nursing home administrators to find the most appropriate management arrangements for the provision of nursing and personal care services under the new system.

To assist aged people to secure the most appropriate care to meet their needs there will be a substantial expansion in geriatric assessment. The total outlay on assessment in South Australia will be increased by 475 per cent, from $0.4m in 1987-88 to $2.3m in 1990-91. To assist in funding services to meet exceptional needs, including the blind and members of ethnic and Aboriginal communities, additional funding of $0.9m will be provided over three years in South Australia.

I have left until last possibly the most important benefit of these new arrangements for South Australian senior citizens, that is, by 1991 no nursing home resident in South Australia will have to pay more than 87.5 per cent of his or her pension, plus rent assistance, for nursing home accommodation. At present almost 30 per cent of South Australian nursing home residents have to pay more than this minimum, often with great difficulty, because most residents rely on the pension for financial support. Some nursing home residents of my acquaintance are paying double the aged pension for their nursing home care. The fact that from 1991 no resident will pay more than 87.5 per cent of his or her pension for this accommodation will be greatly welcomed by senior citizens in South Australia and by their families.

I stress that the funding reforms in South Australian nursing homes will be phased in gradually to minimise any disruption. Initially the new funding system will apply only to new nursing home residents, that is, residents entering homes from 1 July 1988. Special transition arrangements and additional funding will apply for some nursing homes with 20 beds or less-and they provide 5 per cent of nursing home beds in South Australia-in order to protect the quality of care for residents in these homes. The effect of the new reforms will be thoroughly monitored in close consultation with the South Australian nursing home industry, including directors of nursing and consumers, and the program will be reviewed at the end of the first year of operation.

We also make a commitment that in the first year of operation there will be no reduction in Commonwealth funding support for nursing and personal care for any current resident of a South Australian nursing home-even in those homes where funding under the system being replaced by these reforms has far exceeded residents' needs. As regards nursing home staff, there is expected to be a substantial increase in jobs in nursing homes and hostels over the next five years after some minor reductions between 1989 and 1991. The reforms are expected to have little, if any, immediate impact on South Australian nursing and personal care job numbers. Taking account of the steady growth in dependency levels and the expansion of total nursing home and hostel care, there is expected to be a small increase next year in total residential care employment of about 35 jobs throughout the State. In 1989-90 there will be a small decline of about 60. However, from then on there will be substantial job growth in nursing and personal care with over 90 extra jobs expected to be created in 1991-92 and 340 in 1992-93.

To summarise, I am sure that these points will convince the people of South Australia that in the long run they will have nothing to worry about from these reforms. The Opposition has indicated that the current system contains anomalies and it has criticised the steps that we are taking to address them but no-one opposite has said what he would do to address these anomalies. No-one has given us one glimmer of insight into the Opposition's aged care policy. The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) told us nothing and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) told us nothing. I invite the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods), who I believe will follow me in this debate, to tell us all about the Opposition's nursing home and aged care policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join my colleagues in addressing the House on the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill, which has significance for all of us. We are all victims of the ageing process and none of us, even with modern technology, can avoid it. I believe that all Australians in their old age can expect at the very least a number of basic rights. They should expect that the government of the day has the foresight and the compassion to ensure the establishment of a sufficient infrastructure to cater for their special needs. I believe that every honourable member in this House would share the view that they have a right to access to a nursing home, to quality of care, to affordable care, and to freedom of choice. In terms of access, surely no-one would doubt that people have the right to spend their last years in dignity and comfort, cared for appropriately. In fact, under this Government there is an increasing shortage of hostels and nursing homes as a result of the curtailment of licences. Obviously, that has been implemented as a cost saving exercise by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The views of the industry have clearly been ignored over the past four or five years. The elderly have been pushed back up the pipeline into the community, in many cases inappropriately.

Perhaps more important than access in many ways is the quality of care that the frail aged receive in a nursing home. Of concern in this regard is the outcome. According to the report of the Victorian Aged Services Peak Council Survey over the past few months, 60 per cent of patients in nursing homes could not control either their bowels or their bladder, but only 20 per cent were washed daily. The obvious interpretation is that two in five patients were lying in soiled clothes for days on end. Why is this? There is only one explanation-reduced staffing levels. Who controls staffing levels? It is the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) and his Department that control the staffing levels. Who has been vetoing new staff? This Government, this Minister and this Department have. Who is responsible? Clearly, this Government is responsible for the outcomes that have been referred to in the Victorian report.

How appalling is the admission by the Minister, confirmed by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), that of all nursing home residents only 9 per cent receive appropriate care. The Government is almost proud of that. Ninety-one per cent of patients are not receiving appropriate care. How can we trust any government which has been in power for five years and which is presiding over that sort of inconsistency? The honourable member for Dunkley read a list of problems. It was very kind of him to do that. He imputed that that was from a member of the Opposition, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) in particular. I point out that that was a list of the recommendations, the fears and the anxieties of a Commonwealth-State working party on nursing home standards from an independent organisation, the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations.

Let me repeat those concerns. The working party envisaged that meals might become a production line procedure as a time saving measure and that lack of staff might lead to regular individual maintenance programs being decreased, with an increase of incontinence and the consequent bedsores. General hygiene might be allowed to lapse, with outbreaks of skin problems, mouth ulcers and eye infections. These are not my words; they are the words of an independent, highly respected association. It was concerned that contractions might result from reduced stimulation and exercise, that communication with families might become difficult and that patients might become withdrawn because of the lack of staff to organise social interaction. Why might all this happen? Why are there these concerns? It is because of staffing levels. These seem to be valid concerns raised by the people who are most familiar with these problems and who deal with the problems of the aged. The Government somehow seems to think that in drafting this Bill it can just ignore that advice.

What about affordability? Surely that is a basic right. By the time Australian people reach old age they are entitled to believe that their full medical and social needs are provided for, and the expectation is that nursing home places will be paid for by 87.5 per cent of the pension together with a subsidy. However, at present, according to the Minister's own figures, 23 per cent, or 17,000 patients, have to find other sources of payment to meet the bills.

In my constituency, for example, 85-year-old Martha Whateley has been at a local nursing home for seven years. Her brother, John Ollerton of Homebush, has been marvellous in looking after her. She is well cared for in the home but, because his sister's pension no longer covers her fees, he, as a pensioner himself, is obliged to make up the difference. The problem is that in the five months up to January this year the age pension increased by a measly $20 a fortnight, but because of the increasing costs of Government-scheduled fees, the rise in fees was $80 a fortnight.

Where are pensioners at this stage of their lives to find an extra $60 a fortnight? Where is it to come from? Obviously the Government expects friends and family to come forward with the money to save pensioners from the spiralling costs. For people in Mr Ollerton's situation it is emotional blackmail. He cares dearly for his sister, but will not be able to care for her himself, so he will find the money from various sources. It is another example of the Government's desperate attempt to balance its Budget at the expense of people who have paid tax all their lives. I do not know how the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) can complain about costs to pensioners when it is her Government that has produced these problems.

What about freedom of choice? We believe that everybody who has made provision for their old age and their retirement should be able to have freedom of choice of nursing homes. What happens? A person is not allowed to pay a little extra and go into a home with a few more comforts, such as an extra colour television or a few extra armchairs, unless that person happens to be one of the 6 per cent this Minister has designated. Six per cent is all that this Minister will allow to have extra comforts. This is the politics of envy. It is socialism gone mad. It is reduction to the lowest common denominator, bringing everybody else down to the same level. Why should somebody, because he has saved a little money, not have a bit of comfort? The Australian Labor Party does not believe in people looking for themselves.

What about these particular proposals? As we have heard already, the care aggregate module, which is the basis of funding, now means that every week on every nursing home patient in Australia a form will be completed assessing the nursing requirements of patients-a so-called residential classification instrument (RCI). Each form asks for 12 questions. Thus, with 75,000 patients there will be 3.9 million forms and answers to 46.8 million questions in the first year. Those are the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—The honourable member may well laugh. He may well despair as to who will review those forms. It will be another army of public servants. This Government is trying to improve the unemployment problem by employing people to look after 46.8 million questions a year. What sort of efficiency is that? What about the RCI? It looks at transfers, walking, toilets, dressing, eating, continence. One adds up the points and divides people into categories-not according to needs but to a mathematical model. Under this Government people just another statistic.

SPEECH.PARA: My grandmother died very slowly over a matter of months.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that those opposite do not understand about caring about grandmothers. They have no concern about my grandmother or any other elderly people. Certainly the honourable member for Hawker has no compassion in this matter. My late grandmother was in a foetal position for many months while she was slowly dying. She did not need transfers because she was stuck in bed; she did not need ambulatory care. She did not need toilet assistance, she had a catheter in all the time. She needed bathing. She did not need any dressing as she never got out of bed. She needed some help with eating, she needed attention to pressure areas and a fair amount of attention in those respects. She needed no special nursing in terms of diabetic care or anything similar. She had no behavioural problems-she was ga-ga for the last three months. But by the categories this Government has devised, she would be in categories four or five. She would be shifted out to a hostel for independent people to look after themselves. Yet Labor members try to support such legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the additional hour a week therapy? What sort of therapy will a person get in an hour a week? In that time one can just about cut somebody's toenails. This is a major concern. The Government is categorising patients not in a real way, but just according to a mathematical model.

What about respite care? We welcomed the principle of increased funds for respite care in regard to patients and carers, and then we saw that only two in every 1,000 aged people would benefit. We certainly welcome the principle, but we urge the Government to expand the benefits. There have been regular complaints from the Minister via the Press about inappropriate admissions. These are not a reality. In one study in Victoria, supposedly the worst affected State, there was one in 500 inappropriate admissions. Yet still the Minister puts out Press releases attacking the so-called voracious nursing home owners.

In summary, we agree with the general direction of this policy. Unfortunately, we do not agree with the way it has been implemented. We strongly believe that the enacting of this legislation as it stands will lead to a number of terribly difficult problems for nursing home patients all over Australia. For those reasons I support the amendment put forward by the honourable member for Richmond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —About five weeks ago I had a private conversation with the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples). We spoke about the introduction of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill, and I told him that not only is it good and important legislation for the progress of aged care in Australia, but that he should maintain his resolve against the campaign that would be waged against this Bill. He said, `It will not be that bad; it will not be any worse than what happened with the assets test or the fringe benefits tax-the sort of stuff they usually go on with.' I said, `No, you have to be prepared for a real dose this time. When we get to the aged care and nursing home legislation they will drag up the dregs of the drivel.' Are we seeing it! I told the Minister that we would hear about the old ladies in the beds, the same people that the Opposition told to put their money in tins under the beds or we would get it all. I said that Opposition members would sink to the depths of depravity in the use of scare tactics against aged people. Tonight, we are hearing every single word of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the speech earlier tonight by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). Let us look at his Press statement of 23 March. Talk about the depths of depravity! Listen to this: He said that we would be forcing nursing homes to wash patients less often. He said that patients would be left in bed longer, that more chemical and physical retraints would be used, and that communication with patients and families would be cut. I invite the Minister to listen to this next one. The honourable member for Richmond said that there would be a need to implement production line feeing. Can honourable members believe that? Then the honourable member referred to the use, for instance, of non-individual continence maintenance. I am amazed that honourable members opposite can even spell words such as that.

I describe those kinds of statements as the slimiest of slop. We knew that that sort of thing would get wheeled in in this aged care debate. We have just heard from the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods)-the apprentice at work. Even the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) was embarrassed to hear that slop served up in the House because he knows-and I will talk about his contribution shortly-that it was just too far over the odds.

Earlier tonight, the honourable member for Richmond said that all these nursing homes would go into liquidation. To the best of my knowledge, despite all his claims, no nursing home in Australia-not one-has been forced to close its doors. Where proprietors who have been dudding the system have gone to the wall, who has picked up the tab? Where were the private sector rip-off merchants rushing in to fix it up? The Government has picked up the tab. The Minister has had to come in and pick up the tab when these unscrupulous nursing home proprietors have gone out the back door. Tonight we are hearing the slimiest of slop. It is aimed at the people in our community who are least able to defend themselves against it, and I take great offence at these remarks.

We hear talk about the devastation that will be caused to the nursing home industry. Let me take as an example the fringe benefits tax legislation. Honourable members opposite rushed into this House and told us about all those restaurants based on the tax rip-off that would close down. However, the evidence since that tax reform has been that the industry is thriving. We cannot train enough people to service the restaurant industry. New courses are being conducted at the Broadmeadows Technical and Further Education College in my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent college.

—As the honourable member for Dunkley says, it is an excellent college. The new course there teaching and preparing people for the restaurant industry cannot keep up with the demand. This sort of scare drivel from honourable members opposite goes on time after time, and we have heard it again tonight in the nursing home debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the honourable member for Richmond, when he talks about these things: Where have you been? Where was he when the unscrupulous nursing home proprietors were ripping off families and little old ladies and all that sort of thing, requiring us to clean up the legacy of the previous coalition Government? Where was he when member of the previous Government were telling families that their relatives in nursing homes were okay when they were starving and barely alive? Where was he when people were being attracted to these homes and being told that they were being set up under a proper policy of housing and aged care? Let us take an example in my electorate. Where was the honourable member when the Daylesford Hostel was set up and left sitting there empty and without funding for nearly two years? Who had to pick up the tab? This Government did. Now, of course, the Daylesford Hostel is a model and the people there are very proud of the way in which it has been developed. Let us not have any more of these allegations; let us have rational debate. Let us understand something that neither the honourable member for Richmond nor the honourable member for Lowe seem to understand-that we on the Government benches are faced with a strange situation at the moment. Those who claim to relate closely to some of these people, such as the care providers associations and other lobby groups, are now racing to knock on our doors and tell us not to take any notice of their previous complaints. They have been saying, `Now that we understand the legislation, there is no need to take any notice of our complaints.' They are telling us to ignore their own complaints and representations. That is what has been going on.

Let me set a couple of comments straight. There has been talk about a proposed decline in the number of hours. Questions have been asked as to why the Government has not responded to demands from industry groups for an average of 27 hours. It is absolute nonsense to talk about nursing and personal care in terms of averages. The point is to provide hours on the basis of need. The new arrangement will provide 27 hours a week for residents with high service needs. When honourable members opposite talk about 10 hours, they should realise that this applies to residents in a nursing home who are in the lowest category of need. There will be care provided on the basis of need. It does no-one in this Parliament any credit to come in here and talk drivel like the drivel we heard from the honourable member for Richmond who talked about washing people less and leaving them in their beds longer and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fear tactics!
—Scaremongering!

—As the honourable member for Dunkley and my other colleagues have said, this is simply another re-run of the Opposition's tactics of scaring the elderly. It is the assets test revisited. When we heard all that stuff about the assets test from Opposition members, what were they trying to do? They were trying to protect what turned out to be only 2 1/2 per cent of pensioners-people such as the late Sir William McMahon, the former Prime Minister, a millionaire who was getting the full pension. They talk about relating to a traditional base. I will tell honourable members something-they have not left theirs. The honourable member for Lowe spoke tonight of those nursing home proprietors that he knows and relates to. When they spoke of the assets test they were talking about millionaires getting pensions. They have not lost their traditional base. They are right with those who have been ripping off the system; that is the way it has gone.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at this Bill in context. As I said to the Minister several weeks ago, the whole home and community care policy of which this forms part is good and is widely understood and welcomed in the community. The principal priority of the community is that the elderly, our aged family members, should be able to stay in their own homes with help such as meals on wheels, the visiting district nurses and all the rest of the services that we have in the country and city areas. That is the first priority-not sticking them in nursing homes to be victims of extortion. Let them stay home; let them stay with their relatives and let us give them supporting care. Then, when they reach the point where that no longer becomes possible, they can move into a hostel where they are still independent, still able to help themselves to a certain extent but need care on hand. Then, down the track, when they reach the stage of needing nursing home care that is when they should go to such homes. Under this Bill that will be the sort of progress.

I point our that in my electorate, a local committee at Bacchus Marsh has asked the Government to change a grant. We have granted nursing home beds in Bacchus Marsh, but the committee has now asked us if we will reconsider and give them hostel beds instead. The people in Bacchus Marsh understand the stages; they understand the policy. They are asking us if they can go to that other stage because it is a better one. I must say to the Minister that I will be constantly knocking on the door until we agree to it, because I fully support it.

I want to refer to another couple of points before I end my speech. I will be brief because I know that time is limited. I noticed an article on the front page of the Australian Financial Review today. As I often say, this is not some sort of Labor Party propaganda rag; It is the paper of the business people, of the Establishment. On the front page there is a big story that the Liberals are to go for new talent. After one has heard the slop that has been dished up in the House tonight, one can understand why that should be so. I quote from the article:

Mr Elliott, the Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, and the Federal director of the Liberal Party . . . have been working on a strategy aimed at building up the organisational strength of the Liberal Party to match--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is not addressing the Bill that is before the House. I ask him to return to the terms of the Bill.
—I will, Mr Deputy Speaker. I just want to complete this point so that you may see its relevance.
—No, I ask the honourable member to return to the terms of the Bill now.

—I will return to the terms of the Bill. Amendments are proposed to this Bill. Points have been put forward by people who do not understand the policy, who are using a tactic of scaring aged people. They are the very people who are highlighted on the front page of the Australian Financial Review as needing to be replaced because the Liberal Party has to recruit more talent.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor in his contribution regarding clause 30 made certainly one of the most rational and substantial contributions that I have heard him make in the House. I give him credit for that. I say to him that I am quite sure that the comments he made about clause 30 will get a very sympathetic hearing from the Minister and that there might be a lesson for him to learn-that is, that an opposition has a role to play in this House in giving constructive criticism and assistance where possible. When it does that we are prepared to listen and cooperate. I am sure that the honourable member will welcome that. That is why I say he was intensely embarrassed to hear the drivel and slop of those on the other side of the House who deprecated the contribution that he made. If there is a lesson to be learned from that by the honourable member for O'Connor, it is that he ought to do it a bit more often. Instead the irrational ravings he sometimes engages in, he should apply his mind to constructive criticism. He will then be listened to an taken seriously.

I make a final point which is again relevant to the contributions being made. Claims have been made tonight by members of the Opposition that not only will the standard of care be cut but also the availability of care will be cut. Claims made have been in Press releases that the Government was cutting funding when, in fact, as the Minister has announced in many forums and as has been repeated here tonight in many contributions by members on this side, funding has been increased by $130 million. That should be related to the other side of the story: we hear no policy and no constructive suggestions of any substance. Even the contribution from the honourable member for O'Connor was concerned totally with a clause related to Medicare funding. No policy, no contribution-just a claim that the Opposition will cut Government expenditure by $11 billion. Who would be the first cab off the rank in any cut of $11 billion? It would be the aged-those least able to fend for themselves. It would certainly not be the nursing home proprietors or the millionaires on pensions that the Opposition defended last time. I reject the Opposition's amendment. I totally support the Bill and I urge the Minister to maintain his resolve in the face of any drivel and implement this very advanced and progressive new aged care policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister for Housing and Aged Care) (11.25)-I appreciate that the hour is late and that this is the end of a three-week sitting period, but this has been a very important debate and I believe that I should respond to some of the comments made, mainly by the Opposition. The few honourable members on the Government side who had an opportunity to speak put their cases very well and, more importantly, put them accurately. Most of the points to which I will refer were raised by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). I refute the allegation that he makes constantly both in the House and outside that nursing home residents will be forced into hostels. He has said that in Press releases and in this place on a number of occasions. That is obviously not the case. It has never been the Government's intention and it has never been expressed as such in any way, shape or form. The Government has said that, over time, well into the 1990s, it is unlikely that the type of person in a nursing home today will be in a nursing home in the 1990s. We believe, and it is shown quite clearly, that people with lower levels of dependency on nursing and personal care will be able to have as they can have at this stage, a high quality of life-in fact, a higher quality of life- and an appropriate quality of care in a hostel.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Richmond asserted that the Government has not provided details of its $130m expenditure. I presume that he received some of the documents which he referred to a couple of times as being slick. If he had read the documents and had taken some time to find out what the issue was all about, he would have read at page 5 of a document entitled Building a better future-Government Policy on Aged Care a summary of the reform measures-the provision $65.7m over three years to provide the equivalent of almost an extra hour of care each week; $15m over three years to fund 24-hour registered general nurse coverage and funding for director of nursing administration time; $2.75m over three years to provide a nursing home training and reskilling package; $14.5m over three years for the geriatric assessment program--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not just table a detailed statement?

—The honourable member wanted to hear it. I am saying this for the benefit of the people who are listening to this debate. They had to listen to the honourable member. I am giving them the opportunity of finding out what is in the package, because the honourable member for Richmond does not really know. As part of the package, $5.8m will be provided over three years for the special services program to help homes meet the short term extraordinary care requirements for residents with very high service needs; $2.3m over three years to support small nursing homes catering for special needs groups, particularly those in remote areas and homes which cater for ethnic and Aboriginal groups; $8m to enable other small homes to restructure and rationalise through a range of measures; $2m to enable small homes to choose whether they wish to remain in the existing arrangements until March 1989 or to transfer to the new arrangements from 1 July 1988; $12.45m over three years to provide for improved respite care and alternative accommodation arrangements; $3.07m over three years to provide for improved protection of residents and improved monitoring arrangements; and so the list continues. That responds in part to the remarks of the honourable member for Richmond. Those figures have been available for quite a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Richmond also spoke of fraud. He made many assertions on behalf of various groups in the community. He seemed to make very few assertions of his own volition. Most were preceded by the words `I understand that' or `these groups have said'. That again really points to the fact that members of the Opposition just do not have any real policy or opinions of their own. The honourable member for Richmond quoted a figure of 36 seconds per hour, per day. What a way to break down time-36 seconds per hour, per day. Why did he not break it down further than that? Why did he not break it down to seconds per year or seconds per week? That is ridiculous. In this package most programs and resources are termed as hours per resident per week. But no, not the honourable member for Richmond and some of the other people he quoted. The imagery that those opposite put up is meant to scare. This Government has increased resources. Those opposite try to belittle it by trying to paint a picture of those resources to the population.

The honourable member for Richmond talked for a long time about the RCI, which he said was the resident care index or something. It is `resident classification instrument'. That just shows how little he understands of what this is really all about. He and others have said that there is no category 1, that it is very hard to find people in category 1. It has been quite common knowledge, except perhaps to the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and a lot of the other people who put out scare Press releases, that the Government has clearly indicated to the industry that if the weightings are necessary or if it is necessary to adjust the cut-off points to ensure that those who need to will get into category 1, that will be the case. The RCI, the resident classification instrument, will be used to classify nursing home residents into one to five categories of need, category 1 people being assessed as the most dependent and thus eligible for up to 27 hours of nursing and personal care per week. The honourable member for Richmond has said in the past in this House that the Government is apparently moving towards a standard of 17.1 hours per patient in the most critical case. That was never intended to be the case, and he knew it. But he goes on with that again.

After a very extensive period of consultations with professionals and with the industry the Government has said that 27 hours of nursing and personal care will be given to those in the most dependent category. Over the November trial of the RCI, directors of nursing identified some 10 per cent nationally of residents as being in category 1 and there were significant variations between the individual homes in the States.

The honourable member for Richmond has raised a lot of these issues. None of them has any basis in fact. He and others have talked about people with sensory deficits. We do not just measure a person who is blind as being blind. A person who is blind has certain care needs and certain things have to be done for him. A visual handicap is likely to have an impact on a whole range of activities that are covered under the resident classification instrument, such as assistance with washing, eating and walking. All these things are covered under the resident classification instrument. The honourable member for Richmond and the people on the other side who have run around this community frightening people either do not understand the resident classification instrument or they are deliberately misleading people. Which is it? That is the question that the people will have to work out for themselves. I believe that in the coming weeks, as people become more aware of it, they will work out what is really going on.

The honourable member alleged that the Government was phasing in this program in Victoria and South Australia to protect the Labor governments of those States. What have we got here? We have a person who is saying, `Bring in these changes overnight', which would cause a lot of disruption to people, or `Phase these things in'. It is phased in right across Australia. That is what this Government has been doing. It set about an eight-stage program from 1986.

We are now at stage 4 of that program-the most important part of the whole program-which is really phasing in a whole series of changes. It is a very complex industry. It is a very important industry. A lot of people work in the industry. A lot of these institutions are being run on behalf of charitable organisations or churches. There are about 75,000 people in nursing homes. We care about those people as well.

The honourable member for Richmond talked about mismatches. Of course, there have been mismatches. That is the basis of the problem we are facing. However, the system of the resident classification instrument which we are bringing in does away with that mismatch. The honour- able member for Lowe (Dr Woods) raised a point as well. He thought it was great that the Government was in a position where it was saying that it was not happy that only about one in 10 people were receiving appropriate care. I am glad he used the words `appropriate care' because what we have been saying is that about only one in 10 patients have been getting the care appropriate to their needs. The resident classification instrument system will give about 94 per cent accuracy in that regard.

The honourable member for Richmond did not rest at that point but made attacks on officers of the Department of Community Services and Health-attacks which he did not back up. This is something about which he has never spoken to me. But he is prepared to come into this Parliament and, without naming any officer in the Department, make a blanket assertion about people. He is prepared to besmear the names of officers of the Department of Community Services and Health. Again, what we are left with in the case of the honourable member for Richmond is no policy. Did any honourable member hear any policy? There was no policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I invite the Minister, if he wants to attack my character and demean my motives, to move a motion criticising me rather than indulge in this sort of criticism.
—There is no point of order.

—The honourable member went on to say that 950 beds were in liquidation. Not one nursing home bed in Victoria-I presume that is where he was talking about-has closed down because of anything that this Government has been doing. The beds that are in liquidation are mainly in the companies of two people. It is not the nursing homes that are running unprofitably. It is not the nursing homes that are in liquidation. It is the overall corporate structures of those people, as the honourable member well knows. The honourable member for Richmond made assertions against the Department and the Government on behalf of various groups. That is how he got out of most of his accusations tonight when he said that there was a manipulation of statistics. Again, there was no backup. And the honourable member talks about people not backing up their assertions!

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the honourable member for Lowe. As I understand it, the honourable member is a medical practitioner by profession. When I heard his speech my reaction was, `to think that the taxpayer has invested so many tens of thousands of dollars in educating him to care but all we get from him is scare'. That is all we got from the honourable member for Lowe. I believe that he is quite a disappointment. He said that the views of the industry had been ignored. I have plenty of documentation here which I could table or read into the record at any time specifying the views of industry in its involvement and consideration. For example, the NSW Nursing Home Chronicle of Friday, 11 March, stated in a review of the consultation process:
. . . we have at least had the good sense to recognise the willingness on the part of the Commonwealth bureaucracy to try to meet the need for communication as best as possible.
It further stated:
. . . we have been most appreciative of the manner in which the very senior officers of the Department have handled their portfolio in respect to communication with this Association.

There have been many many more statements such as those. Again, the honourable member for Lowe criticised the Government for officiating over a system which had been introduced by the Opposition when in government. It had had plenty of time to do something about the situation. The Auditor-General in 1981 brought this matter to the attention of those opposite. They ignored it. It was up to this Government, the Hawke Labor Government, to do something about it.

The honourable member criticised this Government for effectively having fees charged, over and above the pension, in nursing homes. I remind the honourable member for Lowe and other members of the Opposition, if they are not aware of the fact, that by 1991 no resident in a government-subsidised nursing home will have to pay more than 87.5 per cent of his or her pension, plus rent assistance. Mr Deputy Speaker, can you imagine what security, what comfort, that would give to the thousands of people out there who are now growing older, who will in those years, by 1991, be moving into nursing homes and who will not have to worry about the drain they may be on relatives or about whether they have enough savings to last out their lives in a nursing home? That is the social justice record of this Government in age care reform. People will learn to understand that in the coming weeks and the scare campaign that is going on will be put into oblivion.

The honourable member for Lowe referred to shifting people out of nursing homes. Throughout this debate, throughout everything that has been going on out in the community, we have not heard one word of policy from the Opposition. Those opposite have agreed with the principles of what we are doing, but we have not heard one word in here today of the age care policy of the Opposition. Those opposite do not have a policy. They have an age scare policy, not an age care policy. If the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is looking to shift people around on his front bench, I suggest that there are on the front bench people who should be put into other portfolios where they cannot hurt people. The Government's policy is very much coordinated and it is integrated with the home and community care program, the hostel program, the nursing home program and, in between those, to give it tremendous flexibility and support for people out in the community, the respite care program.

I thank honourable members, particularly those members on the Government side of the House, who have contributed to this debate. Government members, both in the House and and generally in Caucus, have given tremendous support all the way for this nursing home reform program, which will go on to 1992. That support will earn them at this stage and in future stages, as it has in the past, the respect of their constituents. They know that they will have the support of their constituents, and that support will be shown in the ballot box.
