SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 14, after clause 28, insert the following new clause:
Conditions of registration
``28A. Section 73ba of the Principal Act is amended by adding the following subsection:
`(2) A registered organisation shall continue to comply particularly with the conditions set out in paragraph (1g) of the Schedule.
Penalty:
(a) in the case of a first offence-$10 000; or
(b) in the case of a second and subsequent offences-$100 000.'.''.
(2) Page 14, after clause 28, insert the following new clause:
Exemption to Part VIa
``28b. Section 82r of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after `condition' in paragraph (1) (b), `(including the conditions contained in paragraph (1g) of the Schedule)'.''.
(3) Clause 30, page 17, omit subparagraphs (1g) (i) and (ii), substitute the following subparagraphs:
``(i) offer to a contributor to a health benefits fund conducted by the organisation an inducement or encouragement;
(ii) subject, or threaten to subject, such a contributor to a penalty or disadvantage (whether financial or otherwise);
(iii) refrain from offering to such a contributor a benefit; or
(iv) hinder or impede the provision of a benefit to such a contributor;''.
(4) Clause 30, page 18, line 2, omit ``and'', substitute ``or to''.

I have spoken at some length on the need for these amendments. They deal completely with the circumstances relating to paragraph (1g) of the schedule, which I might refer to as the anti-dumping clause. As I argued during the second reading debate, the Opposition believes that this paragraph is not strong enough as it does not contribute to ensuring that the process of dumping can be stopped, particularly as the relevant clause as presently listed in the legislation refers purely to a situation where the Minister may deregister or otherwise appoint an inspector to a very large fund. As I have pointed out, that is impractical and is not in the interests of the contributors. It is not an appropriate penalty for this particular breach, it if were to occur. The Opposition is suggesting that it is much better that a financial penalty be applied, and of course we have suggested that that penalty be large because the financial advantages of being able to get rid of chronically ill patients, of being able to transfer such patients from one fund to another, is very large. I would hope that any magistrate dealing with such a matter in the future would take note of the intention of the Parliament should the Government agree with us now or if we are able to carry these amendments in another place. We want the courts to understand that the penalties have been made this large because, as I have pointed out already, it would not be unreasonable to suggest that transferring just one chronically ill patient could means a saving of up to $10,000 a week in the expenditure of a single fund. Clearly the penalty has to take account of that, otherwise the funds could go on dumping and making a profit, even while paying a fine.
Our first amendment suggests that on page 14, after clause 28, we insert a new clause, as follows:
28a. Section 73ba of the Principal Act is amended by adding the following subsection:
(2) A registered organisation shall continue to comply particularly with the conditions set out in paragraph (1g) of the Schedule.
That is our amendment that deals with dumping. We propose this amendment because section 73ba of the principal Act, the National Health Act, states:

The registration of an organization shall, whether the registration was effected before, or is effected after, the commencement of this section, be deemed to be subject to the conditions set out in the Schedule.

We want to make it very clear that also there is an obligation upon licensed organisations to comply with (1g). We then make out the penalties for the breach of that section, which are, in the case of a first offence, a fine of $10,000 and, in the case of a second and subsequent offences, a fine of $100,000. They are maximum fines.
Our second amendment also refers to page 14 and asks that, after clause 28, we insert the following new clause:
Exemption to Part VIA
'28B. Section 82r of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after ``condition'' in paragraph (1) (b), ``(including the conditions contained in paragraph (1g) of the Schedule)''.'.

Again that is to ensure that 82r, which is a section of the Act which again deals with the appointment of an inspector, will be relevant to these amendments. We also choose to tighten up somewhat the conditions that the Government had already included in its amending legislation. We have moved:
Clause 30, page 17, omit subparagraphs (1g) (i) and (ii), substitute the following subparagraphs:
Subparagraph (i) is very similar to the Government's subparagraph, which stated:
offer to a contributor to a health benefits fund conducted by the organisation an inducement . . .
We have added the words `or encouragement'. At present, subparagraph (ii) reads:
subject, or threaten to subject, such a contributor to a penalty or disadvantage;
We have added the words `whether financial or otherwise'. We also add two additional subclauses:
(iii) refrain from offering to such a contributor a benefit; or
(iv) hinder or impede the provision of a benefit to such a contributor;

We think the last one is very important. One of the practices that has been listed was for a fund so to delay payments and otherwise improperly deal with a contributor as to force him to seek another fund. We do not think that should apply either. We have agreed with what the Government is proposing because we think the amendment will allow people choice but we would not like to see the good work being done destroyed by funds choosing to dump. It is unreasonable to suggest that they will not. As I have said, some funds have pressed so hard to have this provision reinstated that it is impossible to believe that they will lose high-claiming contributors voluntarily. I do not think a large number of contributors will shift but we welcome their doing do voluntarily. There will be a huge temptation on funds to dump out high-claiming contributors. If they do that it will have consequences for us all here. We will be blamed by a lot of people, particularly in Victoria, because the other funds to whom those contributors are dumped will raise their premiums and that will not benefit even the contributors that have shifted.

We are sure that by applying these tougher penalties, making them monetary penalties, we can have at least a reasonable guarantee that such procedures will not occur. I assume that then it will not be incumbent upon only the Government or the Minister to take action, as they would under section 73ba of the National Health Act: if another fund feels it is being dumped upon I would assume that under the normal common law arrangements in Australia it could take some action to have such a prosecution proceed. Those very interested groups will keep their competitors honest, and that is a very significant factor. I do not think it should be upon the Minister to police this provision. I would rather the Minister did not have to get himself another police force and a few more feet in doors. My view is that once we have a monetary penalty and a clear offence for dumping it could be prosecuted by the fund that feels it has been offended against. That describes the Opposition's proposals. We would welcome the support of the Government. We think the proposals are only carrying the matter to a more sensible conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister for Community Services and Health) (11.53)-The Government welcomes very much the support of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the Opposition in supporting the principles that underlie these clauses, which relate to ensuring portability of the pre-existing ailment rule between funds against dumping. As he has so strongly supported the principle I am a little reluctant to point out that these principles directly relate to the preservation of community rating, and his advocacy a few weeks ago of risk rating, which is the opposite, is rather contradictory. It is true that increasingly any one statement coming from the honourable member for O'Connor tends in principle to be contradicted by the next one. I say that gently because the honourable member has supported on this occasion the principle behind this measure-that is, the community rating principle-which we have tried to enshrine with the portability proposal and with the anti-dumping proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage the Government is not prepared to support the amendments, and I shall explain why. I have to say that we look at them sympathetically and, before the Bill goes to the Senate, we will follow up some of the points that have been raised. I point out some of the difficulties that we have in accepting them off the cuff, as I have seen them for only the first time tonight. First of all, in relation to the penalty provisions, the honourable member is suggesting that the deregistration process is a bit of a feather. Obviously, if the only threat we had were deregistration I would accept that. But under section 74 (5) of the National Health Act, where a condition of registration is breached-and we are making these conditions of registration-we can deem that to be a contravention. That contravention can be fined.

It is true that the fine is only up to $5,000. I take the point that the honourable member has made, that perhaps the fine should be a greater amount, may be the best place to amend the provision. However, I think we need to take some care when discussing the amount itself, because those fines will, of course, be taking the funds of contributors. If a fund is fined $10,000 or $100,000, that is money taken away from the contributors. Before the Government accepted fines of that order, I would want to discuss those proposals with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) so that our fines relate to other fines across the system in a comparable way. But this is not to deny that the honourable member for O'Connor has made a significant point, in that by dumping just a few members a fund may be able to make very significant savings.

When we come to the second set of amendments, which relate to defining the nature of dumping more fully or in more precise ways than the Government has, the one caution I would have is that we need to be careful that in making them more precise, we do not enable more loopholes to occur. There is an argument that a more comprehensive, if general, definition of dumping may be safer than precisely spelling it out. But again I am fully prepared to take further advice on that, and if the advice leans in the direction of developing it more precisely, we will certainly take that on board when we introduce the Bill in the Senate. I can clearly see the point the honourable member is making, and we are not opposed to it, because we want to make the anti-dumping provisions effective. But I am told, on the best legal advice I can get, that there is a debate between whether it is safer to do this in a comprehensive way or to spell it out more specifically.

The final amendment is a more difficult one-and it is a pity that the hour is late-because the word `and' is almost a necessary part of the definition of dumping. If people are just driven out of a fund and do not go to any other fund, in a direct sense they are not dumped and there is no immediate effect on another fund. It may be that we want to protect people not just against dumping but against some of the other activities of the funds which may not actually lead to dumping, that is, passing on to another fund. But I think the `and' is absolutely necessary in order to relate to the notion of dumping, that is, passing people from one fund to another. But there may be a point in adding to it an additional protection, and we would certainly look at that.

I indicate to the honourable member that as the proposals he makes are all aimed at strengthening what the Government is trying to do, we will certainly look at them seriously. Before the Bill goes to the Senate we will see what aspects of the amendments can be taken up, because I am not unsympathetic to the proposals he has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and consequently, in accepting his assurances, I will certainly not take this matter to a division tonight. We accept the arrangement and we welcome the opportunity to discuss any alterations. Our particular concern is to ensure that this arrangement works. Nevertheless, I quickly take issue with the Minister's suggestion that in supporting the arrangement I see it as having something to do with community rating. I am well aware that many of the funds believe that this proposal will resolve their problem. Their problem is one of community rating. The Minister may find an alternative solution. I am not at all opposed to the concept, if it can be made to work, that everybody pays the same.

SPEECH.PARA: I made the point earlier tonight that this is an interesting debate for the community, and if both the Government and the Opposition get to the point of being able to raise the issues and have them debated in the community, the community might be better off. But the reality is, as we have discovered, that community rating is an excellent principle if there is only one fund. Everybody is forced to join it. Then there will be a happy mix of young people and old people. Whilst there are competing funds and new funds-we all know that competition is enhanced by new funds-there will never be a perfect mix of young and old within an individual fund. We have discovered that historically the longer a fund is in existence the higher percentage of elderly, high-claiming people in its portfolio. Funds have great difficulty in supplying these people with a decent level of rebate. They just do not have the money. I read a letter to the Parliament once from a woman who said, `Please help me to understand. I have been insured for 10 years. I have just been to a private hospital and had to pay $1,500 extra'. That is not an isolated example, as many honourable members would know.

In raising the problems of the community rating principle, I am not trying to be some sort of smart alec. I certainly have no intention of imposing a burden on our elderly. I am trying to tell the Government that we are fast approaching as situation whereby some of our oldest funds will take the option of closing their doors and reopening at the other end of the market. We have just applied a bandaid for them tonight. I see the proposal as saying that consumers have the right to change from one fund to another. In my mind that is the purpose of this exercise. Its purpose is not to try to prop up long established funds clinging to their little dream that half of their high claiming patients are going to pack up and leave them. As I said, this is the only business I know where one wants some customers to leave. However, there is a very good reason for that.

We should not get paranoid about this argument. We all have a responsibility in this place to ask ourselves whether the long established principle of community rating is working. When it comes to paying benefits to the elderly, it is not working. My party's solution to this problem is yet to be decided. But it is silly to bury our head in the sand and suggest that we come up with a series of bandaid measures. The Minister is probably well aware that he will be under huge pressure in the near future when this little scheme does not achieve the desired results for certain funds. They will come and hammer him about reinsurance.

Reinsurance is another thing that is quite artificial in the health insurance industry. Reinsurance in the general insurance industry is about laying off a substantial risk. Suppose a company insures a $15m building. It may have the capacity to pay out only $5m. Therefore it goes off to Lloyds of London and Lloyds picks up the $10m. But there is no such thing as an individual risk in the health insurance industry that goes beyond the resources of a company. We do not have a company that is so small. So we have this artificial arrangement which says, `We will all sit down at the end of the year and divvy up the profits. We will come up with all these artificial arguments as to why one company should give some of its profits to another'. In other words, the concept is wrong. We are trying to politicise commercial activity. When we do that we invariably get into trouble.

In replying to the Minister's remarks in this area, I say again that in no way am I necessarily endorsing community rating. I support what the Government is trying to do in giving the consumer a go-giving him portability, as the Minister put it. I do not believe that people should be denied health treatment in these circumstances. The Minister has overcome that quite fairly, provided we can be guaranteed that there will be no dumping. I hope the day will come when the Minister and I can have a debate in this place on some of the realities of the private insurance industry, whether it is associated with Medicare or, as I would prefer it, not associated with Medicare. If we do not have a proper, competitive commercial situation someone is going to get hurt. It will not be us. It will not be the funds. It will be certain consumers. On present indications it will be the elderly because they are the ones who are making claims. They are the ones for whom most funds have insufficient money to provide for under the current arrangement. If the Government thinks that problems with Health Australia will never occur, it is wrong. They will. Medibank Private's concerns are probably 15 years down the track. Health Australia's concerns are 10 years down the track, at which stage some vital, new funds will be doing to it what is happening now. I believe that we should be able to have a premium structure that allows the Pensioners League of Australia to have a fund that is just for pensioners with premium levels such that it could pay out adequate rebates and guarantee medical treatment immediately it is needed. That situation immediately requires another; and that is that the Government is prepared to pick up the premium. Never at any stage would I contemplate, as has been suggested in the past, that it would disadvantage the individual elderly person, a person of pensionable age. I just make that point to the Minister. I thank him for his cooperation. He may move the Bill through to the third reading stage and we will not divide.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the right honourable member's question, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On the basis of clarification provided by the honourable member's office the answers provided refer to grey/pink granite, not all granite used on the project.

(1) 1820 cubic metres was the initial quantity cited in the contract for the curved walls. Provision was also made in the contract for its extension to provide for other external requirements such as the landscaping. Thus, the schedule of prices originally agreed on for this contract held provision for such future extensions.
(2) Contractor: Messrs A. G. and A. M. Morris
Source of material: Capital Hill, Eugowra, N.S.W.
(3) The tender document was both lengthy and complex. The following is a summary of the specifications set out in the tender document:
GRANITE DESCRIPTION
General

Grey/pink has been selected for the main cladding which generally shall be a rock which contains abundant phenocrysts of pink orthoclase in a moderately coarse grained grey matric composed of white plagioclase grey quartz and dark biotite and hornblende.
Two (2) examples of acceptable granites of this type may be inspected on site during normal working hours by application to the Superintendent.
Quality Control Criteria
It is essential that the quality of any granite selected for the new Parliament House Project is controlled within very strict limits.

The presence of certain `faults' or `spots' are well known in Australian granites. The visual significance of any such blemish will vary relative to size, colour, frequency and location within any particular panel and the location of the stone of the facade. It is the intent that the granite shall present an even appearance throughout the entire of the facade.

In preparing the criteria for quality control due consideration has been given to all these circumstances. Criteria staged for the two (2) acceptable granites should be taken as a guide and presupposes that no other as yet undetected `blemish' will become evident.
The criteria for the two (2) acceptable granites is as follows:
Grey/Pink Granite
Category A Granites
(External vertical face sills and soffits)
Maximum number of large inclusions:
Maximum number of black spots or small inclusions
Minimum proximity of spots or inclusions-6/1.5m2 50mm x 20mm or 35mm diameter
Maximum size of large inclusions diameter-50mm
Maximum size of small inclusions diameter-20mm
Category B Granites
(Horizontal surfaces of coping only)
Maximum number of spots or inclusions
Minimum proximity of spots
Maximum size of spots or inclusions-6/1.5m2 150mm 60mm in diameter
Discolouration, Staining and Structural Defects
All granite despatched from the quarry shall be of good quality free from weathering discolouration, structural defects and the presence of deleterious minerals such as clays and sulphides.
As far as practicable all material shall be selected to comply with quality criteria and to equal the samples submitted with the Tender Submission.
Evaluation Samples

Three (3) samples not less than 300mm x 300mm indicating anticipated range of variation in overall colour, tone and granular formation for all granites shall be submitted for evaluation in determining the final quality criteria of the selected granite.

(4) The original contract was based on a schedule of rates. The estimated cost of the work based on rates tendered by the successful tenderer, and on the provisional quantities specified in the tender documents, was approximately $790,000.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are social security payments due on Thursdays paid to the banks on Wednesday nights.
(2) Are all banks now instructed to make payments on Thursdays.
(3) Why does the Commonwealth Bank make the payment on Wednesdays and is this equivalent to giving recipients a short term interest free loan.
(4) Could the other banks follow a similar practice to the Commonwealth Bank.
(5) Is he able to say on what legal basis the Commonwealth Bank is able to follow this practice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Details of social security pension payments due on Thursdays together with the funding cheques, are delivered to financial institutions during the three days immediately before the Thursday.
The funding cheques are dated with the Thursday payday date and the Reserve Bank is prohibited from giving value for those cheques until that date.
The Thursday payday may be advanced when it occurs immediately before or during a holiday period.
(2) Under arrangements with the national associations representing financial institutions social security payments are to be available to clients as at the commencement of business on the payday.
My colleague, the Treasurer, as the Minister with portfolio responsibility for the Commonwealth Bank, has provided the following information to parts (3), (4) and (5).

(3) Because of the large number of pension recipients receiving payment through accounts held with the Commonwealth Bank, the Bank has found it necessary, in some circumstances, to make the funds available on the day prior to the designated payday, to ensure that customers' requirements for servicing their accounts can be met.

In cases where funds are withdrawn from an account prior to the pension payday which would not have been available without the pension payment having been anticipated, the practice can be regarded as akin to providing recipients with short-term interest free loan.
(4) Other banks could follow a similar practice to the Commonwealth Bank if they considered it appropriate, having regard to their individual circumstances.
(5) There is no legal restriction on the Commonwealth Bank performing this service, provided it meets any costs involved from its own resources.
